review_title: Runs only on brand name
pros:
>Brand name while switching to next companies
> Cool company if you come to GBS or ISL depts ( please dont join GTS )
> Company inculcates new technologies, but that will not matter individual much
> Hi-Fi Designations
> Once you become a manager, no one can stop you to play & fool around
cons:
> Very Less Hike
> Manager driven company, HR dept is good for nothing
> No transport ( only 7pm to 7am ) 
> Do not join IBM Internal projects
>You are tagged to one dept and if you aspire to move to different technology, company policy itself will not allow you to switch.
> Your work life balance depends on your manager
> Too many boot-lickers for short & long term goals

review_title: Huge IT delivery projects and not much else
pros:
- Great work-life balance
- People are extremely supportive
- Large company so the opportunity is there to get massive cross sector experience (if that's what you want)
- Good place for graduates to start their career in a protected environment
cons:
- Salary is lagging behind the other big consultancy firms
- Watson technology is basically being packaged up and shoved down clients' throats. Good uptake in the USA by clients however the UK has a very limited number of cognitive projects
- Progression from Band 6, and 8 can be slow and bonuses are close to non-existent

review_title: Watson Internal Embed
job_title: Watson Embed Leader in Denver, CO
pros: I get to work with cutting edge technology on a daily basis. I get to be creative and agile to determine new use cases for artificial intelligence in the real world. Sometimes this is with clients and sometimes this is with internal IBM teams collaborating in order to create the next best use for cognitive.
cons: Watson can be applied to various industries in many different ways. Goals and metrics are constantly changing so you have to be flexible and motivated to learn new skills to keep up with the fast paced market.

review_title: Hard grow to really good technical positions - Too much politics and business stuff
job_title: Staf software engineer in São Paulo, São Paulo
pros: Flexibility to work from home when needed (but that is the normal in any tech company I guess)
cons: Too much old people with old thinking. Too much business people and missing real technical talents. It's a business company not a technology company. Salaries are really good only for business people (sales and executives), engineers only get a really good salary if you give your life to the company and become a Band 9/10 (with all the politics you must do to the get there). Pure technical talents are not valued by the company.

review_title: Lots of opportunities but management policies restrict candidates
pros:
-Great exposure
-Awesome allowances
-Decent leave policies
-Manageable work-life balance
-Work from home (enjoyable for some, headache for some)
cons: -Salary of candidates are in a fixed range which should be negotiable and adjusted as per their skills, talent & education and not just merely on 'years of experience' term

review_title: Big company; opportunities await for those who look
pros: There are opportunities to do nearly anything within IBM. I have personally be the beneficiary of many good managers and programs. Although my experience has been exceptional, I have seen other not be so fortunate.
cons: Many managers are removed from their reports and are only focused on utilization. It is a big company and is easy to get lost / challenging to find the right place. Bonuses are a joke; pay bumps are fair, but you won't be getting rich.

review_title: Good company for work life balance and working on cutting edge technology
pros:
1) Opportunity to work on cutting edge technology
2) Have very good work life balance with lot of sensitivity to employee needs
3) Continuous learning opportunity and can switch between technologies as needed
4) Spread across locations enabling one to choose which location they want to work from, provided there are projects in that locations
cons:
1) Poor salaries for existing employees and no talent retainment program
2) Complex promotion structure which keeps employee stagnated in one band for too long
3) Very bureaucratic

review_title: Very Low Salary
pros:
This is in regards to the IBM business center in Lansing, MI only-
The work experience is very fast paced and with multiple teams and projects.
High profile clients.
The benefits are good.
cons:
Lower than the average hiring salary.
Very low bonus amounts given annually after a rigorous application process for them. The bonus is so low it only comes out to $20-$50 more on your monthly paycheck. No option for title promotion or any bonus given. If you work with all remote clients (which the majority of us do) the manager of the building still requires you to come in and work. So you waste time in the morning to go to a building where you work with no one and sit in an open office environment to work remotely. Highly distracting and not productive.

review_title: Big change in the right direction
pros:
Open to change and improvement on a large scale
Employer of choice for LGBT / BMI / Women in tech etc - very supportive environment
Feel valued & empowered
Competitive salary (not the best but fair and stable) 
Great career opportunities
cons:
Quite outdated / lengthy processes, many of which are self driven and 'feel' unsupported e.g. significant HR cases
overly complex business structure 
Very cautious / risk averse 
Matrix structure can make it difficult to navigate new areas/tasks/responsibilities

review_title: Unlimited Great Opportunities
job_title: Offshore Team Lead in Quezon City, National Capital Region
pros: Being one of the leaders on innovation in the whole world, everyone will never be left behind. You just need to exemplify pro-activeness and establish regular sessions with direct supervisor/manager to align your personal career plan and growth. Along the way, you will live up to be a proud IBMer and inculcate its core values and principles.
cons: Sometimes, dispersed team members who are located in different parts of the globe and physically separated manager-employee/group setup may encounter challenges. This may include but not limited to, language barrier (communication issues), time zone variance (sync up problems), unrestrained behaviors (lacking direct governance) and estrangement (compromised camaraderie). But overall, still a great company to be with.

review_title: Not what it used to be, but probably better than most I/T companies
pros: Benefits are excellent. Job flexibility in where you work, when you work, how you work are very positive reasons to be at IBM. Also, there are very smart and engaging people to work with who have high standards and moral integrity.
cons: You can feel just like another number. Constant threat of outsourcing has hurt morale and job security is a thing of the past. Teamwork is also lacking because at the end of the day, most employees feel like its they have to look out for themselves. Thus, atmosphere has become more cut-throat and ultimately, a lot of employees have lost any sense of loyalty.

review_title: Poorly managed company... will not survive too long with all the inefficiencies and poor employee morale
job_title: Hardware Engineer in Research Triangle Park, NC
pros: There are not many, if any good reasons to work for STG.  The only good reason I can think of to work for STG is a steady pay check for the short term.
cons: There is no appreciation or respect for employees, management is incompetent and decisions/promotions/raises are completely political in nature.  It is not what you know or what you do, its who you know.  Upper management is too greedy with the distribution of wealth, leaving employees with only crumbs.

review_title: IBM Canada
pros: IBM Canada offers flexible hours that allow employees to manage the demands of both work and family life.  With the very large product and brand base, there is a lot of variety in assignments, and lots of opportunity for technical growth.
cons: IBM has long hours because the products you support are available worldwide.  Customers could have questions and problems from virtually any country and you need to be able to respond on a very short time line to inquiries.   In addition, a lot of roles are being sent to other countries, and the training and support of the other countries requires long hours and significantly extra effort because of the language barriers.

review_title: Great Experience out of College!
job_title: Staff Software Engineer in Atlanta, GA
pros: The opportunity to work for such a global company. IBM sets the pace in many technology sectors.  Skills learned here are in high demand outside of IBM. As a software engineer got to work on latest and greatest web technologies and got a job really quickly after leaving IBM. I was able to rotate around to different software brands building a good portfolio of knowledge of software offerings. From development to application software.
cons: the BIG in Big Blue. Sometimes feel kind of distant. Most of HR is taken care in a central place, e.g Raleigh, NC.  Also most people are very good at what they do making promotions kind of hard to attain.

review_title: In 10 years there won't be any US IBM engineers.  All engineers "rebalanced" to India.
job_title: Hardware Engineer in Research Triangle Park, NC
pros:
Management supports working from home.
Good group of people to work with.
cons:
Frequent layoffs.  Gradual shift of workers from US to India.
Understaffed for amount of work.  Poor communication from project managers.
Unreasonable project schedules that have just become a joke.
No sense of big picture, everything is week to week survival.
Upper management seems to be only concerned with profit and their stock options.
Difficult to see where you fit in such a large corporation.
Can easily have first line manager be in some other geography hundreds of miles away.
Working remotely from the main group can leave workers feeling isolated and lost.

review_title: Like living in a socialist country with a healthy quality of life and full of soccer moms and dads.
pros:
1. Above average workplace environment
2. Possible to explore other parts of a large organization
3. Education and skills growth
4. Looks good on a resume
5. Management and implementation methodologies are good (on paper)
cons:
1. Cliques mean good opportunities go to friends and families, impossible to break into the "Club"
2. Lot of dead weight
3. Professional development managers are (typically) not great achievers and don't know how to motivate or manage high-performance employees
4. In practice, technical excellence is not given high priority; is fundamentally a sales organization
5. Easy to get stuck in a silo and feel like Rip Van Winkle in a couple of years

review_title: The IBM brand is still strong, but there are definitely better consulting firms to work for.
pros: There are a wide variety of projects available to Consultants within GBS and the brand name of IBM still goes a long way.  Additionally, opportunities for professional advancement/training are abundant.
cons:
Opportunities to be staffed on projects outside of your service area are rare, so if you wanted to move from say Supply Chain Management to Finance, don't count on it.
Additionally, movement between the Public and Private Sector practice areas is equally rare.
If you are staffed on the client site on a small project team, your exposure to Managers and other IBMers can be very limited.

review_title: Working for IBM STG
job_title: Senior IT Specialist in Austin, TX
pros:
- Great technology
- Ability to switch and do something new every couple of years
- Extensive training opportunities
cons:
- Salaries are not competitive
- Lack of motivation and employees recognition from management

review_title: Big Blue
pros:
* Very collaborative environment: people all around the world no matter their 'rank' are willing to share their insights if needed.
* Huge amount of intellectual capital: frameworks, methodologies, project deliverables (GBS Practitioner Portal, Institute for Business Value)
* Strong brand
* Highly professional environment.
cons:
* very limited possibilities for international projects
* training in GBS could be better (compared to the rest of IBM)
* clear separation between GBS and the rest of IBM (cultural difference)
* high performers don't get sufficient recognition 
* still strong focus on IT, less business consulting

review_title: A company in flux
pros: Top technology name, great resources for technology smarts.  Large consulting and software business.  Well known name.  Largest global outsourcer.  Recognized worldwide.  Have moved globally quickly with people and sales.  Smarter planet seems to be working well as a marketing campaign.
cons: Short term focus on people.  Moving jobs overseas at a rapid pace.  Frequent downsizing.  Changes in direction on the consulting side are frequent.   Changes in middle level management frequently.   They have never gotten all the parts of the business working effectively together; often work across purposes.  Losing ground to MSFT and Oracle in enterprise software.

review_title: Very good work place where you can enjoy relaxation
pros:
1) Flexibility
2) Brand name
3) Work life balance
4) Good career growth
5) Depending on project you will get onsite chance.
6) work from home
cons:
1) Bad HR policies
2) There is no proper seats for employees.
3) Managers are exploiting IBM policies and they are making lots of money. ( Eg - GSS bangalore managers)
4) Last four years no hike, when we will ask they will tell we will send you to US for one month.
5) In GSS team about 45% people are from Andhra, Guntur - one of the managers native. Some of the guys don't have degree. After 2 to 3 yrs continous working they will become IBMers

review_title: Situation in Hungary IBM
pros: International Blue Chip Company, good for CV.
cons: Even if it is a International Company in Hungary, I was in a team full of Hungarians. So generally I was left off, and in my opinion everyone was fake just to show a friendly environment to the management. Many colleagues are afraid of competition. If I had been doing good I was criticized to the management not to get a negative view to the management. So till the end I was not interested to make some effort for my position.

review_title: IBM has remarkable people and excellent infrastructure, but career-wise, I'm looking for something more.
pros: Consistently excellent colleagues and teamwork mentality. Robust infrastructure, extremely huge  intranet, and generally great management. Great work environment. I feel safe and able to do my work. Everyone is busy and productive here--and some people are truly remarkable.
cons: Career development can be challenging, especially because there is too much to do and sometimes not enough interest in how to best utilize talent. Opportunities for career exploration and side projects are well-advertised within the company, but difficult to execute on a general engineer/technical staff level. Especially if you want to grow skills in a slightly different technical area. However, this is perhaps inherent for all large companies.

review_title: Disappointing and discouraging
job_title: Long Term Supplemental Role in East Lansing, MI
pros:
Decent health insurance (if you pay for the step-up plan)
Well known company
Access to all documentation
Access to self-paced training on a variety of topics
cons:
Low salaries in comparison to the market
Employees are micromanaged
Experienced professionals are treated like children
Attendance is taken 
Employees (might) have one square yard of work space in the office
Employees are discouraged from working from home, even when their clients request it
Long term supplemental employees are not allowed to post for "regular" jobs for 18 months from when they were hired.

review_title: Good if you are stratified with low salary. Never bet on elephant in race
pros:
It has well defined rules that makes empoyee to understand what he could expect in each case.
Benefit of working from home somtime.
Good training program.
Good overall professional culture.
cons:
Salary increment is very low. It is not good to spend lot of years in IBM. The junior get double of the salary. 
You band does not progress in spite of you spend many years performing roles.
Some managers are very arrogant.
No significant achievement award, year end party or many team lunch. 
The extra curricular activity in the team is null.

review_title: It all depends on the team.
job_title: User Experience Designer in Research Triangle Park, NC
pros:
Flexible work/life balance, easy to work remotely.
Pay is satisfactory.
Company policies can be short sighted and frustrating.
cons:
Difficult to get promoted. Especially if you're not a typical role like a developer.
Employee evaluations are subjective, it all depends on your management.
Each team works differently. Overall the IBM culture is friendly and fair, but if you join a recent aquisition, for example, you may not be treated "fairly" by the non-IBM environment.
Work environment has become depressing over the years, with most people working from home. Not a lively place to work anymore.

review_title: Comfortable, Insightful and a great learning experience - especially how things are managed professionally in IBM
pros: Employer friendly policies such as flexible hours, work from home, unlimited sick leaves, and a good workplace environment. Managers show faith and trust in employees. Communication channel is fairly good.
cons: Promotion and career growth within the company can be too slow. Many free-riders can go unnoticed owing to the large size of the company. In spite of automation in basic HR processes, there is a need for a HR POC. People manager concept puts too much load on managers for them to help their employees well enough.

review_title: Good training, not a job for long term
pros: Good training ground for new graduates.  Especially in consulting, a chance to learn a lot by working with many clients.
cons:
You get locked in into one area of specialization and industry - difficult to then work with clients in other industries if you want to 
Opaque career level ("band") structure and salary levels associated with them - no manager ever showed what is the salary range for a band; you have to guess or figure out from colleagues what is possible. 
Very slow and opaque promotion process
Low salaries compared to similar companies; good benefits though.
Grueling schedule for consultants, driven by utilization requirements that sometimes were 100%
A lot of things sound good on paper (benefits, mentorship programs) but they are not realized after that

review_title: A looonnnnggg  grind....
pros: Some very good people to work with, and the opportunity to work on large client accounts utilising cutting edge technologies
cons:
- plenty of deadwood, particularly in lower level management
- remuneration lower than market rates
- excessive levels of process
- staff treated like numbers
- too much sending work to lower cost centre areas overseas
- 'variable pay' : 10% of your remuneration package that you will only see if a miracle occurs, bank on about 1-2%
- bring overseas workers to take Australians' jobs due to a supposed skill shortage

review_title: An excellent learning experience
pros:
* Decent pay
* Interesting projects -- IBM has their hands in a lot of cool stuff
* Lots of opportunity to move around (and up)
* Work with the best equipment (IBM makes some of the best servers, storage units, etc.)
* Big company, meaning nice perks like travel, up-to-date equipment, etc.
cons:
* Situated in Markham
* I was doing my internship during the recession of 2008.  I was quite put off by the fact that I saw many senior-level people shown the door around January of 2008, while, at the same time, IBM was continuing to hire interns for cheap labour.  Ultimately, I decided to go to grad school instead of accepting the full-time offer of employment that they made to me.  Nevertheless, I had a great time there and learned a lot.

review_title: A once great company, now a disgrace
pros: A great company if you have family and need the flexibility to work from home or take care of the kids. Still at the same time working. Decent health benefits as well.  If you don't like to do any work but like to talk as though you are doing work, this is the company for you.
cons: No 401k match. No pay raises unless you're an executive. No job growth unless you're best friends with upper management or legacy into the IBM family. The only employees that get ahead are those that throw their work over the fence and take credit for others work and accomplishments.

review_title: No Frills - IBM is the world we live in.
job_title: Architect in Warwick, West Midlands, England
pros:
- Talented people.
- Truthworthy.
- IBM culture and the people that are here are very consistent.
- Has breadth and depth in terms of industry sectors IBM operates in and range of work (services, software and hardware).
- You can leave a very well rounded person.
- Job security.
cons:
- Average pay and very average benefits.
- Poor bonus scheme.
- Experienced people are not valued. The technical experienced persons must become salesman or be ill treated and leave eventually.
- Struggle to communicate all the range of things going on across the company.

review_title: Solid and reliable, yet tough to push for change from the middle
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Research Triangle Park, NC
pros: Tons of good smart people.  Lots of different possibilities for work, if you can get approval to transfer there.
cons: Due to the size, often hard to effectively execute on change (not very nimble).  It takes a ton of effort consensus building, getting buy-in, securing resources and finally (if you ever get there)  ability to execute on the idea or change.  Also often have got mediocre evals with no warning of what I need to change or improve.

review_title: Too big and too politics
job_title: Staff Software Engineer in Markham, ON
pros:
Big company, many fields you can work on or learn.
Very computer science and has good smart colleague to guide you.
Work time is flexible once you master your work. For me no overtimes.
cons:
Too big and too politics. Wasting resource and time all the time...
The evaluation process is just discouraging people to "work hard" rather than to "work smart"
Very like to have the trend of missing middle level good people, either young fresh students, or old "senior" people who more likely to "work smart" but getting the high pay instead of get things done...

review_title: Lost in a deep BLUE abyss
job_title: Human Resources Leader in Washington, DC
pros: Very smart people, with deep personal and professional commitment, who remain blissfully unaware that they will have no future.
cons: One of the most depressing, alarmingly arrogant and confused IT companies in the world. Acting like wolves, hunting in small packs, they eventually run out of food and are then forced to eat their own kind.  Greed remains the key motivation for leadership, who will seemingly stop at nothing to best a colleague, weaken a partner or flip a customer. Reckless outsourcing of American jobs for low paid, often unqualified personnel in so called “growth markets”. Stay away from this work environment.

review_title: Bright ideas and great minds company.
job_title: Global Software Enterprise Architect in Amsterdam
pros: IBM has a lot of smart where you can learn from and achieves unbeatable solutions. Corporate ethical values are the best in my few. With 400k employees, there is always something to do. Due to the company size and long history, access to C-level is most often easy.
cons: Work-life balance is under pressure, although first line management try to help. Getting bright solution from the design table to production is hard, most often people are not willing to invest and spend time on long term relation with customers. Shareholder driven organisation. Promotions and compensation plans are getting worse.

review_title: IBM and the other old guard companies
job_title: Senior Design Verification Engineer in Oakland, CA
pros: They have been in business for a very long time, have re-invented themselves repeatedly in order to stay relevant, and they are relevant still. They are also very DEEP and forward thinking in terms of technology, still have one of the cutting edge semiconductor research capabilities along with software as well. No they aren't always as sexy as the latest valley social media knockoff startup but are still, in my mind, as an engineer, pretty solid
cons: They are a LARGE company, and you do have to spend some time figuring out how to navigate within the organization. Due to their size they can sometimes be. I worry a bit because like many other tech companies, they undervalue doing development domestically at times and are under pressure to streamline in areas where I think in the long term could be leaders

review_title: Supply Chain Analyst
job_title: Supply Chain Analyst in Essex Junction, VT
pros:
1) People are great, willing to help
2) IBM is great name to have on resume 
3) Good way to start career
cons:
1) Lack of formal training, disorganized management strategy
2) Lack of opportunity to advance due to bad performance in the division, promotions and raise are hard to come by
3) Managers expect you to work weekends and after hours - although the hours can be flexible
4) Managers disconnected with what employees actual do - inability to make business decisions, decisions and works progresses very slowly
5) Culture lacks energy and employees lack work ethnics - most people are ready to retire no incentive to work hard

review_title: Riding the death spiral.
pros: Its a good place to start because they're always in the market for dirt cheap labor. If you're fresh out of school, they will charge their clients for an experienced developer as long as you have a pulse.
cons: Management hates employees, that's the only explanation for many of their compensation and promotion policies, openly forcing employees to engage in "competitive differentiation" which simply makes for the cutest hostile work environment, everyone trying to make their peers look bad and screwing everyone to cover their behinds. Instead of fixing problems finding new amazing stuff to blame on each other. But in the end is the person who the manager likes the most (or hates less) who gets promoted.

review_title: Managing Consultant
job_title: Anonymous Employee in New York, NY
pros: Provides great breadth of services, many smart people, and an offering catalog that is second to none. Has a name and reputation that almost everyone around the world can instantly recognize.
cons: Global Business Services is slow to adapt to the market and is often held back by its size and overhead. There is a lack of focus on talent retention and often senior leaders are powerless to help keep top employees.

review_title: Ibm - Long term supplement employee ( Contract)
job_title: Long Term Supplement Employee in Charlotte, NC
pros: Benefits as per with IBM employees. Support for benefit is great.  Other than that , I have got nothing.
cons:
Corruption.
 When I got selected by client , the recruitment coordinator for IBM contacted me through common friend ( small Indian community in CLT) to lure me to join to his bro-in-law's company- which is a vendor to IBM. 
When I complained to someone in the  the Partner level , he sent the  recruitment coordinator to India for couple of months - and now , after 2 and half , he is back with the same position same place . 
The partner must have got real mad at me for complaining , since after that he never spoke to me and generally everyone in IBM ( employees) ignores me.

review_title: Pre-Sales / IT Specialist
job_title: Anonymous Employee in New York, NY
pros:
Flexible work schedule. Every day and every engagement is a way to learn new things. At IBM, you never stop learning and gaining knowledge. You can never get bored. You are always challenged with new products, new solutions and new business problems.
No Micro-management. Good Pay. 
I just LOVE IBM!
cons:
Nothing major. With so many people working there and so much knowledge generated it is sometimes difficult to get quickly to the person or information you need. 

No coffee machines, snacks at IBM Offices.

review_title: Okay place to work for
job_title: Staff Software Engineer (Band 7 Software Developer) in Emeryville, CA
pros:
* Supportive management
* Very little micromanagement
* Competitive Salary
* Excellent Benefits
cons:
* Not too many extra perks such as outings or  meals or gym memberships or extra vacation days 
* If things go wrong, it can take some time to get them fixed.
* Work culture is okay. Split into various micro groups.
* 401K match contribution only happens at the end of the year. If you leave before year end, you forfeit the company's contribution.
* Not much support for personal growth except for what is offered by company itself.
* Monthly employee recognition process makes no sense.
* Finally, the company has implemented a new way to evaluate performance based on input from employees. Have to wait till the end of the year to see how it works out.

review_title: The Good, the Bad and the Ugly
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Perth, Western Australia
pros: The Good ... well that's what the IBM company use to be and for those of us who have been here a while (10 years plus), it's that memory of a once great company that helped put man on the moon is why we stay.  Work/life balance is excellent, however with co-location coming down the pipe this may change soon.
cons: The Bad and Ugly is not knowing when you will be RA'd.  It may not happen today but it will happen. Staff morale is plunging and in free fall now and most FLM have little interest in being transparent and motivation their teams.  Everything is manageable within IBM if it wasn't for the constant threat of being RA's.  It's everyone for themselves as people scramble to try and find new roles externally.  Come here at your own risk.

review_title: Not the worst, but corporate
pros: Salary and benefits are decent compared to local average (in the IT department at least). Work/life balance is also quite good. Option for frequent home-office. There are some interesting projects, and some very smart guys working on them. Freedom to work on your own way - results matter more than the way leading to them.
cons:
Not all colleagues are very smart - there are not many employable people in this market, they try to hire most interviewed people, if they show at least a minimum amount of intelligence. (There is an almost constant hiring frenzy in many departments)
It is a classic corporate job, lot of bureaucracy, everyone is a cell in a worksheet, though for some it might be a pro. If you don't know IBM, you will be surprised how small amount of IT-related things are really done.

review_title: IBM India GBS Retrospective from Current IBMer
pros: Provide broad range of services and have very complex methods for each delivery areas. Provide Work from Home opportunity on a need basis.
cons: IBM is going through major internal transformation and trying to position itself primarily as Cloud platform company with strong focus on cognitive computing. However, as IBM India is primarily viewed as cost center, this technology shift related growth opportunities hardly reaching in its realm and existing GBS projects are just viewed as money fueling mechanism to support this technology shift. So salary growth, especially for IBM India GBS employees are heavily impacted even for high performing accounts.

review_title: Opportunity, Equality and Diversity
pros: In 20 years at IBM, for the second time in my long working career, I've had the opportunity to be part of and drive some amazing transformational programs.  There are opportunities to work in a diverse range of careers where the work that you do can really make a difference for employees, for clients and for the world outside. Now at the end of my working career I'm so grateful that IBM's long tradition of diversity allows me to continue in a rewarding career past normal retirement age.
cons: IBM is working hard to shake off its bureaucratic image but it takes time. Sometimes that can be a source of frustration. Working in a global role, I have to work some unsociable hours. It is not a 9-5 job but it still offers considerable flexibility in managing one's workload.

review_title: Digital Development Sales
job_title: Digital Development Sales in Atlanta, GA
pros:
• Excellent Benefits

• Good Education 

• Great Clients and Business Partners

• Great Place to start a career in technology
cons:
• Layoffs quarterly. Experienced, top performing salespeople are being affected. 

• Several Sales Managers are not staying educated. They are not leading and/or preparing members of the team to go to the next level. They are not familiar the team’s job tasks. Focused on playing politics with other managers.

• The “Bonus Plan” is too subjective. Sales reps on this plan are paid from a pool of money. Managers determine how much each sales rep makes.

• Limited career growth

review_title: Good place to work at but could be better
pros:
- WFH (3 days)
- Work life balance
- Flexibile hours 
- They encourage you to innovate and force you to study at least 40 hours  every year.
- Equipment
- Asociación de empleados
- Transportation but is not free.
cons:
- Salaries are not bad but they are below the market
- Month payment
- Is really hard to get a salary increase or a good promotion
- WPS policies sometimes are annoying
- They force you to do OT in order to recover time for your vacations ( something that I've never understood )
- They pay you the OT but only after de 12th hour per day 
- Some managers have favoritism with older employees

review_title: IBM Research, for the best and brightest
job_title: Research Manager in San Jose, CA
pros: IBM Research has some really smart people working on very interesting problems.  There is a lot of freedom to work on our own ideas, which leaves us responsible for our own success and failure.  There is also a lot of freedom in work/life balance -- I don't know anyone who has the same freedoms that I have (working from home when I want, travel, etc).
cons: Politics often define which research projects ultimately fail and succeed, and you have to learn to play the game.  It can be quite difficult to get a good project into product.  Salary and benefits used to be very good, though they have been tightening in the last few years.

review_title: Innovative market leader with many opportunities for talented staff.
job_title: Senior Engineering Manager in London, England
pros: Extensive number of opportunities.  Can change career direction without have to change company.  Is a world leader in many areas.  Always new products come through, research into new markets, etc.  IBM rewards success, with rewards and bonuses very much skewed towards the top performers.  If you are good - you can be very successful at IBM.
cons: Bureaucracy can by trying.  Expense controls seem ever more draconian.  As a manager, I feel like I'm more of a process administrator, rather than a leader with true authority to make decisions.  I am able to do far less now, than I could 10 years ago.

review_title: IBM is great; just don't expect a large commission compared to most technology companies if you are in Technical Sales.
job_title: Consulting IT Specialist in Dallas, TX
pros: Large community of people and resources to work with.  It's usually easy to find expertise.  There are always opportunities to learn more and work with some of the best minds in the industry.  Help customers see value in the payback they'll achieve by deploying solutions end-to-end across their enterprise to achieve a Service Oriented Architecture. Whether your in software, hardware or services -- whether you do sales, development, marketing, or product advocacy, IBM will challenge you to give your best and provide the best to companies across many geographies and industries.  At IBM, you can build specialized or broad-based knowledge and experience.
cons: Cuts in commission, especially for technical sales.

review_title: working at IBM
pros: Good growth opportunity available and good exposure to domain competency. The way the senior management guides the middle management is just stupendous. The flexibility in working hours add advantage to hire great talents through out the world. The employee friendly policies and open structure makes them feel empowered and the voice of concerns are acted upon immediately providing the employees with self satisfaction. Be it group events organized within the company, or official parties dinners, seminars, trainings, everything is so fun filled that one doesn't feel the pressure of performing. Hence we can say that performance comes naturally when the company is so friendly to their employees.
cons: Low salary paid as compared to industry standards. Lack of awareness towards the society from the company might add a bad name to the company.

review_title: It's a good company to work for.
job_title: Senior Sales Analyst in Atlanta, GA
pros: You get to work with intelligent people who are also nice.  Brand-name recognition.  Generous compensation package.  Being able to telecommute saves time wasted sitting in traffic, helps the environments, and boosts employee productivity.  I'm not a morning person, but happily works late into night sometimes if needed.  Management in general are competent and understanding.  It doesn't hurt that employees get all sorts of little perks, too, from discount show/movie tickets to free museum admission, from travel priviledges (cheaper car rental, hotel stays) to employee pricing at some of the customer websites -- Apple, Sony, Panasonic, GE, Sharp, Philips, to name a few.
cons: Politics, politics, politics.  A lot of decisions are made from top down.  Bureaucracy.

review_title: IBM - I've Been Mislead, mistreated, miserable
job_title: Customer Fulfillment Professional in Raleigh, NC
pros: work from home mobility is nice.  IBM has nice logo items.
cons: Senior management is only interested in keeping stock price high.  IBM is always offshoring jobs.  2/3 of IBM employees are outside the US now.  Vacation blackout dates for a total of 2 months each year.  Management has not mentioned a word to it's US employees, and over 5,000 have lost their jobs in the last two weeks.  They rule by fear and intimidation.  When you manage good business results, you don't get a raise, and instead are fed the line "at least you have a job" all while IBM records record revenue.

review_title: IBM STG is good for computer engineers, hardware engineers and physicists but not good for computer science engineers.
pros: Place for discovering innovation. Plenty of opportunities to move within STG for good-fit. Many opportunities to learn new technologies and contribute to the same.
cons:
STG's primary business model is to make and sell hardware products - high end servers/data storage/mid range server/storage. This makes it hard to change course midway. 
STG is not a good fit for computer science professionals (e.g. BS or MS in CS).

review_title: A good place to start....
pros:
Competitive pay
Great benefit plan
Continued bonuses during recession
Work/Life balance
Ability to attain skills necessary to career development
Great people to work worth on the peer level
cons:
Senior Management is disconnected from day-to-day activities which leads to a lack of oversight and inability to address issues when necessary.

Senior management seems to be more concerned about keeping clients happy rather than making sure employees develop careers and are challenged in the work place.

Work load is very inconsistent, which is a reflection of the client's needs, but also a reflection of the mismanagement of client expectations and unrealistic deadlines.

review_title: Consultant
pros:
The 401k benefits are outstanding.
The opportunity to do many projects in various areas are excellent.
The opportunity to work in many different locations are excellent as well.
cons: You are the only person responsible for your career.  Employees are just another number.  The way promotions are handled are completely unfair.  Do not expect to get raises.  They do not develop their employees.  They will lay people off if they do not have projects to work on.
