review_title: Right Person on Wrong Place
pros:
Open work culture 
Work is work is work 
Exposure to different role
Can get everything technically if you have a proper network  
Few people are overloaded with work
cons:
No much activity beyond work ( might me specific to division I am in ) 
Salary is not as per market 
Clarity in not there in terms of roadmap 
No definite growth path for technical person ( Sales & Marketing Division ) 
Little / No benefit for extra effort 
At times more work less time & or intimation at wrong time 
Replication of work within the organization

review_title: Good place to start as a fresh graduate
pros: You have the opportunity to work in a ,multi-national environment, with people from all over the world, gain experience as  for an entry-level, suitable to be added in your CV.
cons:
Very low salaries compared with other similar IT companies, people are working as to gain experience , as long as you are staying as much you  realise that bureocracy is the most characteristic for  Brno DC. 
Neverending promises as at the final performance evaluation ,nothing will change, even if you had been a valuable employee.
No meal vouchers.

review_title: Overworked, sales comp plan has *gotchas*
job_title: Sales Representative in New York, NY
pros:
For Sales folks - you can leverage the client team matrix (I have heard - so far it hasn't worked for me)
If you can reach them, there are some really SOLID tech folks (when customers complain about bugs)
cons:
Sales plan is dismal at best - if you work the same amount at another company, you probably would make twice as much.. 
many gotchas in the sales comp plan - not the best way to retain hard working sales folks
Competitive products within IBM itself - and you probably would be selling only one of those products
no work/life balance - you are expected to work over the weekends
Takes 3-4 days for folks to respond to your emails if it is not urgent
Not a place to make money

review_title: It is a hard place to work, to much corporate overhead and irrelevance
pros: Good training, encourage working from home, good with work/life balance issues and they try to accommodate peoples unique personal situations within the working environment
cons: To many internal meetings that are pointless, to much "you have to do this to comply with requirements" so people just go through the motions, such as on-line updates on products. To much dead-wood around the place, lack of local authority to approve anything, processes that are far to rigid which make it hard and waste time. Not enough emphasis on doing what is right for the customer, things have to fit within the IBM policies and procedures or they simply do not happen.

review_title: Pays as little as possible, helps employees as little as possible
job_title: Manufacturing Technician in Essex Junction, VT
pros: Reasonably good people work at IBM
cons:
Everybody's hands are tied.  Nobody can help you.  You will be paid as little as possible while your benefits are chipped away.  

There is a strong sinking ship feeling.  Early this year there was a significant layoff.  Just a few weeks ago, furlough.  This is scary.

review_title: Not the same company anymore
job_title: Business Operations Manager in East Fishkill, NY
pros: The people and the innovative culture of behind the products.
cons: work-life balance has gotten out of balance and is more like work-work balance.

review_title: Started well, but going downhill
pros: IBM has lots of great people.  There is a wide variety of work available, although not always what you want to do where you want to do it.  Most offices employ flexibility of working hours, and projects understand that its not a 9-5 clocking in job.  My local office is close to home
cons:
IBM employs a staff ranking system against a Bell curve, meaning that 10%+ are always deemed not to have done enough - doesnt work in a company where everybody goes over and above.  
No delegated responsibility or rewards, just blame.  
There is also a culture of working longer hours being 'rewarded' more than working smarter, or being more productive with your time.

review_title: It was good while it lasted, but was going downhill quickly, so I left on my own terms and am happy I did.
job_title: Software Sales Representative in Toronto, ON
pros: Flexibility, work from home, ability to change jobs every 2 years, really great group of people
cons: low base pay, horrible conversion to US dollars, high quotas, you can only make money every 2 years.  Training has dropped drastically and they do not invest in their people like they did over 10 years ago.  Too many people in upper management positions.  Everyone who makes, or exceeds plan does not get 100% club trip, or bonus money, it only goes to a select few and you cannot bring your spouse.  I can go on and on....

review_title: Managed by a spreadsheet
pros: Working for IBM is like working for many different companies, so potentially you can move about and build your career without changing companies.
cons: Employees taken the burden of what I like to call "IBM Blue Overhead". There are processes, tools, databases by the 1000s. Getting help or support often requires contacting someone in another country. Raises and bonuses are abysmal. They have off-shored so many internal support positions that basically you need to be your own IT help desk, HR partner, and BA. Your first line manager has virtually no control over your salary, raises, bonuses.

review_title: Managed to Wall Street rather than to customers or employees or for long term growth
job_title: Band 8 Tech Services in Dubuque, IA
pros: In the fifteen years I was there, I worked with many very talented people across the globe.  In the late '90's, talent and technical depth were developed, nurtured and expected to excel, and work/life balance and the internal culture was built to retain the best of the best.  The people within IBM from that period, in the first two management tiers, are outstanding.
cons: With the Service Delivery Center concept, people became commodities, and the brain trust in services was drained.  Work life balance eroded along with benefits, training and retention.  Executive direction became obsessed with quarterly reporting to Wall Street and the bonuses at the expense of long term performance planning and responsible expense planning, resulting in whimsical and contradictory leadership.

review_title: Acquired By IBM Lotus
pros: Lots of good benefits.  Lots of good people.  Very strong with Enterprise clients and complex solutions.
cons: Lotus business seems to be in decline.  Lots of big committee like meeting.  Slow to make decisions. Small business and smaller opportunities tend not to get much interest or support because managers have big numbers to make.

review_title: Not so much growth career-wise
job_title: Applications Developer in Quezon City, National Capital Region
pros:
-Flexible working hours. 
-Ability to work at home. 
-There are multiple opportunities to enhance one's technical skills through trainings (online/classroom).
cons:
-People Managers are also Project Managers, this makes their roles conflicting as they tend to focus more about the company rather than its workforce. 
-Contrary to its values being promoted among employees, process is very poor, if there is even one in force. 
-Holidays are accounted for utilization. If there are public or non-working holidays (Christmas, New Year), you have to render overtime to take back lost hours which is ridiculous.

review_title: Mostly harmless
pros:
View from the office in Moscow City is cool (-:
Compensation package for discharge was given ok and fairly, no complains.
The project (bank infrastructure installation and support) was interesting.
If you're a corporate warrior and career-oriented person with corporate values and right attitude -- you'll be ok.
cons:
Office became overcrowded since people from one floor were moved to the other office spaces.
If your project is over (or you don't have enough "billable" hours in your workload) -- it's your problem. If you have no billable hours -- you're a candidate to be fired in a month (or two). HRs are supposed to find you something but actually i haven't seen the positive result of their work.
The Russian office is really bureaucratic.
Everything, from health insurance to coffee should be payed by employee (insurance is to be paid partly, let's be fair)

review_title: IBM - Big Blue
job_title: Senior Technical Specialist in Overland Park, KS
pros: IBM is a globally respected company and one of the few companies capable of handling the IT requirements of the world's largest and most complex enterprises.  IBM is also a leader in the latest technology advances related to cloud, analytics, data, mobile, and AI.   Many IBMers work remotely, and the company rates highly as an equal opportunity employer
cons: IBM jobs in the US are drying up.  Cost pressures and are driving job opportunities overseas.  IBM is forced to treat US employees as costs they would get rid of if they could.  This is especially true in Technology Services and Strategic Outsourcing.

review_title: It is what you make of it
pros:
- Flexibility, flexibility, flexibility - as everything is done by your laptop, there is no need to be in the office if you don't have meetings. 
- Offices across the UK in all major cities that you are able to work from
- Competitive pay for industry 
- Good graduate community and support network
cons:
- If you want to be recognised then you need to constantly be updating your manager with how great you are doing. 
- Company is slow and relies on reputation rather than innovation
- Overly bureaucratic and complex to complete even simple things
- Luck of the draw in terms of what role you are given. Some are far more difficult than others and some provide far more opportunities.

review_title: IBM Research: Best Industrial Research Lab in the World
job_title: Research Staff Member in Yorktown Heights, NY
pros:
IBM Research is the best place to work in IBM:
 - Interesting and difficult problems to solve
 - Highly intelligent coworkers, expert in a wide range of fields
 - Chance to influence the future of the company
 - Connected to industry and academia
 - Offices! (Researchers need places to hunker down and concentrate)
cons: IBM is very bureaucratic and seems set on saving money by cutting everywhere they can, often to the detriment of employees and their morale. IBM Research is only partially exempted from these problems.

review_title: Off to a good career start, hard to shine
pros:
- good opportunity for people without previous work experience  to gain knowledge across various vastly different departments and centers (accounting, finance, operations...),  only basic logical thinking and fluent English needed
- possibility to manage time and deadline (but highly dependent on department)
- possibility of home office and part time/telework
- many internal rotation opportunities (starting minumum one year in a role)
cons:
- bad compensation and pay raises
- shrinking benefits each year
- unclear communication about usage of social funds to employees
- cost saving/cutting initiatives recurring each year

review_title: Much has changed and not for the good
pros: Big organization and ability to move to different/diverse roles.  Flexibility.  Reasonable place to work if you have a supportive manager
cons: Low morale with increasing job losses (RAs).  Rolling RAs even when local teams have limited pre-sales technical coverage.  For many products in AP, IBM has less technical SMEs on the ground that most startups/competitors.  Layers of management and executives mainly managing up.

review_title: Frequent layoffs.  Stagnated salaries
pros: Knowledgeable and smart colleagues.  Good work balance.
cons: The company has mass lay offs frequently. Almost half of their employees are on contract, most of whom have been let go from their full time roles,  only to be brought back on contract three months later.  All this while the CEO draws 32 million dollars a year in salary and writes herself a check of around 3 millions dollars as "bonus". How can she get a bonus when the company is performing badly and the other employees don't get any?!

review_title: Lions lead by Donkeys
pros:
They have a well organized structure. 
If you are in an area that does not need to have it's numbers reduced the work environment is quite pleasant.
Good people work here.
Pension and benefits were very good
cons:
Very bureaucratic
Extremely process driven in all area's
If you are in an area where they need people gone, the work environment and management policies become quite toxic.
They do not pay competitive salary's
Salary raises are hard to get and when you do get one they are risible, I got yearly ratings of 1 (the highest) and I got a 1%  salary rise.
Training was non-existent
The in-house technology that they wish you to push is often inferior once it's been IBM-ized

review_title: Only Kolkata IBM is good
pros:
-Flexible working hours.
-Like other big big MNCs card punch, 9 hr office rule are not here
-Laptop for everybody.
-unlimited sick leaves with valid medical certificates.
-Flexible work from home.
-Best Learning and training platform.
cons:
-All the above mentioned pros are not applied for Chennai IBM. There mostly old employees with typical judgmental mindset work.
- They will  spoil your carrier just because you are not staying in office  min 9hr. 
- Bangalore IBM has all good carrier opportunities, but there u to work more than 60hrs in a week, but max 45hr labor you can claim. 
- Apart from Bangalore, you cant get jobs on latest skills like IoT, Block-chain, Cloud App etc in any other DCs.

review_title: No directions included
job_title: Business Operations Professionals in South Houston, TX
pros: Work life balance is great. More than average flexibility to work from home whenever needed. Several teams only work in office twice a week.
cons: Management is still operating under the former company, good Ole boy system. If you're not white and or a male, you don't stand a chance of promotion, unless your manag(er/ement) is from the traditional IBM. Otherwise, all of HIS people will get the promotions and or pay increases.

review_title: It is the employee who does the work, not the stockholder.
pros: Have a reference with an IT leader on your resume.
cons: Bureaucracy, no respect for the employee, no straight talk, the stockholder has all the rights. All the raises seem to go with the younger recruits( less than 10 years) and the more senior people don't get much. IBM considers once an employee is hooked, there is no need to give more than needed. If you are a sales rep, understanding your sales plan and how much you will get paid is rocket science. IBM seems to manipulate the figures and raising the targets beyond reason  so you get paid what they want you to get paid. All this trickles down to "save as much as possible for the stockholder".

review_title: Consulting--great way to get experience and propel your career upwards.
pros: Everyone knows that you are working for a great company and you are looked upon for leadership based on your experience.  Using the knowledge and skills learned from my time at GBS, I was did well in an MBA program -- post-consulting career.  The personal perks include: airmiles and hotel points.
cons: As a consultant, you are more in tune with the client.  Its also difficult to get noticed by your managers for jobs well done.  If you are not careful completing all necessary administrative work, it may mean the difference between a great bonus or an alright one.  IBM does not allow you to collect American Express points.

review_title: Managed by the Human Resources department
pros: Breadth of opportunity across technical fields and geographic regions. Long term careers are possible for the very capable top performers.
cons:
Management are unable to make any decisions themselves. Salary decisions, appraisals and bonuses are all determined centrally in a very impersonal manner. Raise any complaint with management and they empathise and share your concern - but they are powerless to do anything about it. They just say "ask HR".

Promotions are apalling. The way the defined benefits salary scheme has been abandoned in 2009 has been disgusting. Despite not being personally affected I am outraged at how my colleagues have been treated.

review_title: Review of IBM Research
job_title: Research Staff Member in Hawthorne, NY
pros: IBM Research has a good reputation. As a result it can open doors. There is flexibility with respect to balancing work/life/family issues.
cons:
Although there are some projects in which RSM's do real research, overall IBM Research is not what it used to be. It's mostly a development lab rather than a research lab. This is why many promising young researchers who start at IBM become invisible in their fields several years after they start.

This problem is an old one. Management claims to want to address it, but there has been no progress in addressing the underlying culture and issues.

review_title: It probably completely depends on who your manager is and who you work with about whether you will have a good experienc
pros: Good amount of vacation time, and sick time policy was very flexible.  I got really sick and took a week off, no problem.  Lots of opportunities if you are able to stay there for a long time, and you are noticed.
cons: The managers interperet coroporate policies so differenttly, this makes some people very lucky and others very unlucky.  Compensation starts very low for entry level positions, and people treat each other like crap, that was my experience at least

review_title: OK Place - Salary and Bonus is Poor
pros:
- Flexible work arrangements, can work from home depending on project or job
- Name recongnition for resume
- Exposure into how a corporate entity operates
cons:
- Salary and Bonus is downright poor now.  IBM sr mgt believes staff are commodities.  They pay/reward below market.
- Since salary has become poor, a new medicore class of employees are being hired.  I gues these are the ones that couldn't get a higher offer somewhere else and it shows!
- Seasoned partners are leaving...lots of middle managers with no skills left.
- No more education reimbursement (MBA)

review_title: It's a job.
pros: Solid, well-recognized company with decent benefits. Definitely a large variety of positions and experiences available and most employees (US-based) work from home, so there is reasonable flexibility.
cons: Working from home makes it very tricky to have any kind of personal relationship with colleagues. IBM continues to layoff US-based workers without any notice, whatsoever...Morale is just terrible. Amazing to see people who have 30+ years in with the company still work 16+ hour days when they are fearful (daily) that they won't have a job tomorrow.

review_title: Very educational and interesting.
pros:
i) People, people people. My co-workers were mostly young and fun people. Very helpful and knowledgeable.
ii)Growth opportunity. IBM is a big company, you can switch between very different fields and still work for IBM - which is good for salary, further opportunities and meeting new people.
iii) The Research Triangle Park is a great place to live. The ocean is near, smokey mountains are near. A lot of nice clubs and a college life and city feel in the Raleigh area.
cons: i) The cubicles were grey and rather boring. Some more collaboration on specific problem solving would have been better. Do not get me wrong, there are a lot of meeting and talk between developers and managers, but it was a tiny bit more general.

review_title: It was great a decade ago, then jobs for Americans offshored or replaced with H-1B, L1 visa holders.
pros: If you don't care about job security, and can get a job, it may pay well.  However, IBM is shifting American workers into centers in low wage states and locations.  Existing employees can relocate themselves or simply lost the moved job.  Many job types were "debanded" (demoted).  Today it is all about cheap labor.
cons: Enormous job insecurity.  Many Americans lost jobs this year but some get to return as contractors (without benefits).  Number of American workers declined to 105,000 in 2009 and is believed now to be about 95,000.  This is a company with about 400,000 employees.  There is job growth, but not in the USA.

review_title: Excellent Company to work for....
pros: Excellent opportunities with different roles and responsibilities. The organization is so big that if you can choose to change your career path, even then IBM will have some thing for you. Clientele is one of the best, project pipelines are incomparable, onsite opportunities are plenty. Excellent working atmosphere. Once person joins the company, then there is no reason to leave the company except for personal reasons.
cons: Promotion process is long drawn process. From 2012, IBM has implemented a new Career Enhancement Tool everybody and promotion process is attached to this. Hoping to see a big change in Promotion process in coming months.

review_title: Not that bad to gain your first experience, but then it s better to get out
pros:
Looks good on a resume, you gain experience.
Working from home is possible by some manager, a lot depends on how your manager is.
Flexible working hours.
cons:
Bureaucracy and old systems. very process oriented unless you are from a developed country and local teams trust you to drive improvements.
Very big difference between managers, some are good, some extreme bad.
Low salaries, there are promises that you can go to a developed country, which are in the end never true, no matter how good you perform.
People are still treated as robots, with a high rotation as a consequence.

review_title: IBM is good, Kenexa is not
pros:
Being an IBMer.
Flexible hours.
Good benefits.
cons:
Unfortunately, at the Kenexa office, we are always running and going nowhere. Goals are not clear or change all the time.
First level managers are all juniors, they think that they are awesome though. The truth is that they have no clue of how to motivate or lead a team.
Many people are leaving the company not only for the stress but for the inefficiency to get the work done. Many people are just waiting to get their Green Cards and then they will leave.
The former CEO (Rudy Karsan) has a great speech, he even wrote a book about motivation and how important is to have the employees engaged. Unfortunately those are only words when it comes to Kenexa.

review_title: Lowest salary, jailed career, government ripoff
pros: People can just relax and not get noticed. For those who would like to work from home or come for coffee and chitchat this is the place to be.
cons:
Salary never grows. Never!
There is a botched Pbc process that gives the lowest number just to keep the headcount of people. Your work is never valued. 
Young people are hurriedly hired to meet the hiring targets (a govt funding ripoff really) and left to rot the rest of the population. 
No real work is done. Managers have their favorite characters who get the opportunities and get the end of year bonus. If you are a girl and want to get maternity leaves, yes get into this office and disappear. No one cares.

review_title: Benefits great but slow to give out training dollars
pros: People are talented and gifted; a lot of projects to roll onto to try different roles/responsibilities.  Work with a variety of people where you can learn from; people who've been with the company for 10+ years and those at least a year. Benefits are great - covers dental, medical, etc.
cons: Depending on who you have as your manager and who he/she reports to, you may or may not get training dollars - you need to talk to the right people (mainly those higher in the chain) to get the training you need to get ahead for your own career development

review_title: Good times.
pros: Great company to build a career in with the ability to move departments and job roles. Emphasis on education but you need to drive this yourself and seek out opportunities. Always felt proud to say I worked there.  You can make opportunities happen but again, you need to drive this yourself.  Good work/life balance as working from home an option in most non people mgmt. roles.
cons: This didn't inhibit me so much because I worked from graduate age but the feedback from newhires or people TUPEd in was that the organisation is complex, conservative and very process laden.  I wouldn't consider them competitive in terms of compensation but it is possible to negotiate a good starting salary if you have the skills they require.

review_title: A little bit slow
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Cairo, Cairo Governorate
pros:
- Overall nice company to work for.
- Could potentially have a good pay depending on the department and which band you're in.
- A lot of tools making it possible to interact and network with IBMers all over the world
- A CV booster
cons:
- Managers are absolute dinosaurs that like to micro manage.
- Hard to move up the ladder
- Little opportunity to move around to other more exciting roles and projects as a support engineer.
- A lot of beauracracy 
- The HQ building at Pyramids heights is absolutely hideous. It is the most gloomy and depressing place to work in. 
- Constantly cutting costs at IBM making it harder each year to receive training

review_title: WORK LIFE BALANCE
pros: Work life balance is amazing. I was allowed to work from home everyday when my son's nanny left us. Company is very diverse and is very supportive with LGBT community. I learned a lot specially the value of integrity (we are not required to log-in, just make sure you finish all your work). Was able to interact with many types of people. Superiority is not a big deal. Uplines and Global leads are just a chat away. Systems are established as well as processes so everything is already in line for you. You just have to be resourceful and proactive! Another thing, trainings are unlimited! I am very proud to say I was able to experience working at IBM.
cons: Organization structure always changes so during my time many employees were redundiated. Lucky me I was not included.

review_title: Good Entry Level, not Great for Long Term
job_title: SAP Consultant in Baton Rouge, LA
pros: Good position for early career opportunities.
cons: Not very well structured. Pay is low. Travel 100% even though it says 50%.  Different mentality between CIC centers and regular IBM. IBM treats the CIC as "Near Shore" workers with the concept of bringing offshore work to the US.  No defined career path for early professionals after a certain point. Managers make it hard to promote to band 7 while CBDers in the company automatically get promoted between the 1.5-2 year mark. Managers change every 6-10 months because they don't even live in Baton Rouge.

review_title: Ausum Company to work with.
pros:
I have been  working with for more than 5 years now.

Honestly speaking I have worked with other big IT MNCs which are competitor of IBM in the market. But I would say IBM is better than other companies in following aspect.
Not Great but excellent but  work life balance. 
Great infrastructure.
Process oriented company.
It's not like Indian IT MNCs where you will see your  managers are not professional and say whatever they feel like on the floor. Here managers are extremely professional. 
A lot of scope for self learning. IBM invests a lot on training of it's employees.
You will get a chance to learn and explore IBM products which are really cool. To give you few examples you can consider IBM BlueMix, IBm Cloud, IBM Watson. Maas 360 etc.
cons:
Less increment 
Environment less competitive.

review_title: Technical Support Associate
pros:
-a lot of leaves(22 planned and unlimited casual and sick leaves(need to show medical certs though))
-team outings(twice a year)
-work culture(especially collegues were mostly good)
-everyone were helpful and supportive in my process
-SMEs and my manager were chill and supportive
cons:
-10hrs shift
-one way cabs
-not much of incentives apart from shift allowances and that changes every time your shift changes
The only problem here is that there is so much of pressure and stress that it starts eating you out
Heavy call flow 
They have shrinkage almost all the time but don't appoint new hires and that is why workload increases so much
Job becomes monotonous and depresses you because you don't see yourself growing in anyway

review_title: Nice benefits, poor outlook if you're in the US
pros: Work/Life balance options are mostly pretty good.  If you're non-exempt and in a position that can get some overtime hours or carries a pager, the pay isn't horrible.
cons: Very poor senior management treatment of lower rung employees.  Nearly all technical workers are now non-exempt (hourly).  The big push is to globalize resources to areas with cheaper labor rates.  American technical employees are second class citizens and liabilities.  Due to these issues, morale in the company is dreadful and getting anything done is pretty much impossible.  The other large issue in Services is that Sales is under the gun to sell as much software as possible and we are always stuck trying to deliver the promises.

review_title: Good place to work if you can tolerate the usual problems of working for a large corporation.
pros: Lots of different things to work on.  Good ability to switch jobs if you don't like what you are doing.  Many jobs have the ability to telecommute if management approves.  More of a results oriented management style than one focused on face time.  Most first line managers are competent and seem to care about their people.
cons: Long hours and the usual corporate stuff:  bad senior management decisions, "cost cutting" that ends up costing the company more money, mass decisions that don't make individual sense, etc.  Issued laptops are often very unreliable and it takes forever to get a new one.

review_title: IBM India - Inside Out
pros: Work Life Balance, Opportunities and overall IBM Policies
cons: Poor Management, especially HR. Absolutely no plan in deployment of resources across projects and no surety given for career development even though plans are in place. Reporting structure too is not well directed.

review_title: IBM Canada is a great place to work
pros: The best reasons to work for IBM is the flexible working environment. There are flexible work hours, which means you can come in when you want, and leave when you want, as long as you get your work done. Also, most managers will let you work remotely from home from time to time. The floater holidays are especially great to have in the summer. It is a friendly community with many extracurricular clubs, sports, activities. IBM promotes higher education through IBM-paid courses and reimbursement for graduate school. There are many opportunities to grow or change careers within IBM.
cons:
- No overtime pay
- Strict performance evaluations
- Very competitive environment (can be good and bad)

review_title: Great education & training, but little recognition, thanks or pay.
pros: Great education, some of IBM's training courses are world class.
cons:
Little recognition, low pay, no promotion.

IBM's newer management had none of the metoring or people development culture of the old IBM, and introduced a ruthless approach to exploiting their people. The trouble was that they did this with the old IBM system, where excellent education and a lot of mentoring had compensated (a bit) for the low pay and slow promotion in a large organisation.

review_title: Looking IN I wondered what the big deal was, now that I see "Management" talk, its really no secret.
pros:
1) Global
2) You could work a lifetime and not know all of IBM
3) IBM Name Hype
4) Diverse experience opportunities
cons:
1) Global means you 
2) You can work 1 year and know all the management "BS".
3) Underpaid
4) Benefits suck this includes cafeteria facility too
5) Need to subscribe to Blue Culture
6) Its like running a 4 x 4 relay, you do your bit and hand it over to your manager who passes it on and so on......

review_title: Fantastic place to work!  People are key to business success.
job_title: Senior Software Engineer in Hawthorne, NY
pros: As a research assistant, I was frequently given free reign to try new technologies and see how they might be applied to real world application.  It can be exciting to take something new from the lab and actually oversee implementation as a pilot in a customer setting and be able to take the feedback directly back to the lab in a continuous improvement cycle.
cons: It was a temporary assignment and had to come to an end.

review_title: Great job, but no advancement opportunities or work-life balance
job_title: Anonymous Employee in California City, CA
pros: Colleagues are awesome, work content is challenging and interesting, ability to work at home, great interaction with clients, lots of potential to move around business units at the company
cons: 20 hour work days and weekends are the norm for managers due to global team structure, expectations are total work overload, lack of work life balance, positions are not back-filled as promised, annual raises are pathetic or non-existent, requirements for advancement are ambiguous or poorly communicated, bottom line thinking prevails such that only sales related efforts are rewarded monetarily

review_title: Smart executives, phenomenal technology but ancient processes
job_title: Research Staff Member in Ithaca, NY
pros: Collaborative atmosphere, smart people, investment in basic science and research, proactive opportunity creation and advancement for women, phenomenal technologies.  highest integrity and ethics. lots of opportunities to move within the company. Watson strategy will propel the company to next level. Top executives (VP level and above) are smart and excellent at what they do.
cons: processes designed for the last decade prevent company from moving fast enough to compete with new threats. Not-invented-here syndrome. Poor middle management.

review_title: An implosion case study
job_title: Senior Technical Staff Member in Austin, TX
pros:
Flexibility to work from home
Opportunity to work on extremely advanced systems technologies, but see cons section.
Good 401K match % but only applicable if employed on Dec 15th
cons: Revenue is in a tailspin and profits are up at the expense of employee compensation.  Quarterly layoffs are the norm, and specifically target the 40+ population in the US.  If you're very good, you have Job security but don't expect bonuses or career growth, that's reserved for the low cost geographies.  If you're not good, you'll be laid off swiftly, unless you're in a low cost geography.  In short, all stick, no carrot.  In short, the culture the made IBM great no longer exists.

review_title: Change Needed @ IBM
job_title: Anonymous Employee in East Lansing, MI
pros: The only pros i have seen the company has got flexible work culture.
cons:
IBM is such a Huge Company but implementing a change or getting an approval takes for ever. If you need a single thing to get signed off Non of the Management folks would take responsibility to make it happen. Every one feels it's not their job to get it done. 
Additionally  Management tries to preach a particular Culture and they never follow. When it comes to Promotion they recommend doing Career Framework and all  Crap and Finally they provide peanuts for their employee who works 18 hours a day. 
In my center please have experienced Managers. Do not bring in in experienced rookies as Managers for Senior Employees.

review_title: Bad managment that relies on smoke and mirrors
job_title: Senior Hardware Design Engineer in Poughkeepsie, NY
pros: Flexible work schedule but expect to work much more than 40 hours a week. If a new hire they will treat you better for awhile until the favorites are chosen and the next batch come in.
cons: Below average pay for above average work load. No pay raises for several years in a row. Raise have been below CPI since Gerstner left. Lower level management is very political and petty. Upper level management completely clueless. They think being a "me too" company will lead to profits.

review_title: A Sinking Ship (Sr. Architect)
pros:
Lets face it - IBM (like Yahoo) is not doing well. 

Its share price has halved in the last 2 years - and there are few takers for its Bluemix cloud service.

The consequence is phased "resource action" - i.e. redundancies each month.

I've seen many of my colleagues being made redundant in the last few years.

There is no budget for training - and  there is enormous pressure on remaining billable by joining projects that are entirely out of whack with one's skill set.

Employees spend more time looking for jobs than trying to do a better job.

Strangely, the hiring for permanent roles is ongoing - although there is not enough work. 

Many new hires are rendered redundant even before completing their initial 6 month probation.

Joining IBM in the UK? - think again.
cons:
Wave upon wave of redundancies affects employee morale.
Poor work-life balance.
Excessive travel.
No training budget.
Limited options for career growth.

review_title: Will Big Blue Come Back?
job_title: Senior Program Manager in Austin, TX
pros: Great opportunity for someone getting started right out of school.  The salaries are better than average and the Learning and Development is unsurpassed.
cons: Most everyone knows IBM unless you are under 25 years of age.  The company is suffering from brand recognition, but trying to make a comeback.  The recent reduction in employees should help the bottom line, but what does it do for the reputation?  The future of this once glorious technology leader is in jeopardy.  Let's all hope it can come back and soon.

review_title: Work Life balance is plus, repeatative work is minus
pros:
1) IBM work life balance depends on the project you are into. For me it provided a superb Work life balance, 
2) gave chance to learn and upgrade skills, partner with Oracle for GBS practise, So you can attend various oracle training free, but have to manage along with project work.
3) Very much process oriented, we don't have last minute project blunders, no production deployment pressure ever. 
4) 
All the above points mostly depends on the project you get in.
cons:
1) If you are assigned to one project, it is difficult to get release from that project.
2) very slow in giving hike's and promotion.
3) Have to be nice with your managers to get onsite opportunity
4) Sometimes monotonous work.

review_title: IBM has lots of opportunities
job_title: Senior Technical Program Manager in Paramus, NJ
pros:
* Great professional people to work with
* Many tools and resources available
* Big projects with wonderful contributions to society
* Lots of volunteer opportunities
* Depending on management, might be supported to grow career
* Ability to submit patent ideas
* Lots of inside educational opportunities
cons:
* Cost cutting has affected travel and education to cut them to a minimum
* Confusion over moving folks to remote work at home and now stressing co-location
* Employees pushed to be working all the time and late hours, so not a lot of time or desire for people to socialize or for education opportunities
* Many are living in a state of wondering when they may be hit by a layoff
* Layoffs seem to be random

review_title: Poor Leadership Not Customer Oriented
job_title: Delivery Project Executive in Washington, DC
pros: Name Brand; Entry level Resources
cons: Sr leaders get bonuses- mid level to entry level bonus minimal.  Yearly bonus last year for high performer was $321.  As a manager of high performing team I was allotted $218 to split between two resources.  Company does across the board furloughs for subKs at a moment's notice.  The only exception if an SLA will be missed.  If IBM misses a committed deliverable without penalty- so be it- they would rather do furloughs so they can meet their numbers.  Resources have not received raised in over 5 years.  Promises to next band level put on freeze and never revisited.

review_title: Good and Bad, set up boundries
job_title: B2B Customer Integration Lead in Austin, TX
pros: Great exposure to the corporate tech industry and working with high level clients. Opportunities to learn and get certifications
cons: Poor management, if you want or need anything out of this job you will have to go for it yourself. There isn’t much support for growth. If you need a training or want a raise you have to fight for it. If you don’t set up boundaries your team will keep piling work on you until you break.

review_title: Great place to work... but stress level is very high and the pay increases are low.
pros: Flexible work schedule, working from home, information sharing and skill building.  People are very friendly and management is highly trained.  There are many opportunities to move around in the company, and it is encouraged.
cons: Heavy workload, above average employees get very little pay increases from year to year.  This could be a sign of the times, but overall, I'm not satisfied with my yearly pay increases.

review_title: A horrendous place for white males over 40 to work.
job_title: Middle Manager in Hopewell Junction, NY
pros: It is a good place for young people to start a career and get good training as long as there is a plan to leave the business within 5 or 6 years.   Employees in the sales and marketing professions can gain significant good contacts to move into other businesses as they grow their skills.
cons: IBM discriminates against white males, and in particular, those over 40 years old.   It is clearly a supporter of reverse discrimination.   All diversity groups are protected and nurtured except white males over 40.  It's a disgrace and causes many roles to be filled with people of lesser skills in order to minimize the role of white males in the workplace.

review_title: Good company to work for
pros: Very flexible with work at home options.  Opportunities to work with the best in the industry.    Excellent on line/virtual classroom professional courses available for all employees.  I've had excellent growth experiences working on smaller start up projects which have provided invaluable experience.
cons: Too much red tape hinders decision making.    Too many middle managers who do not understand software development or developers.     It is very difficult for non-technical employees to get good raises or promotions.   There is no identifiable corporate culture in the software group and people are given assignments rather than  put into growth or career positions for the larger projects.   Senior management determines schedules and scope and does not understand appropriate project management methodology which leads to lots of weekend work to accommodate already compressed schedules.

review_title: United We Stand Divided We Fall
pros:
Home office. Varied projects.  Pizza gift card one Christmas.  Boss says "go home early" at end of day before holiday.  Boss buys drinks and dinner for team 2 to 4 times a year.  Flexible hours. Usually no one looking over your shoulder.
Once a month team meetings.
cons: Spread out across the globe.   Each person for themselves.  Technically incompetant leaders.   Can't understand heavy accent fast talking Indians.  Lacking networked architecture before software solutions are expected.  Holiday party consisted of a meeting on the phone.  No preliminary meetings to prepare and unite as a team for in house customer service visits.

review_title: Pays well, but works you to death.
pros: The pay is good, and you get to work with people around the world as well as a bunch of hillbillies in North Carolina.  IBM is customer focused.
cons: The review system does NOT promote teamwork.  It is cut-throat.  Also, IBM never does anything new or creative.  You use old tools to work on last years technology.  IBM buys new companies, it doesn't invent or create anything.  Its heyday is long behind us.  This is sad.   Also, the stress level is unbelievable.  I've seen people crying at their desks far too many times.

review_title: Enh, it's a living.
pros:
-Great benefits when compared to other companies. 
-Big company = lots of opportunities
-The risk of failure vs. the risk of reward in inside sales is pretty good
cons:
-It's a big machine, you might inadvertently get chewed up by it.
-Moving around within the company is a crap-shoot, you might end up in a spot that's terrible, but you have little way of knowing ahead of time.-\
-Lots of people slacking off, hiding within the protective confines of the big machine.
-The right hand doesn't know what the left is doing

review_title: Good on your resume but move on
pros:
Large company to make decent contacts
Great first line managers in general
cons:
Departments were very silo like, you would hear 'its not my job' plenty
Pay not great and unbalanced / male dominated
Work life balance depended on which department you were in, over all terrible work life balance
Many times client facing roles were understaffed
Executive level compensation excessive
Executives had no common ground with front line staff or their leaders
High rates of outsourcing to companies such as India
In some departments the inter office politics was terrible
In one department a thank you came in the form of eating pizza at your desk while taking calls

review_title: IBM is THE technology bluechip

2)  There are more career development resources available to you than you'd likely find at any other private corporation.

review_title: Good learning and work/life balance enterprise which overall keeps me satisfied
job_title: Software Engineer in São Paulo, São Paulo

The main pro is probably the work/life balance politics of the enterprise, which really helps me by allowing home office a couple times a week, since I live a little too far away from my office.
The benefits which the enterprise gives are also great, and so are the learning opportunities within it.
cons: The major cons probably are the salary, which isn't exactly the best ones on the market.. but are still in the average, and also the fact that it is a huge enterprise, which causes advances within its hierarchy to be slow.

review_title: Good work life balance, work from home, ideal for women employees.
pros:
1) Work life balance. Most projects have no pressure at all and are long term cool projects.
2) Chances of onsite if you stay for long period.
3) Flexible work timings. No 9 hours mandatory stay.

review_title: Good company in many ways but they do not value employees
job_title: Senior Software Engineer in Atlanta, GA
pros:
Let you work remote
trust you to get your work done, no micromanaging
great coworkers
interesting work
cons:
ridiculous policies for performance reviews(pbcs). Perfectly good people get low reviews and great people get passed over for top ratings because they follow an algorithm instead of honestly rating work
Top execs do not value their employees
very little training/investment in employees
changed the 401K match to yearly matching so they can freely lay off people and save $$
Do not allow much transfer between departments

review_title: Bad place to works; treats employees like pawns
pros: Company has a great history. The opportunities are good if you have a responsive Band 10 or above to employees needs and concerns. Benefits are fair to on par with industry.
cons: Where do I begin?  No one in this company can communicate for beans. Leadership calls employees resources and gives us all serial numbers...most organizations call their people, well, people or talent. This trickles down to everything...poor treatment of employees, ever shrinking benefits, terrible pay and no increases, company expects the world out of its employees but gives us NOTHING in returns. IBM has sold out to EPS and absurd promises to the street

review_title: Great place, cool projects, "at the heart of IT"
pros:
Great place to work at the core of IT, not just the 13957th user interface on top of it.
Many very capable people (not all, but most).
Management is very much understanding the personal needs of employees, e.g. family situation, and is really concerned about helping (which is more than "listening").
cons:
Pay is ok, but could be better.
Buildings are at times not the newest.
Nowadays the company tries to save money quite a bit too much.
Too much driven by quarter results.
Old employees have MUCH better financial benefits than the young generations.

review_title: Great place to work until retirement
pros: Very smart people, many diverse and interesting projects, stability, great flexibility in working hours and work-life balance, work is quite diverse and includes aspects such as: research, development, business development & marketing, customer relations, patents.
cons:
- Salaries are reasonable, but raises are scarce and bonuses almost non-existent.
- Too much proprietary technologies, which are everything but modern, not enough use of modern open-source technologies.
- Too little communication between different groups, and the one that does exist comes bottom-up (from employees themselves).
- Too much time spent "between projects" and on things that eventually get trashed
- Too much bureaucracy (I guess that's reality in such a big company)

review_title: Humiliatingly low salary.

2. You will get monthly salary in time.

7.  Even the essential facilities like printer are not maintained for the past one year ( G1, Manyata, Bangalore ).

review_title: Falling smarter

Loyal peers in face of a company that has not reciprocated

Executives are tone deaf
Limited staff to support clients
Morale horrible
Using outmoded stacked ranking

review_title: Try working for IBM if given a chance
job_title: Senior Product Manager in San Jose, CA
pros: Excellent thought leadership & vision in the market, Good work life balance, good flexibility like working from home (teams are distributed all across the country), Good benefits, industry average salary. If you're getting a job at IBM, I highly suggest you work here for one year at least and figure out if this culture is a good fit for you or not. You will learn a lot here.
cons: As usual with big companies, too many processes, takes too many approvals to get things done. You have to work hard to stand out, But that is true for any other company. Don't expect big bonuses or stock options.

review_title: Good Place to Work
pros: Great entry level training. Solid reputation in the technology industry.  Over 100 year old company so it has some stability based on longevity.  You have the opportunity to work with some smart, innovative people.  Compensation is ok and when you add benefits, they are competitive with the market.  They do not pay at the top or bottom.
cons: Has lost some of it's focus on the people and not as invested in training management on strong people skills as well as good functional skills.  If you get a manager with both functional and people skills, you will enjoy your job.  If not, they seem slow to move poor managers out which affects the whole team.

review_title: Completely Distracting Experience.
job_title: Sales Manager in East Orange, NJ
pros: Great, Good  and very smart people especially at the field and 1st level management.. Excellent Benefits( Although Changing).
cons:
Poor - work life balance. Inefficient management regimen, despite all their tools, Salesforce, Notes, still rely on MS Xcel spreadsheets to mange their business. " Chinese Fire-drill" cadence calls. Trickle down communication is very ineffective. Many 3rd and 2nd levels confused about roll and create "panicked" environment for rest of organization. Very Stressful.
Because of size of organization, Internal IBM'ers become gatekeepers making contact with customers and prospects the most difficult experience ever.Difficult to run a team effectively with current management structure

review_title: Not Much Fun
pros: Good pay (as a band 10). Work from home. Largely get to define my own priorities and tasks in support of the overall mission. My manager isn't focused on time in the office as much as on accomplishing objectives, so work schedule varies and is flexible.
cons: Most of my projects (staff role in global for GTS) seem to go nowhere and don't make a difference to anything important, which isn't what I was hoping to do with my career. It's painful to get things done with so many competing interests and priorities in the company. Problems with employee technology and tools (e.g. cleaning up mail due to ridiculously low email quota, instant messaging and intranet sites not working, etc.) have to be dealt with on personal time (since I'm measured on objectives accomplished, not time in the office).

review_title: A once great company being destroyed by terrible leadership
pros: When I started at IBM it was an amazing place to work. Great group of extremely dedicated talented and driven people. Superb, world-class education available to all employees, great culture, IBM had the world by the tail. That all changed when Sam Palmissano took over as CEO in 2001.
cons: Sam destroyed the company via lack of vision, extremely poor leadership, and excessive cost cutting. IBM internally is now a terrible place to work, with constant layoffs and a culture of fear and intimidation. They are so tied up in their own bureaucracy that they can't get anything done quickly. Many of the superb employees have left and those that are left are afraid to do anything for fear of losing their jobs.

review_title: Decent but not as good as it used to be
pros:
Great people, above average compensation, excellent work flexibility(most times).
Good benefits(above average) and nice working environment. I would definitely recommend this role to individuals interested in working in a Finance environment. Also the COE uses many tools, and guidance and support is available to those who show initiative.
cons: Too many processes, high turnover(mostly due to the fact that employees get bored of their roles and move to better paying opportunities). Role and responsibilities seem too specific and mundane for my liking. I'm not so sure if the experience gained can be applied to other companies as some of the roles handle finance functions too specific.

review_title: Big Blue is a great place to work!
job_title: Regional Manager in Costa Mesa, CA
pros: IBM really has what they are doing "down pat".  For a big company I was always impressed by how smoothly their internal systems worked and that they really tried to help employees when they needed it.
cons: In order to advance in the company managers have to work in all different parts of the business so they can understand them.  This means you will get short-term managers popping in on a regular basis who don't understand the part of the business YOU are in so they can learn.  Some of these are good, some not so good.

review_title: Poor management and unreasonable expectations

review_title: Get the name (if you need it ) and head out
