- When your executives are not closing deals, you get bad ratings which means no salary increases and no bonus ... even though you could be working around the clock 
- When you executives are closing deals, you barely get any meaningful bonus because you are delivery guy (or what they started calling it past couple of weeks client service professional)

review_title: Lots of opportunity but you'll really have to work for it.
pros: Great people, well known brand, deep pockets, complex projects and good learning experience. Global reach means lots of opportunity if you're willing to travel. Reinventing itself in some really leading edge technologies such as AI, cognitive computing, cloud, deep analytics. Few constraints on work location or work style. Very wide array of jobs, can reinvent yourself and have many careers within the same company. Competitive salaries.
cons: Complex and difficult to navigate Recently seen as "old tech", not a glamour brand Wall Street hates IBM and IBM tries to manage to Wall Streets needs over its customers and employees Leads to regular "Resource Actions" and divestitures which can be unsettling. People disappear overnight! Flexible working means constant working. Very easy to be sucked into an unhealthy dork life balance.

review_title: Could be great, but management failings are holding the security teams back.
job_title: Security Sales Specialist in London, England
pros:
They have the worlds best portfolio of security solutions and their plan of integration is winning deals.
Market leading products and continuous acquisitions and R&D make IBM the number one place to be to sell security.
cons:
Half the systems and processes should have been left in the 90's where they belong.
There is a lot of nepotism in the management teams, where long term IBM staff with little or no outside experience reign.

review_title: Could be great, but management failings are holding the security teams back.
job_title: Security Sales Specialist in London, England
pros:
They have the worlds best portfolio of security solutions and their plan of integration is winning deals.
Market leading products and continuous acquisitions and R&D make IBM the number one place to be to sell security.
cons:
Half the systems and processes should have been left in the 90's where they belong.
There is a lot of nepotism in the management teams, where long term IBM staff with little or no outside experience reign.

review_title: Fun Challenging Opportunities but Hampered with Big Politics
job_title: Senior Product Manager in Cambridge, MA
pros: IBM is undergoing a radical transformation to remain relevant in the new cloud and big data economy. This offers a lot of opportunities to shape the future and evolution of the company. The job of product manager is challenging and allows for a lot of creativity.
cons: Big company, big politics. The current climate is difficult with constant efforts to reduce cost while at the same time having the challenge to re-invent the way it brings products to the market. I've seen for quite a while a parade of executives that are only interested in promoting themselves rather than delivering value for the company.

review_title: It Pays The Bills
pros: Many opportunities within the firm, a variety of projects.  A "job supermarket" as one manager described it.  Friendly and down to earth colleagues for the most part.
cons: The company is just too big and it's easy to get lost in the crowd.  Be prepared to work really hard, to be told that you are doing a fantastic job by the people you work with, until it comes to your annual review at which point you are told what a "satisfactory" job you are doing.  But you should be really proud of that!

review_title: Mediocre
pros:
- Depending on team, can be low stress with good work life balance. Flex time and work from home are nice benefits.
- Generally pretty good culture. People try to help each other and there isn't much backstabbing.
cons:
- Depending on area, things are in flux and management will constantly being changing priorities.
- Quality of engineers is questionable in general. No technical questions are asked during interviews, so you can get hired without really knowing how to code.
- Flat or pathetic increases in salary.
- Not much room for advancement since everyone has 20 and 30 years of seniority.

review_title: A cognitive company for future and Best place to work
pros:
IBM has changed a lot from earlier days. It is currently transforming within itself to meet the future technologies like cloud, cognitive and analytics etc, 
Huge number opportunities within IBM to choose your career.   Give back is one of the loving program I like where it you give back to your company by mentoring , inventing etc. Review mechanism is  also changed very recently which would help employees to take on short term goals and meet your manager every quarter to check your progress.
cons: Nothing see as of now due to major transformation in progress

review_title: Creating opportunities
pros: If you have your eye on a role or are passionate about something, you are the only thing standing between success or failure.  People who create their own opportunities will thrive here.  If you are not ready for that entrepreneurial atmosphere, this may not be your best option.
cons: There are many layers of redundant process supported by a back office function that needs its own transformation, but you can be a part of that change if you bring solutions to the problem into the process.

review_title: Good enterprise to work in, but too much politics.
job_title: Analytics Consultant in Cairo, Cairo Governorate
pros:
- Large scale and challenging projects. 
- Time and location flexibility. 
- Global exposure (clients from different markets, working with global IBM teams, world class trainers).
cons:
- Silly policies, not always smart, and more into bureaucratic. 
- Slow processing of business and career progress. 
- Too much politics in management teams, so that matters get handled way too personal. 
- Slow in being up to date with latest progressive trends in the world (my unit and management in IBM started to focus on Analytics and Data Science in 2015 only).
- Below average financial packages, compared with other large IT companies in Egypt's market.

review_title: GBS Partner
pros:
1) IBM is a (the?) top, global brand in the IT products and services space
2) IBM Watson has been a huge differentiator in the past 2-3 years
3) IBMers are highly competent individuals who are full of integrity
cons: Financial performance over the last five years has not met Wall Street's expectations. Resource actions have been necessary to align headcount with declining revenues. Employee morale has declined accordingly

review_title: Not cool as it looks
pros:
- a good network of professionals
- if you are at the beginning of your career, it´s a decent place where to start, especially if they offer you to go to the bootcamp
- company has a good reputation and high visibility worldwide
cons:
- lack of senior people and clear leadership: too many young and unexperienced people covering a role that should be given to more talented and experienced designers
- the design dept plays the role of the "cool & young guy", while the rest of the company is just an old stinky and slow dinosaur
- lack of management: also in this case, people with no experience cover roles that are above their competences
- everything is too slow and there is a total lack of transparency
- low salaries & small opportunities for progressing in your career

review_title: Spacemakers Project for Americas at 14th Ave Markham
pros: Our team used the Design Thinking methodology -we collaborated in an agile environment to develop a unique design for our current space.  Everyone expressed an opinion and shared ideas - we worked extremely well and had fun while doing so.  It was nice to see our hard earned results come to fruition - made us feel proud to be a part of IBM!
cons: Timeframes are tight so we needed to work around our current schedules to get this project completed on time.  Thankfully we were granted a 2 week extension to complete implementation.

review_title: Knowing your MO will help you decide joining IBM
job_title: Senior Business Control Specialist in New Delhi
pros:
a) Knowledge, Knowledge, Knowledge
b) Work-Life Balance
c) Maximum types of roles ( Almost everything you can think of .. From Developer to Chef , From Doctor to Plumber.. IBM would have a role for you)
d) Unlimited Horizontal growth ( don't like your role , find another one within IBM, change roles and restart)
cons:
a) Money, It is not the best paymaster ( not the worst either)
b) Money ( Peanuts in increments)
c) Money ( there is virtually no monetary incentive)
d) Money (It has probably the worst system of claims so you prefer not to claim)

review_title: Service Delivery Specialist
pros:
1. Work-life balance is the biggest advantage in IBM
2. Work from home is a big plus
3. Brand value matters
cons:
1. Internal movement process is too complex. Can't move to another domain or different business unit even if you have the skill
2. Management is stringent about job role and project
3. Notice period is 90 days long.
4. Irregular and seldom salary hike
5. Need to give assessment very often to justify employees' position in organization. Can be fired also if one fails to crack assessment for 3 times

review_title: Great for Millenials
pros: Some flexibility around work hours. Expected to work beyond what you're compensated for, though work/life balance is good - better than many companies. They're also trying with snacks, catered lunches, happy hours, etc - but that doesn't really appeal to the masses who are just trying to get the job done and not engage in a million activities that detract from work.
cons: Management turnover is atrocious. Don't expect anyone to advocate for you, you're just a cog in the corporate machine. Anyone director level & up will likely jump (sinking?) ship within the next fiscal year, unless there's a huge turnaround.

review_title: Software Developer
pros:
* Really smart people and great learning opportunities
* Easy to work remotely
* Office in Southbank is in a cool location
* Stable
* Using more up to date 
* Tolerant and inclusive environment
cons:
* Underpaid compared to the market
* Corporate hierarchical management structure makes the company slower and less attractive to fresh talent
* Still feels like old style corporate (although a lot of work is being done to refresh)
* Some teams are less fortunate than others (have access to better perks, more autonomy, etc.)

review_title: Interesting experience that is not regretted but you have to move on to advance.
pros: You get to work on some leading edge products. The people there are generally pleasant to work with. Terrific work life balance, perhaps too much though since things take forever to happen.
cons: Limited potential for for personal enrichment if you're a top performer; it's like working in the post office. Projects take forever to complete due to bureaucracy, but arguably also due to quality focus. Compensation left a lot to be desired, with meager increases for colleagues that deserved more (not much trickles to the bottom). Way too over matrixed; decisions take eons by the time you level set with all business units.

review_title: Could be worse but could stand a lot of improvement.
job_title: Technical Sales Manager in New York, NY
pros: Access to a variety of different jobs, locations, industries, and intellect. Flexible working environment - work from home or mobile office or customer site. Great benefits. Competitive pay. Lots of great support from the development labs when you need it. People are always willing to get engaged to help in a customer situation.
cons: Internal competition for clients.  Compensation plans drive myopic behaviors. Mid and Sr level mgt lacks vision and leadership skills. Good sellers get promoted to executive ranks, but they only know how to be sellers so they drive a seller mentality when they should be leaders.  There are very few leaders at IBM.

review_title: IBM needs to implore honesty and candor among its values
job_title: Advisory IT Specialist in Essex Junction, VT
pros: Flexible Work for personal life issues.  First line management was often supportive, though had no power in decision making for your career goals
cons: IBM provides lower pay versus comparable positions around the country in other peer companies.  On top of the lower pay, there is also an instablity of of employment due to what they deem a competitive market forcing them to take resource actions.  Though this extreme reaction does not seem to be on par with other organizations as frequent as IBM.  There is also a large barrier between upper management and "everyone else", which provides a huge gap of uncertainty among employees as to how they "benefit" the company as a whole.

review_title: Good work/life balance, not always the most exciting work
pros: Great work life balance (I have 2 young children at home, and I have all the flexibility I need to deal with the typical toddler/infant issues), varied experiences, great management team, IBM legacy of innovation, the pay is pretty solid, most of the people are great to work with, great reach back to some of the best technical minds in the industry
cons: Consulting offerings are somewhat ill-defined, paths to advancement also not well defined. I work in the Intelligence Community and our presence here is limited. We cannot compete with companies like Booz Allen for the bigger projects. We often have to work as subs to other consulting firms.

review_title: Great place to get a years experience, but don't plan to stay
job_title: Senior IT Specialist in Bethesda, MD
pros: If you're young and need a year or two of experience, this is a great place. They'll hire almost anyone, chew you up, burn you out, and lay you off. IBM notoriously pays lower than others, so you'll have an opportunity to boost your salary as soon as you leave. The benefits used to offset the low salary, but they have been whittled down to average, at best.
cons: No raises, No education, Too much travel, high utilization targets. For example, while IBM is making record profits, a blanket decision was made not to give I/T Specialists raises. Doesn't matter what you did, no raise, no chance. 110% utilization makes you average, (rated a 2) which means no raise, no bonus) Plan to work 50 hours minimum to keep your job, 80 hours to excel, and that is only if the contract allows for it. (FYI, travel time doesn't count).

review_title: IBM nice right place to start, wrong place to finish
job_title: Project Manager in Research Triangle Park, NC
pros: You get some valuable experience in the area you work.  You are a valued commodity for the first year or so. The IBM name is still held in high regard in the business world.  So it is a good stepping stone.
cons: Career advancement is very limited. There are too many people not moving which stagnates growth. There is no true work and life balance on most IBM accounts.  As a consultant you are asked to travel a lot.  Overtime is not an option, it is a requirement.

review_title: Great place to work, especially in bad economic times
job_title: Senior Sales Representative in New York, NY
pros: Best of breed products and services, pride of association both with the company, pride of association with peers, very flexible working options, from both time and location perspectives, virtually unlimited career opportunities, opportunities for international assignments, strong company culture, very good benefits compared to similar companies, can get in the door at virtually any sales prospect.
cons: Below average pay compared to competition, far too many layers of management, too many people paid on the same deal, old fashioned command and control style of management, complex sales plans that are virtually impossible to understand, success punished with massive quota increases.  But all of this is probably the same as at most other similar companies.

review_title: More layoffs imminent
job_title: Hardware Engineer in Research Triangle Park, NC
pros: Learning new technologies that are in development or are ready to hit the market.
cons: If you want to get overworked, unpaid and under appreciated, this is the place you want to be.  I have never seen management try to cut corners to save a buck than I have in the Systems and Technology Group.  And not to mention the sheer incompetence of team leads not making an effort in order to distribute accurate and correct test plans in order to complete necessary projects on time.  Once the project does reach it's completion date, there is no appreciation expressed for the hard work or overtime spent in order to meet project deadlines by management.  It's off to the races to try and complete the next disaster of a project that you're assigned.

review_title: A decently good stable company.
job_title: Technical Specialist in Foster City, CA
pros: Good place to work if you have want something stable (when you have a family and what not). People are very jovial to talk to. It is easy to assimilate to the IBM environment. IBM provides many opportunities to join and get to know the community.
cons: Entry level pay isn't so good. IBM isn't a company for college grads. When I worked as a Technical Specialist, I didn't feel they paid me well enough for my services to the development of web applications. I mean, again, if you need a stable job where you can work for 30 years, IBM is a good place to work. But other than that, there is no progress for a young career as myself.

review_title: IBM is a stable place to work, but innovation only happens in research labs and the groups your hear about on TV.
pros: Great benefits! Access to leaders all over the globe is an incredible networking opportunity. Very proud to tell people I work at IBM. At the highest levels of the organization the IT industry thought leadership is unparalleled.
cons: Working for a smaller group or cost center within Big Blue can be especially challenging. My group is like a small/medium business that is expected to perform on par with Fortune 500 companies but lacks the resources to do so both in dollars and people. Cost cutting is paramount.

review_title: Used to be good. Now ... questionable
pros:
Work in multi-cultural env. to broad the sights
The governance (Matrix)
Work with talents
cons:
Work/Life distortion (12+ hours per day)
Budget shrinks year over year, being stingy to all employees, but asking technical people to create more and more innovative deliverables
Then it means it is generous to shareholders (but not to employees, only 5% discounts of subscribing stock option)
Punish young and new hires (taking longer and longer for promotion, less and less raise while being promoted.)
The ROI is low when working on a hot product/project (no more bonus, no clever rating rules)
Boring office layout (while the office layout is somewhere the creative works root)

review_title: Great learning environment
pros: The learning opportunities are endless
cons: Sometimes difficult to find information when project is done at more than one site

review_title: Nothing like the Good Old Watson time
pros: IBM is great about Work Life balance, Flexibility to work remotely, benefits are not bad.  For a big comporation like IBM, it's actually less cutting throat, and many co-workers are actually very friendly to each other.
cons: No more Job security, many jobs are offshored and it happens quite frequently!  Managements are coached by executives to be dishonest to employees.  No more encouragement for good performance, no more promotion or raise.

review_title: Great place to begin your career
job_title: Software Developer Coop in Toronto, ON
pros:
There was a great work life balance for interns. They even have a gym at the software lab!
I was assigned fun new projects and learned a lot of interesting technical and management skills. My mentor and project lead listened to all of my suggestions and criticisms with regards to design and provided insightful feedback and suggestions as well! 
I came out of my internship learning a lot.
cons:
Some tasks and assignments were a bit tedious.
Too much bureaucracy. I did not like waiting around to be assigned new projects or for the project maintainer to accept our code changes. 
The cafeteria had a lot of food, but I didn't enjoy their offerings very much.
The compensation isn't very competitive compared to other tech companies such as Amazon, Google, or Microsoft.

review_title: always learning
pros: great people to learn from,nice work life balance,very vast business so there are immense opportunities to learn be it functional learning or business. For every skill or domain you want to start learning , there will be many good  SMEs to learn from.Many career orientented presentations to benefit from and IBM has good  focus for its resources to undergo certain trainings and certifications for betterment of both employess and company.
cons: at times career path is not clear in absence of proper networking to get connect to right people as its a very vast organization.Pattern of promotion is more or less decided upon the kind of networking you have with in company.at times it is difficult to change your carrer aspiration and path because of lack of proper guidance and support.

review_title: Modern, competent, fair, bureaucratic
job_title: Research Staff Member in Yorktown, NY
pros: If you work here, you have a unique opportunity to work on top tier software and hardware products.  A large company like IBM can apply its weight to go in directions that other companies cannot.  It is certainly a unique company and an interesting experience.
cons: Working conditions are somewhat grey and dull.  The email client everyone has to use (Lotus Notes) is an appalling piece of software that quite frankly is beyond contempt.  Other internal tools (the intranet, expense claims, etc) are slightly better but still way below expectations.  The bureaucracy generally is a pain.  You must follow the bureaucracy and be a good cog in the machine but if it fails you then that is your problem, not IBMs.  Very frustrating.

review_title: Ideal Place For The First Job
pros: IBM is a large corporation & its name is common knowledge among almost everyone. They dont their own banks but they practically every other type of business for the world. This gives the employee the opportunity to venture into any territory thus helping people shape their careers effectively. The environment is culturally very strong & facilitates an open door policy at all levels.
cons: Being a large corp it has set a lot of boundaries & policies for day to day operation which at times do more harm then help. The salaries & the salary structures are not as per industry benchmarks & need revision. It is slowly becoming an HR strong organization rather than a delivery strong organization.

review_title: Bye Bye Blue
pros: Loved working  from home.  Managers were excellent in terms of dealing with direct reports.  Good work-life balance.
cons: No corporate loyalty towards employees any more.  Only focus of HQ is to improve EPS, any way at any cost.  In the long-run, this will kill an American icon.

review_title: The elefant is running in the morass deeper - how to get out is quite unclear ?
pros: - international company, many "good" coworkers, room to learn new things
cons:
- 1st line management does not care much about employees; senior execs look just at stock valuation; continuous layoff threats (resource action); hardware business uncertain how to continue ---> strategy ? New acquisitions don't work well outside of USA.
- Initiatives at personel level are ususally turned down
- in European countries, IBM just tries to fulfill minimum legal and tax requirements

review_title: Had many different jobs within IBM in almost 27 years at the company.
pros: You can get plenty of independence and responsibility, and great people to work with.
cons: There are fewer great people left - many are voluntarily leaving for more money/less stress.  Decreasing staffing, increasing workload, and disconnected management can make the days very long.

review_title: IBM is a huge and well-run computer company that grows mostly by acquisition rather than organic internal innovation.
job_title: Senior Software Engineer in Costa Mesa, CA
pros: Very stable and successful company; decent benefits, effective management, solid products, strong software and services businesses.  Strong research division, which does most of the internal innovation like the Watson project.
cons: Easy to get lost amid over 400,000 employees and many divisions and product lines.  Political infighting between competing organizations can ruin your day.  Opportunities for innovative work are limited, as the company innovates mainly by acquiring smaller, more innovation companies, rather than innovating internally (other than in IBM research centers).  Hardware business is struggling currently, but that could change.

review_title: Software Engineer right out of college
pros:
Lots of opportunities for starter in the Technology industry. One is able to learn so much from people who are highly qualified.
The work environment is very laid back. You do not have a situation where a manager is constantly on your shoulder.
Talk about work/life balance, this is where you find it.
The pay is very good
cons:
Young people may find it a bit hard because there are very many old people in this company. Many of the old people have been there for several years. The company`s old creed of giving people a career for life is responsible for this.
The company also embarked on rebalancing to refocus its business model which led to some people losing their jobs lately

review_title: Very positive experience
pros:
Great team work, friendly atmosphere, lots of training, the company keeps motivating employees by paying great commissions, job rotations or growth. The company provides lots of benefits to their employees as well. Nothing is impossible to achieve but may take more time comparing to other smaller companies. 
There is absolutely no discrimination based on race, colour, religion etc...one of the staff was fired for making some small racist comments although I don't remember the details. 
And women are encouraged to apply for high positions in the company.
cons: IBM politics, too much processes and approvals but this is almost in all big companies

review_title: Horrible.  Just Horrible.
job_title: Senior Network Administrator in Keyser, WV
pros: Money.  If you are out to do nothing but make money this is the job for you, otherwise go somewhere else.  If you are looking to make a difference or do something epic, this is not for you.
cons: Long Hours.  Unfair review process.  Poor career growth.  Short on staff.  Horrible business practice.  Employees are required to work a 44 hour work week, coincidentally works out so that you only wind up with 1 day off a year IF you are able to take vacation.

review_title: Good career growth but constant threat of layoffs.
job_title: Staff Hardware Engineer in Rochester, MN
pros: Many paths for advancing your career and skill set.  Great people to work with (though if most of your team is on another site, move there or change to a local project).  The environment really is set up to communicate well with your team and provide you the required assistance in getting a project done.
cons: Constant threat of layoffs even in the quarters with good market performance.  Upper management really gives no warning about employment prospects.  It is probably best to be in a city where there are other employment options, should your job go away.

review_title: I think IBM has lost it way
pros: Strong technical talent. You can find a person in IBM that is an expert on anything. This makes it a wonderful place to learn and grow.
cons: Very large and bureaucratic. Not very nimble. Lots of people in middle management just looking for a way not to be blamed if things go wrong. The appraisals are more based on quotas and financials than on performance.

review_title: Overall positive despite being laid off but retired.
job_title: Senior Project Manager in Denver, CO
pros: Company values are well established and the company size allows a lot of latitude especially in the areas of research and development around new technology.  Depending on your work location salaries can be 10% - 20% above the average rates for that location except in some of the biggest metropolitan areas.  Almost everyone knows IBM..
cons: No longer "your father's IBM"...many of the perks and benefits associated with IBM have eroded over the years.  Sometimes the bureaucracy can become overwhelming -- the company is not everyone's "cup of tea".

review_title: A company to learn - A Brazilian perspective
pros: Although in Brazil the company is not known for the biggest pay checks, it is not said enough how much you can learn from it. It allows work relationships with people from all around the globe and many different areas. Mentor program is great, it really gives the mentee new options and different perspectives on their careers. The possibility of getting to know a different area without having to actually move from areas is a big plus!
cons: Salary compared to other companies and to the amount of work required. Working hours (closing quarters required too much overtime).

review_title: Unexpectedly disappointing experience
job_title: Senior Consultant in Quezon City, National Capital Region
pros:
- Brand recognition
- Competitive compensation
- They have spacious office space
cons:
- I transferred to IBM because the company was known for it's processes but it turns out the processes are just done on paper and nobody fully understands why it is done. Therefore, most of the time it does not add any value.
- Irregular working hours
- The Manila Delivery Center was very bureaucratic. Even though it is an international company, management is like a microcosm of the Philippine government. Disappointing, really.
- For people thinking of transferring here, keep in mind it is mandatory to go to work on Regular Holidays. Regular Holiday pay mandated by the PH government does not apply, you only earn a Time in Lieu leave.
- However, taking leaves like Time in Lieu, Vacation Leaves are discouraged. Most of the these benefits are forfeited to achieve the company's financial goal at the expense of the employee's time.

review_title: Everyday is a challenging experience.
job_title: Human Resources Senior Manager in Quezon City, National Capital Region
pros:
Flexible working hours at manager level
Good location, near my home
Everyday is something new, challenging work
My team is great and hardworking
Great addition to my resume
Pay is good at management level 
Availability of a Diana (pumping) rooms
Good training ground for people starting out in thier career. Alot of possible internal movements.
Ability to work from home
cons:
Eventhough inhave flexible hours it is still difficult to maintain work-life balance
Difficult to backfill people and get the resources you need
Poor strategic perspective..sometimes it feels like management decides on a whim
Benefits and salary increases can be improved 
Too many audit and business controls requirements
Culture of a need to work and stay "late"

review_title: PhD Microelectronic engineer
pros: One of the best place all over the world to do R&D in Microelectronic! Lot of very talented people, so you can learn a lot from them. Since it is R&D it is still a very interesting job where you could learn everyday
cons: Not easy to work in a company when you do not know what's going on. Not clear vision of what will happen in less than a year. Due to that lot of people are just not motivated anymore. Forget about see you salary increase, even if you are in the top performers!

review_title: A Sweat Shop WIth Lots of Brain Power
pros: Provides an opportunity to work with some extremely bright people.  Forces you to look at issues from every angle (sometimes to a fault), but is invaluable experience for career growth.  A great place to learn and then move on so you can advance in your career both level wise and $$$ wise.
cons: No life balance at all.  Work, work, work at all hours, since the organization has most of its employees outside of the US you need to be available at all hours.  Employee morale is horrible (at least in the US) and the focus is always on costs...ALWAYS.  Those at the top are very well paid, with lots of incentive; however, the workhorses are not as well rewarded with pay and other types of remuneration.  Obviously, I'm not a long term fan.

review_title: People turn red when you say IBM ISC
pros:
Woking from home model is a pro as you don't need to commute = save time and money 
IBM ISC (following may not be true for IBM finance center or IBM SK) is a good place to start out but....
cons: ... leave as soon as you gain some confidence on how to move around corporate environment and before the toxic and unhealthy atmosphere hurts your self- worth. IBM will not make it right for you. Since financial crises 2008 it has become just another company in terms of caring for employees. Every year they take away a little bit more, pay has flat lined. Benefits suck. Internal education is a joke. Can't get the tools you need to do your job.

review_title: Large Comany making a turn for the worst.
pros: Huge company lots of people you can meet and connect with. Looks good on resume.
cons: Company used to be more stable. Over the past 3-5 years it's starting to get rocky. I wouldn't be surprised if there were massive changes in the next 6-12 months. IBM has always been a set of revolving doors and they seem to be revoling a lot faster as of late. Pay is awful compared to others.

review_title: Good People, Bad Company
pros:
* The people I work with immediately are great people and honest workers.
* The pay is good
cons:
* The company itself does not care about its employees. They are quick to lay off and let go and it's causing their company to become a stepping stone rather than a career builder. 
* There is no accountability in upper management. They all look after each other to keep their bonuses.
* I feel like I signed on to a job rather than a career. It's pretty much expected that you'll leave within a year or 2 for another position. They provide absolutely no incentive for employees to stay.

review_title: Loved the people hated the process.
pros: I met some wonderfully talented people. I did learn a few new programs. Symphony is a terrible program compared to Microsoft.
cons:
The performance reviews were rigged. You were judged not on your personal achievements but on your "band" (level) on your floor on a bell curve. Just like in college. A couple would get 1s, a few would get 2+s, a lot would get 2s, a few would get 3s, and a couple would get 4s. 

Only the 1s & 2+s would get raises and if you got a 3 you were stuck in your position for 18 months. If you got a 4 you were walked out. 

Many times your work was not even comparable to the other band members' work but you were judged the same.

review_title: Loved the people hated the process.
pros: I met some wonderfully talented people. I did learn a few new programs. Symphony is a terrible program compared to Microsoft.
cons:
The performance reviews were rigged. You were judged not on your personal achievements but on your "band" (level) on your floor on a bell curve. Just like in college. A couple would get 1s, a few would get 2+s, a lot would get 2s, a few would get 3s, and a couple would get 4s. 

Only the 1s & 2+s would get raises and if you got a 3 you were stuck in your position for 18 months. If you got a 4 you were walked out. 

Many times your work was not even comparable to the other band members' work but you were judged the same.

review_title: Employee Feedback
pros: Seems to bend over backwards for "Women's employer of choice"
cons: IBM tends to use internal resource placement for roles, often resulting in square pegs in round holes vs best person for the job. Also has tunnel vision with regards to use of S/W owned by competitors e.g when I first started we were not able to use Microsoft excel because it was owned by Microsoft..we had to endure lotus 123 for quite a few years, basically cutting off its nose to spite its face

review_title: Process Engineer
job_title: Fab Process Engineer in Essex Junction, VT
pros: I thought the work life balance was good.  You were able to go home at the end of the day and were not called after hours or on weekends very often.  Most of the time the job seemed balanced, enough to do but not too over whelmed.  I thought management help keep you balanced if you got too much on your plate. Enjoyable people.

review_title: GBS & CIC: Good for recent-grads but don't stay long
job_title: Applications Developer in East Lansing, MI
pros: If you're looking to join IBM GBS in their CIC unit, they offer a good "party platter" of different jobs and roles you can try out. Its is suitable for recent-grads or folks new to IT and software engineering. In this Center, you'll learn a lot of things, and you'll earn a lot of hotel/airline miles from flying every week to client sites. The CIC's clients have a range of demanding jobs. But you're never alone as you'll have the backing of a massive company behind you, ready to help. There are so many experts and SMEs within the company directory to reach out to and ask for help. This is a good place to work for people who are looking for fast paced work with changing demands, you'll end up playing all kinds of roles from dba, sysadmin, IT levels 1, 2, 3, and general programming. If you end up on a project that you dislike after a few months, you could switch to other projects if they have seats available and you get management approval. Projects are very liquid, so if you don't see something you like this week, something else might pop up next week. Your IBM assigned laptop can be Lenovo or Apple Macbook, with the Lenovos offering choice of Windows or a few Linux flavors like RHEL. But some projects require client-approved laptops that are entirely up to them. Lastly, but most importantly, you'll meet lots of smart and dedicated people. Connect with them early and keep in touch. I would only recommend people work at an IBM CIC for a year or so until they can find something else more stable or in their specific career field.
cons:
Client projects available to pick from are mostly legacy and maintenance "keep the lights on", and not a lot of actual programming. (Workday, SuccessFactors, RPM systems, etc.) 

The utilization reports are all that matter. You have to record your hours every week on Thursday by 4pm or managers will hunt you down, but their time-recording tool won't let you pre-set hours for the coming week. 

Your progressions are tied to how many extra hours you can bill the client, and since you're salary you won't earn OT. Progressions to the next band level are only allowed once per year. Its not merit-based. If you're ever sick and looking to take a sick-day, you'll be pushed to work-from-home instead to continue billing hours to the client.

The minimum expected billing is 44hrs/wk but it wasn't unheard of to work 70hrs/wk. Every so often, there will be a competition to see which worker can earn the most hours in a month. Some folks worked 150+% utilization during this time. The winners of these competitions would get a $25-$50 gift card. 

If you're one of the few that actually works in the Center, the office supplies are non-existent. Good luck if you need a pen, paper, whiteboard markers, or other basic supplies as they don't stock up on anything. Including coffee. And no, we weren't allowed to bring in personal coffee makers. 

Conference rooms are constantly being squatted by managers, which forces everyone to make conf calls from their cubicle in an already loud open office. You don't get an IBM-assigned mobile phone, so you'll have to share your personal phone number with managers, coworkers, and clients. 

Projects come and go on a whim. Your project can get pulled out from under you one day and the next you'll be assigned something else entirely. That next project could require travel, so starting next week you could be in New York for the next six months. 

Sometimes the bill codes for a project will stop working, so your utilization will plummet while PMs scramble to get new billing accounts in place. Which triggers your name to show up on reports other mangers see, and then they'll ask why you're not billing hours, and you'll explain the bill code doesn't work, all the while your PM is not communicating this to the upper managers in the first place. 

Even if you're not affected by RAs (mass layoffs), you'll hear about them every year. It wasn't uncommon for PMs and coworkers to disappear. It seemed a lot of seasoned workers would announce their "retirement", only to update their LinkedIn that they're working for another company. Again, make connections while you're here and network with these people as soon as possible. You'll never know if they'll be RA'd or retire unexpectedly.

pros:
-Great 1st line managers
-A few nice staff members (in rare cases)
-Cognitive Computing is somewhat exciting
cons:
-Bottom feeder team leads

-Old business practices
-"Agile"focus that ends up being more like a poorly-executed version of Waterfall

review_title: Nickel and dimed
job_title: Senior Systems Analyst in Indianapolis, IN
pros:
Competitive salaries.
Plenty of new technologies to learn.
cons:
If you play their games (blue dollars used on internal tools that don't work but offered by IBM), you'll do great.
Management taught to never make waves for fear of career being hurt.
Too many policies in place now that only help IBM.  401k matching will only be given in December, if you leave earlier, you forfeit any matching contributions.
No matter how long you've worked with IBM, if laid off, you will only be given one month of severance.  Used to be based on years of service.
These are all smart moves for IBM but eventually the employees understand how little they really matter.
If you've worked there over ten years, be careful, you could be laid off only to be replaced by college grads making 40% less.

review_title: Going Downhill
job_title: IT Architect Lead in Austin, TX
pros: If you live in the USA, getting hired on will be tough, since IBM offshores jobs like crazy.   If you live in a strategic location, find a way to get hired, and join a good team, you might enjoy being at IBM.
cons: IBM has suffered 18 or so quarters of revenue decline, so the company is always "restructuring".  In other words, you will always wonder when you will get laid off (or RAed in IBM terms).  I advise anyone thinking of joining IBM to go elsewhere.  I left IBM voluntarily and it was the best decision of my career.

review_title: Why I Like IBM
job_title: Executive Project Manager in Washington, DC
pros: I consider myself to be a "graybeard" having been around IBM for 20+ years. Over the course of my career I've learned, delivered and succeeded multiple times for multiple clients. Most importantly, I got to decide exactly what I wanted to do each step of the way. During 2016, I participated with the IBM Corporate Service Corps, deployed to Dakar, Senegal with 14 other practitioners to work on several "pro bono" projects that will pay dividends to the Senegalese people and to IBM. I must say this project stands alone as being a highlight of my IBM career.
cons: Like any other organization you must deal with a bureaucracy; however, IBM continues to re-make itself and to remain relevant all practitioner's are challenged to do the same, continuously.

review_title: Staff Are Just A Cost
pros: It is a large company so there are a lot of 'potential' opportunities.
cons:
The company focus is on cost  - bid low and then cut as much cost as possible to meet the contract - the main cost on any contract is people. They are ruthless in their utilisation of human resource - if yo work for them it will be a constant battle to keep your job.
If you work for them, the laptop you sit in-front of is an asset, you are a cost.
Sadly they are no different to many large companys.

review_title: Is that an iceberg?
pros: The team I work for, an acquired company has kept their culture and is an excellent group to work with.
cons:
It is a sinking ship.  The company is trying to sell anything and everything whether or not we have the capability to deliver it or not.   All anyone cares about is delivering whatever the minimal requirements in order to invoice the client.   

Recently had a "Client Executive" threaten me with "heads are going to roll" in an email.  This is 2017, you cannot talk that way to employees, especially after everyone takes and agrees to a Code of Conduct which outlines how this type of behavior is not tolerated.   I realize we are in big trouble as a company that does not give you license to threaten people.

review_title: Sales Manager Software
pros: Smart, motivated people up to the mid management level. Work from home makes it nice especially since must of the day is spent on conference calls.
cons: Six month sales plans and shifting comp strategies with unachievable quotas  make it difficult to make steady commissions worth the intense pressure the company applies. Constant layoffs with ever changing criteria has every employee concerned that they have a target on their back.  Budget cuts have gone so deep that customers are paying the price with reduced support resources and churn.

review_title: Good company overall, a little traditional but it's trying to change.

- Flexibility of work hours.
- IBMers are great people to work with.
- It's trying to transform the way we work.
- Career opportunities, you can different roles within the company.

review_title: Overall, Good Place to Work

cons: A lot of redundancies/overlaps in jobs.  The company is so large that there are portions of the company that has no idea that other areas exist.

review_title: Software Engineer for 30 years who left

review_title: GBS @ big blue
job_title: Applications Architect in São Paulo, São Paulo
pros:
As a giant company, it has tons of projects with a very distinct needs. It's very likely there is a project that needs your skills somewhere.
There is a lot of opportunity for training and it is well seen by the company executives and managers.
cons:
Living by project can be very stressful as you might be assigned to multiple projects with partial fte and in many cases the project managers might not really respect the fte allocation. 
It's also very stressful when you are about to end an engagement in a project and have to look for another project or you are put on the "bench" (just for a bit before you are out). Don't expect a lot of effort on managers and executives to help you find it. They will find for themselves first.

review_title: IBM Global Services
pros: Telling people that you work for IBM gave me immediate respect for my abilities - regardless of what I said I did.  The benefits were greats
cons: The division I was worked for had very poor communication.  The change in the operations from inhouse to the global delivery system was done with seemingly little regard for the inhouse personel.  Compensation changes had rules changes every year - regionalizing pay scales, market adjustments for specific job classes and not others - unfortunately, there are people that were not receiving even a cost of living type adjustment thus effectively getting a negative raise.  That doesn't do much for morale.

review_title: I'm happy!
job_title: Technical Specialist in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Flexibility, work-life balance, strong technical community, ability for an individual to make a difference (for a large organization!) Good salary and benefits (grass isn't greener when you check out other companies). Also, you can have a long, interesting career at IBM by moving around to different divisions, specializing in industries, etc. if you want change (I've been here 10+ years and never thought I would last that long).
cons: A VERY large organization that can be overwhelming when you are new. Some of the senior management seems clueless and you have to wonder how they got to where they are (must be related to someone at the top!)  I think IBM does a good job of recognizing top performers.  Average performers are usually the ones that make the most noise, at least in my division.

review_title: IBM: now with more buzzwords and lawyers! Wait... that's not a good thing...
pros: Variety of job possibilities; positions available worldwide; fairly stable; low expectations; average compensation
cons: Lack of "cool" products; loads of bureaucracy; impersonal; pay is not concomitant with effort; you work for a law firm, not a software company (#1 in patents for years has led to a very litigious corporation); carebear corporate culture that promotes based on externally-recognizable characteristics instead of merits

review_title: It's not your father's IBM
job_title: Senior Project Manager in Lexington, KY
pros: Decent and comprehensive set of benefits. Ability to interact and network with bright people.  A robust infrastructure for access to employee benefit and technical information.
cons: Annual resource actions by stealth that lop off 10% - even solid and above average performers - is demoralizing.  Minuscule or no salary increases. Far too much political correctness required for advancement.  I have over 20 years with IBM and moral is the lowest I have ever seen it.  People are in fear of keeping their job and therefore reluctant to stretch into a new assignments for fear of being the low person on the totem pole when the next RA hits.

review_title: Good money - zero job security
pros: The salary is very good, but creates a feeling that they are "buying" you to the exclusion of the rest of your life.  I was given the oppurtunity to travel the world with IBM, for which I am grateful, and the commerardery between me and my team mates was great while I was there
cons: They do not care that you have a home life, and their use of poermanent agency employees must border on the illegal when it comes to employee's job security.  You live in permanent fear of not being able to interpret a brief in exact accordance with your bosses' vague outline and once you leave, you never hear from them again.

review_title: The IBM Logo Has Lost Its Sheen
pros: In most instances, IBM allows employees to work at home which has been a blessing.  The other benefits (health, dental, and vision) are among the best I have seen.
cons: They will work you to the bone for months on end with no real recognition for it.  For being the largest computer company on the planet, they have internal systems that can frustrate the hell out of you.  IBM's first principle used to be Respect for the Individual, no more.  You won't find that statement anywhere within IBM.

review_title: IBM

review_title: Happy to leave!

review_title: "It's not always about the money Spider-Man"
job_title: Senior Software Engineer in Costa Mesa, CA
pros:
-Opportunity - So much opportunity to do more than just your job, passion projects, giveback to community, working with schools, internal groups, external groups.  My development job at IBM is a very small amount of the work I do, I do more for IBM outside of my lab/office just in the external giveback and working with outside organizations and groups.
-Work Life Balance - I think it's termed "integration" now, which i prefer, I've raised three kids here, it's never a perfect balance but that's ideal, because I get time to work when I need it but also time to drop kids off at school, go to kids sports/games, and help with homework.  I do work a lot, but it's driven by me.  There's tons of projects and things I do when the kids go to sleep or on a quiet evening because I love to do this stuff, and that's just me. 
-Community outreach- there's a huge sense of giveback at IBM.  IBM has a portal for registering volunteering and giveback and gives grants to organizations you work with.  IBM encourages and gives us a lot of autonomy on this so there's no real limit to how much you can work outside of IBM giving back to community as long as it doesn't interfere with your business commitments, and they will provide computing/tech resources/educational kits to help support it.
-Mentoring/networking-the most underated feature of IBM is mentoring, as a senior engineer  we're encouraged to be mentors to junior engineers, and while it's not required, it's extremely helpful to have a mentor, it's allowed me to navigate and plan my career progression based on their advice and experience.  Because you're in charge of your career the mentoring is the perfect amount of coaching and self-accountability that I need to stay motivated and on track in my career goals.
-People- People are awesome, I've worked with many people who work tirelessly with time they don't have to help me, or other people, to work with high school groups, to help people they don't even know within IBM who need help.  The part that makes IBM culture and values amazing is every single person you meet who is a living embodiment to them.
-Overall - The thing I love about IBM is that there's so much to do, I'm never bored, and always feel like I have an impact, but most importantly I feel like my impact is greater outside the company, and helping make the world better by being me and defining how I can give back to my community and help others. Is the pay comparable to the other big companies trying to recruit me?  No, but like Kingpin said "It's not always about the money Spider-Man"
cons:
-Big-, IBM is B-I-G, so there's no list of steps for things like career progression, establishing internal support groups (like a gaming group for example), how to establish a community outreach event, etc. and that's mostly because no one defines what/how you do any of that, and really the way it's done is different for everyone so it's really up to you to figure out how to do all that. 
-Money - They pay well, is it great?  Not compared to the giants like Facebook, netflix, or Google, I've talked to those companies just to know what a move would look like and the money difference can be quite big if that's your motivation.
-Getting things done- I'm not sure I would do anything different for this given IBM's size, but IBM has a much more organic approach to starting things, getting things done, innovating side projects and community outreach etc, where you can start groups and projects you're passionate about, but you have to gather the support for it, you can get support and funding, but you have to originate the idea and figure out how to make it work and do the leg work for it, which is great if you're a type A personality and passionate about something.  But also means you become the project manager, recruiter, and communications person for your particular cause so its easy to take on too much at times.

review_title: Stay away from it unless you are a masochist
job_title: Senior IT Specialist in Copenhagen, Capital Region
pros: They pay you a salary, when you work for them. Only your co-workers keep this place bearable.
cons: This company is huge and highly inefficient. Management is focused on their own circles and careers and care little for people. First line managers should not have the title as manager. They cannot take any decisions themselves and it is ridiculous to negotiate salary with them, as they cannot award anything but peanuts. The work place is considered a factory with common workers crammed into too little space and salaries kept to a minimum. Forget any development if you are above 50.

review_title: Has the potential to be great
pros: The flexibility to work from home or at a client site.  The ability to be able to work on a variety of projects.  If you like to travel this is the company for you considering you can basically live anywhere you chose and travel to your work location if not located in your living city.
cons: Some of the downside to working for IBM as a consultant is you don't have the direct day to day communication with Management.  Even though you have a project manager, that person does not always keep you update on everything going on.  Another downside is if you have problems with a manager or co-workers getting management involved sometimes can be a problem.

review_title: IBM, proud tradition and a place to do honest, relevant work
job_title: Staff Engineer in San Jose, CA
pros: Work/life balance at IBM is better than most other top-tier IT companies.  There are several good projects within IBM for those who are motivated to seek them out, but the company is not dynamic and bleeding-edge enough to provide great experience to all its engineers.
cons:
Being a large corporation with a smaller footprint in the most cutting edge technologies, I believe it is difficult to demonstrate innovative solutions without being hindered by service work and other duties.

It is easy to get stuck in a rut where you are not learning universally applicable skills.

review_title: Great for average employees. No-No for really talented and quicker employees
pros: No hassles. Not much pressure. Good place to relax. Everything is process oriented. So one doesnt have to worry about everything because every small work takes ages to complete. Work and pressure are only for those who want to take them and come forward. In all IBM is a good place to be before retirement.
cons: Very slow growth. Compensation will be shared with others. Top talent will not be able to get the top benefits. ISL looks like the only business unit that has some sense of ability and rewards the talented employees. Young talent will not be able to stay put in the slow paced environment of IBM.

review_title: what I see IBM Global Services
pros: The brand is loud and clear. IBM Global Services is a big family. There are all kinds of jobs and people here. People can have many opportunities in this company. It also provides many kinds of professional and non-professional (hard/soft skill) training.
cons:
1. For an IT specialist, performance is not very important. Overall compensation and benefits is OK for an employee. But, no attractive compensation or bouns for good performance an IT specialist.
2. Many burden and overhead in daily operation. It causes low productivity.
3. Heavy workload. Work, Life balance sounds like a joke recently. It impacts the employee moral.
4. Few and few professional training opportunities.

review_title: Tom Watson is rolling over in his grave...
job_title: Middleware Systems Analyst in Boulder, CO
pros: Opportunity to learn if you are so inclined. Insight into the worst of corporate politics you will encounter anywhere. Chance to develop that ulcer you have always wanted. Best possible people- IBM is a cult not a company, and it is a wonderful thing to be a part of.
cons: Chance to develop that ulcer you haave always wanted. Absolutely ZERO job security- unless the knowledge that you WILL be eventually eliminated counts as job security. Culture of zero work life/balance. "Bleeding Blue" requires bleeding.

review_title: Good to work for 2-3 years
job_title: Technical Team Lead in Gurgaon, Haryana
pros:
1. Work Environment is positive.
2. Work From Home facility is a huge plus
3. Salary at the time of entry is competitive
4. Technical Exposure is unmatched in the Indian IT industry
5. Variety of Projects
6. Support from Project Managers
7. Onsite Opportunity available fairly enough
cons:
1. Salary as you spend more than 2 years in IBM India
2. Career Growth in terms of Promotions not very relevant
3. Ratings & Promotions not very fair.
4. Onsite Accomodation not satisfactory.
5. IBM Global Partners treat IBM India as any other Indian company.

review_title: Even worse than before
job_title: Field Technical Sales Specialist in Philadelphia, PA
pros:
Working from home.

The System x Technical sales group is by far the best technical sales team out there. Sadly, I don't think that's going to be true much longer. I have heard that IBM SE's aren't that great, but I think that's true for the other brands, not x86. The x86 SE's at IBM are top-notch.
cons: Just about everything at this point. IBM was getting to be a terrible place to work about 3 years ago. Now it's unbearable. Almost everyone I know wants to leave.

review_title: Great company, but very large where you feel more like a number...
job_title: Senior Consultant in White Plains, NY
pros: Great company and the know their businesses.  They have great intellectual property and a lot of solid employees.  You definitely have a lot of competent peers to work with and depend on.  They have great strategies and a culture of being number one in the services they provide.
cons: It is such a large organization, you feel like a number and not that important.  Everything is done and reviewed with very formal systems.  Lots of data for data sake.  You have to fill out a lot of forms all the time to document everything.

review_title: IBM is what you make of it
job_title: Staff Software Engineer in Littleton, MA
pros: If you are a go-getter and pro-active about advancing your career, you will climb the ladder. A key to advancement is working cross team and with management several tiers above you.  Most of the time you can pick your hours and work from home, extremely flexible.
cons: There is so much entrenched bureaucracy, sometimes it makes you want to scream. There are definitely glass ceilings everywhere and you have to know how to break through them or sidestep them.  Make sure to negotiate a good salary. Every person is different and has a different salary even if you are the same band level. IBM runs on strict margins, so money can be tight and even as a high performer you often wonder if you'll be cut in the next round of layoffs.

review_title: Great place to kick-off your career
pros:
Course offerings for any type of technology you may be interested in.
The management hierarchy is not just vertical but horizontal. Meaning, your growth is blocked by your managers above you. 
Its one of the best places to start-off your career. IBM training is highly respected in the industry and for the right reasons I would say. I learned a lot of technologies there.
cons:
I would like to have a strong impact on the growth of the company. But, it is hard to do so in a huge organization like IBM. 
I found it hard to stick with it for a long time. But, it is definitely one of the best paces to start your career.

review_title: If getting rich is your goal, IBM is not the place to be.
job_title: Advisory Software Engineer in Raleigh, NC
pros: Lots of smart people to work with, top notch in their technical skills.  Working on latest technologies makes getting up in the morning to go to work a worthwhile endeavor.
cons: Overall treatment of employees needs to be improved.  We are certainly not "interchangeable parts."  Lack of pay raises because one has reached "50%" of market penetration is a joke - one wonders who they survey to reach that conclusion.

review_title: IBM is a company of policies
pros: IBM gives a very good work life balance , it's a company where you can work from any where and they have no questions if you are working from home for months until there is no client escallation.
cons:
Pay pacakage is less compare to others .Its a company for managers .I have got no hike in 2 years and when I was about to get hike I have alraedy decided to leave the company .But surely I want to come back at later age ,it's a company to work in your later days and retire from the same .
Thanks to IBM for giving me a world wide recognition , brand value is excellient .

review_title: Varied experiences based on projects and managers
job_title: Senior IT Specialist in Costa Mesa, CA
pros: There is room to grow and many resources to learn from and take advantage of. There are opportunities to work from home or remotely; however, those opportunities can sometimes be difficult to find and acquire. Benefits, job security, and resources are the biggest reasons to work for IBM.
cons: Typical "big company" politics and game playing regarding promotions, ratings, salaries, etc. Multiple managers and numerous "admin" tasks and policies are sometimes cumbersome. Depending on the employee's specific organization, there can be a high travel requirement for those workers who may not want to travel.

review_title: Not much growth opportunities
pros:
You have the option/liberty of working from home for many projects.
Work time is flexible, they do not monitor your check in and check out time for the day.
Decent onsite opportunities and the salary at onsite is better than many other Indian companies.
cons:
There is not much scope in growing in technical roles. 
The annual hike % is lower than the other top Indian companies, so not the best place to work for remuneration-wise.
Promotion is not automatic after spending x number of years in a band. You have to fight hard (coupled with buttering your management) for band movement, including documenting reasons why you deserve promotion (it's a part of the promotion process!)

review_title: IBM Services Center - Lansing (formerly Michigan Delivery Center)
job_title: Applications Developer in East Lansing, MI
pros: They'll hire just about anyone who has the word "Java" on their resume. Fairly laid back atmosphere. Great for a first job out of college. Chance to get real industry experience with fortune 500 companies. Great benefits on day 1.
cons: Lowest salaries in the field. Overtime exempt. Clients can be downright abusive (in terms of work/life balance) and give impossible deadlines. I know people who have been flown to a client site and worked 10+ hour days every day for a month, and only got to fly back for a day and a half to see their families.

review_title: Good starting point, at least in Czech republic.
pros:
people you get to work with (same lvl as you, some managers are fine aswell)
get in touch with not so common technologies
good place to start career in IT without any previous experience/higher education

review_title: IBM is a mix of old and new management style
job_title: Senior Project Manager in Guadalajara, Jalisco
pros: Home office is a great benefit and IBM experience looks good in the resume
cons: Getting promoted takes years and old  management style expect you to work and wait for long time as they did before getting the promotion.  You need to remember to your managers, and the people that makes decision on your career, about your non-ibm experience because it seems to be ignored and they only consider what you did in IBM,  "how many years do you have working for IBM " is a common question, specially if you want to ask for a promotion. 2-3 years is nothing compared with people that have been there for 20-30 years.

review_title: Not sure about Big Blue anymore
job_title: Senior Engineer in Hopewell Junction, NY
pros: Despite attrition in recent years, still has very deep technical staff.  One of the greatest assets the company has is its people.  Its amazing the work that can be done if you know how to navigate the organization....once you master this skill, the sky is the limit.
cons: On the hardware side, its not clear what the vision is for the company.  As software and services are the financial engines for the company, I think we've lost sight of how hardware fits into the equation.  Also, when the chips are down, there are some really bright people that have come up with unbelievable tactical ideas that have helped us....lets leverage those people more on an everyday basis.

review_title: Good but not a lot of room for advancement
pros: The people I worked with were smart and professional.  I learned a lot and enjoyed my time there.  There was a lot of comradery and collaboration.
cons:
There review process seemed ok but didn't really mean anything.  It's all numbers at IBM, and if there isn't a budget for what you are doing, doesn't matter how well you do.
IBM is moving there support services offshore which will decline their service in that area.
Felt like a number in the end.
Pay was as low as the market you were in would bare, and raises were few and far between.

review_title: The Business Equivalent of the Borg!
pros: A large company does provide a level of stability.
cons:
IBM grow by identifying new innovations and then buying the smaller companies that made them. They're so large that they can continue to do this.

The biggest problem is that you end up with a few hundred emails every day, most of which are people NOT adding any useful information to a topic, but saying that they agree totally with the email, and how fantastic it is! This isn't the way to run projects; most IT firms I'd worked for previously (including Sun Microsystems) would only want you to "reply to all" in the event that you had some technical information that was relevant to the email, and NOT because you were trying to have your name made known to everybody.

review_title: Fast-paced and efficient work environment but not exciting.
job_title: Advisory Software Engineer in Kirkland, WA
pros: The employees are all smart and dependable. The company is efficiently run (at least in my department) and I learn a lot about efficiently managing and working in large software projects.
cons: The workplace is very competitive and not very rewarding. You complete against your peers for paltry raises. The amount of cost cutting is very concerning and many people are worried about layoffs. Everyone I work with has been been working on the same pieces of the same software project for over a decade.

review_title: Missed Opportunity ... again and again
job_title: Senior Project Manager in Research Triangle Park, NC
pros: Some really smart and talented people who go way above and beyond under difficult circumstances to meet stated objectives.
cons: Knows they have some great people so uses them until they are driven off or ground to dust.  Relies too much on the name brand and past glories.  Shadow of the company it used to be.

review_title: A sinking ship with no happy people left
pros:
-if you have been out of the market for a while and want to get some experience, come here. It is really easy to be hired.
-Good if you want to improve your language skills (German, French, Spanish, Italian, Russian, etc.). You will get the chance to speak to native speakers on a daily basis.

-Unexperienced people is assigned to key roles they are not prepared for.
-Most of the managers have never had International experience and that can be perceived in their daily decisions.

review_title: Great place to learn on the job. More and More  Miserly across the board.

Health and 401K are very good, except that they moved to giving the company match only at the end of the year - so either you stay and get it or you loose it. review_title: Working for IBM, Nice
pros: Working as a contractor for ten years, I was very well treated. I wa allowed work from home when I wanted. The most important thing for management was I did a good job.
cons: Working in France as a contractor, the social charges are enormous. This isn't IBM's fault but a problem with a socialist country and government. Also, not an IBM problem, but to build a career in France, you need to be in Paris. There is a very central view of companies in France.

review_title: Incredible support for Millennials and Women
pros:
I am a part of the Summit program, which is consistently ranked as one of the top training programs in the country. IBM invests a significant amount of time and money into developing young professionals, which is not very common these days. 
Work-life balance is very good. Employees are able to work from home. I go into the office 3 days a week and work from home the rest. 
Women hold a large portion of senior leadership positions, and support for women is standard practice.
cons:
Bureaucracy of a large company and the time it takes to include all the right people. 
Some silos that make communication between business units uncommon.

review_title: In-competitive salary & faulty appraisal system
pros: Work from Home Option, Training modules to keep the employees up to date
cons: The annual appraisal system(formerly PBC, currently Checkpoint) is faulty. This needs to be corrected. The increment policy is also not adhered to.

review_title: Software Development
pros: Excellent support for personal issues like appointments, childcare related time off, etc.  Reall good leadership development, incredible smart and talented peers, Latest technology innovation like AI, fantastic benefits package.
cons: Not specifically a con, but more a data point, being a large company, the work culture depends on the division you are in.

review_title: Under Major Transformation
pros: Excellent leadership trainings, great at being divers and accepting culture
cons: Most of the organizations within IBM go through major change, and after 5 years of strategy shift, the company still suffers of continuous QtQ revenue decline. This generates fake enthusiasm of the leaders, who are rather nervous of making their budget, doesn't matter what. Obviously this is recognized by the employees, who make sweaty efforts to assist the change, though the biggest changes should rather start with high level (organizational) changes.

review_title: Career Suicide
pros: Work life balance. Flexible timings.
cons:
No Hikes. (Yes none at all. Even if you have been working for 3-5 years still you won't get anything)
Bonus? Nope. (Officially, you might be lets say entitled for 2.5 lakh bonus.. you will get probably around 35-40k if you are lucky)
Promotion? Nope. (There are literally no appraisal cycles at IBM. You might get a promotion if you are lucky)
Band - When you are recruited, please make sure your band is as per your experience level. Otherwise you will be recruited at a lower band with a higher salary and your "PMR" (internal IBM metric to give hikes and promotions) will always be on the higher side resulting in no hikes for an indefinite period. 
Weak Management - IBM has thick headed people in senior management positions who are least bothered about employees.

review_title: Restless Transformation at Big Blue
pros: Constant transformation as a technology firm means restless reinvention of skills required. I have had ten roles in ten years and have had a phenomenal career growth. Learning and leadership programs are best in class including participation in Corporate Service Corps assignment to Tanzania. Brand remains one of the most valuable. Truly a global corporation with daily interactions with colleagues from across the globe. Aspiration to change the world through innovation that matters such as cognitive computing to improve healthcare and education means it is easy to find relevance and meaning in one's work.
cons: As a large corporation with nearly 400K employees, decision-making tends to be slow with many layers of approval required.

review_title: P-Tech is a Fantastic Program!
pros: Simply put, I work at IBM because of the great people and the broad career opportunities -- along with additional opportunities to make a difference.  One that stands out to me is Pathways in Technology (P-Tech), a wonderful mentorship program that I've been involved with for 3 years.    I enjoy making a positive impact on public education, and IBM has offered me a great way to contribute.  New collar jobs are critical to our future success, and I'm confident that my P-Tech mentee will one day be a star!
cons: Long hours at times, given global working relationship and dependencies in our business

review_title: Corporate Communications
pros: Without a doubt the best part of the job is the people. Brilliant, collaborative, and open to new ideas, they spur lots of opportunities for employees that aggressively seek advancement. And I'm particularly impressed and proud to call myself an IBMer because of their leadership in diversity, inclusion and patent leadership. I'm bullish about IBM's future and the powerful ways we can help our clients and their clients build smarter businesses.
cons: At 380k people, this business is not for those who can't operate in a matrixed environment. It's best suited for networkers who thrive on the size instead of getting lost in it.

If you are a fresh graduate and a great self learner then you can join but keep yourself updated with technology as you will not be contributing much in projects in IBM GBS.

* Hike is very very less.
* It depends on the manager if you are going to get awards/rewards for your good work.

review_title: Worst Company to work.. probably beacause everything is management discretionary

Work from home.
Flexible timings.
Work Life balance is great

Everything is management discretionary, HR have no role. Management lies a lot.
Ask to work as oncall for 12 hours for Rs.300 and for some projects we have a lot of work pressure in oncall (Rs. 300 is really low when I am getting Rs.1k for 8 hours of work in a regular day).

management is really bad, ask to work from 12-9 in general shift etc. and there are no HR policies, HR say everything is management discretionary.
No career opportunity.

review_title: Watson Health - Changing company management not in touch with reality
