review_title: Mixed bag
job_title: Marketing Manager in New York, NY
pros: Large company with many business units means you can expand your skills and grow your career without leaving the company. Strong emphasis on learning and many internal resources to build skills. Positive stances on important issues facing the country (e.g., diversity)
cons: Large company with many business units can sometimes mean too much bureaucracy, too much reporting, and groups working within their own silos instead of collaborating. There are some amazing, smart people... but there are also many who have risen up the ranks but don't add value. It's frustrating to encounter those people. Despite the positive stances on important social issues, I'm not always convinced they practice what they preach. Layoffs every year are inevitable and no one is immune.

review_title: Reality at IBM
job_title: Advisory I/T Specialist in San Ramon, CA
pros: Very few. I was a 31 year employee and have watched as the current management has taken  what was one of the best companies in the world and reduced to an "also ran". Senior management has been in "react mode" for so long that they think long range planning is what's for lunch tomorrow. The work force has been so reduced that we were all forced to work 15-25% uncompensated overtime and still the layoffs continued. They company no longer cares about it's customers or employees, just how much upper management can steal from the company. Most of us long term employees lost over 50% of our retirement in 1999 when "Three-Fingered Lou" needed some more money.
cons: Long hours, low pay, no job security, no respect for workers.

review_title: Rocognition of On-Shore Resources
job_title: IT Specialist in San Francisco, CA
pros: Resources are limited so you get to wear many hats.  You have the ability to move to different organizations if you have the required skillsets.
cons: Gradual replacement of on-shore with off-shore resources.  Cost and and number of billable hours appears to be their number concern.  Your job can be eliminated at any time if they no longer need you or you become an expense to the company.  There are a few unfair practices that I've seen while I was working at IBM, such as deferral of vacation to boost their productivity ratio, reduction of base salaries by 15%,  reclassification to lower band.  Management is not always supportive.  On the average, you have the find another position every 2 years.

review_title: IBM. An original curate's egg?
pros:
Whilst promotion is often terrible if you stay in the same job group, IBM is such a large company that there is always an opportunity to move elsewhere if you're prepared to step out of the 'comfort zone'
The support from your colleagues and team members is usually excellent and wherever possible there is a great deal of flexibility in hours and locations worked.
cons: Its a large company... The same thing that makes for a wide range of job options has also meant that the company is suffering from excessive red tape and is frequently far too process led.

review_title: Good but can be much better.
job_title: Advisory Software Engineer in Westford, MA
pros: The rang of opportunities is very high. A lot of very talented people work here. While not always easy to find, there are projects that are on the bleeding edge of technology.
cons: High barrier to ship projects; a lot of non-functional requirements to keep in mind (globalization, accessibility, etc.) that detract from interesting work. Hard to be promoted if in a top-heavy organization with a lot of senior engineers.

review_title: A great place to work, as long as money isn't your motivator
job_title: Staff Software Engineer in San Jose, CA
pros: There's ample opportunity to work on cutting edge stuff.   Anyone who enjoys systems programming and is good at it will have a job at IBM.
cons:
- The belts in the company are extremely tight right now.  Despite record profits, IBM is not investing the money in their employees.
- Getting your job outsourced is a constant fear.
- attempting to complete any task is a constant battle.  The bureaucracy at IBM is worse than its reputation.

review_title: Work if you can put up with the management BS
job_title: Senior Hardware Engineer in Austin, TX
pros:
Good Pay, some flexibility... really depends if you work in Hardware or Software. 
Payscale is good compared to other companies at least in Austin
cons:
off shoring, complex management system. Likes to make everything single thing way too complicated. 
Management does not value employee loyalty and experience... if they don't need you, then you are out. 
management keeps changing often. Its hard to focus when you management keeps on re organizing every 4  - 6 months. 
By the time you get comfortable working with one manager, you have another manager and his style to adapt to. 
Employee morale is also low because of this.

review_title: Not sexy as Apple; not smart as Google; not talented as Microsoft
job_title: Staff Software Engineer in Austin, TX
pros: Working at IBM there were many opportunities to learn new technologies and a wide range of jobs available if interested in moving about the company.  HR and corporate IT were competent and professional.  Managers were typically well trained in their roles (e.g. strong focus on communication and coaching).  Coworkers were usually sane, intelligent and amiable.
cons:
The business focus was driven entirely quarterly.  Very bad vibe coming from middle-management (who didn't care about their professional employees).  The atmosphere felt cold and chronically stressed-out.  Upper management was aggressive about rolling back employee compensation (e.g., shifting focus toward younger, shorter-term employees that can work insane amounts and burn out).  Easy to become pigeonholed in a bad role/division (managers can block you from seeking different jobs within the company... and do exercise the right during horrible projects or in bad teams -- most of which are).

Feedback/ratings were based more on gaming the system than actual employee contribution (i.e. to limit bonuses/raises there can be only one, maybe two, excellently rated employees in your team; the rest have to be average).

Most importantly, moving up in terms of leadership is only a doorway into some weird political arena where you are more responsible for gaming the arbitrary metrics defining success than in actual accomplishment -- i.e., you do whatever it takes to affect some meaningless improvement in a spreadsheet.

It's an OK place, but don't stay too long or it will rob you of the skills needed to survive outside the company.  Lots of people in their late 20's talk about their big ideas outside the company, but get comfortable and never go anywhere.  But the company is ruthless now so realize from the day you join your days are numbers (so always keep exit doors open so when the time comes it's for the betterment of your career rather than for the sake of whether your division exceeds or underperforms its quarterly target by one percent).

review_title: Hoping for the best.
pros: IBM had a good name years ago, one of the top innovators.  If one focuses on learning there is a lot of potential to learn many aspects of the business.  There is potential to excel in one's job if you keep your focus.
cons: Too big so that some managers are apparently either not competent and not trained to bring out the best in themselves and others.  It appears innovation is not rewarded enough.   Not just technological innovation, but innovation in how to run a business in order to make the truly company indespensible because customers will always expect the best, next great thing.

review_title: Stay away until Sr. Management changes
pros: There are opportunities to work on exciting projects and learn how a large company works.  The benefits are good (not great).  With the right manager, you can have a good work-life balance.
cons: Executive management does not communicate truthfully about layoffs or pretty much anything dealing with employees.  They have basically been lying about the current layoffs.  Of course, they layoff staff but very few managers.  They purport to hire only the best, but then they have no problem giving ranking based on an arbitrary distribution.  Which in turn does not make employees feel very valued.  Benefits have slowly been reduced over the years; waiting for that to happen again.

review_title: Great people, awful management.
job_title: Senior Software Engineer in Chicago, IL
pros: Wide array of projects. Experts on almost any subject are available and helpful. IBM has a reputation for excellent which lends automatic respect to any outside contacts.
cons: Constant reorganizations and layoffs.  Organization is intended to protect senior managers turf, not promote efficiency.  Respect for IBM is largely based on IBM's past behavior when product excellence was encouraged and employees were encouraged to develop deep expertise in subjects.  Current IBM strategy is to minimize cost and produce mediocre products that are "good enough."  Technical expertise is not valued by management. Successful IBMers learn to ride the wave of popular technology while doing little concrete work.

review_title: Good place to start
pros: Great benefits for all.  The pay is also quite good.  The name will really open a lot of doors for you down the line.  They also offer great training opportunities for all employees to join in on.
cons: No such thing as a 40 hour week. they expect much more of a time commitment from their employees though which is a bit unfair in my opinion.  Also there is no real office.  So many people work from home so it is tough to meet coworkers.  Theres no real office christmas party and things like that, youre kind of on your own.

review_title: Interesting work, but high pressure and insufficient resources
pros: Good people to work with and the work can be interesting.
cons: There is never enough time or people to do the work we're given.  There is very high pressure to get any problem resolved immediately.  Nights and weekend work is common, without compensation.  There is little recognition for doing a job well the first time.  But if you make a mistake and then correct it, then people notice that you fixed something, even though you were to the one to break it to begin with.  As in many places, those that talk the loudest are those that advance, even if what they are so loudly talking about is nonsense.

review_title: Wanna work in India????
pros: Solid company with a good reputation.  Good benefits including 401k with company match, medical, vision, dental, etc..  Training is generally available but needs to be completed on line.  On site training opportunities are rare and limited due to funding issues.
cons: Work life balance is challenging.  Resource actions are becoming more numerous.  Too much focus on the cutting costs at the expense of jobs in the US.  Global resourcing can result in significant positive impact to the companies bottom line, but for the most part the quality of services provided suffers and results in poor customer satisfaction and a loss of revenue.

review_title: IBM global services is lost in its direction, believing it has value propositions it only proposes to have .
pros: Its part of a historic company who's values have been treasured by employees for years. Working for such a diverse company with the benefits it provides makes you recognize the historic support of its employee value proposition.
cons: IBM has lost its way, with IGS leading its demise, by ignoring customer value and destroying employee morale. IBM believe that billing is more important that the clients needs, and has become a factory of poor skills that clients end up replacing weekly.

review_title: I advise Federal clients, I shouldn't be force to work along side Federal clients
pros:
Available opportunities to contribute and lead on your individual project, if you seek them

Very bright and competent colleagues who really roll up their sleeves to get the job done
cons:
If you are too good, you may end up stuck on the same project for years.  While your specialization in a subject matter area may deepen, your opportunities to go to other projects becomes severely limited.

Your salary may trickle.

review_title: Micro managed by Shareholders, Extremly Virtual, too big to fail.
pros: Good brand to keep you afloat in bad economy. Not sure IBMer meanes anything with 400K emplyees.
cons:
Its a Jungle inside. everything is virtual. Like a website.
Partners are Gods. very unapproachable.
100% of GBS is travel based. travel/expense policy sucks. IBMers have lost thier class. Sole aim make wealthy share holder happy. 
With 95% utilization requirement, only thing you can take is 3 days and federal/state holidays.
extremely limited salary increase. Promotion means nothing with limited salary increase.

review_title: IBM - Good working environment
pros:
Flexible working hours and IBM has a policy to set offices within city limits 
Great place to learn new technologies
Wide range of job roles
cons:
IBM is not a paymaster and so salaries are less compared to similar employers 
Work in IBM is recognized based on your documentation and not on your deeds
One has to set his path himself - right or wrong people guide you but not the path

review_title: Fairly stable job, no-nonsense and professional benefits.
job_title: Staff Software QA Engineer in San Jose, CA
pros:
The stability of my particular job and some of the people I have been able to work with are the best parts of working for IBM.  It's also relatively easy to look for other job opportunities within IBM before they go to external hiring.

The benefits (salary, health, retirement) are basic but actually quite good, IMO.  I'm not sure about the salary part, but my health and retirement benefits are good, including retirement matching (up to 5% of my salary) plus an additional 1%.
cons: I'm not sure the salary is as competitive as it could be.  It seems other newer companies pay more for their engineers.

review_title: Good culture, Flexible working hours, could do with better compensation and benefits.
pros:
Love the flexibility offered in terms of lunch time, office hours and working from home when needed.
Emphasizes good communication between manager and employee by having 1 to 1 meetings and feedback sessions.
Big on education and training so lots of learning opportunity available.
Good culture and opportunities for career development.
Good
cons:
Increment and bonus is quite pathetic.
Can be lost in a huge organization like this. 
Though opportunities are there competition is tough as well and you got to fight for it and sometimes its not always fair.
Waste a lot of time dealing with the numerous systems and problems, tedious processes and sometimes long line of approvals.

review_title: It's ok for a while to have a good reference in your CV
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Frankfurt am Main
pros: IBM is a big company, which offers you a lot of opportunities to enhance your skills. You can learn a lot if you care for yourself.
cons: IBM is a controlling company in its inner processes. There is no flexibility and if you make a good job it will not be honored in the long run. You wont make a fast career, everything will take its time.

review_title: IBM is going on almost 2 years of flat / falling sales;  the reaction is to invest less and push harder
job_title: Business Development Manager in San Jose, CA
pros: smart people, many of whom do care about relationships and doing the right thing for the client
cons: It's a financially driven organization and we are absolutely feeling the pain of not growing the top line;  They compensate by squeezing more costs out (our salaries) to grow the bottom line;  many of my peers have had salary roll backs in the last many years as sales objectives are nearly impossible to make......

review_title: Great company, but too much sales oriented
pros:
- some colleagues are really great,
- relaxed atmosphere (at least within the technical community, usually not impacted by layoffs),
- some great technology to build solutions upon.
cons:
- the majority of colleagues, especially upper-level managers, seem incompetent (or just stupid),
- too many useless roles within the company, most of the people don't know much about IT but deal with incredibly slow and complex internal processes,
- especially in latest years, the whole organization has been too focused on sales, completely forgetting customer satisfaction or even customer needs.

review_title: Bipolar Corporation
pros:
Great health care  benefits
Many committed employees
Opportunity to work in many facets of IT industry
Pension check for those who were fortunate enough to be in the plan
cons:
Requirement to work 60+ hours weekly 
Target employees for resource action ( firing)  once they turn 50  reardless of performance, and contribution to the business..
Too many layers of executive management and the executive perks are bordering on criminal 
Latest 401K modification (paid only once a year so if they RA you 1 day prior to the annual payment day you get no IBM matching)   
HR focused 
In the future I expect IBM will default on the pension plan

review_title: The good and bad of a huge company
pros: I enjoyed/respected the amount of trust placed in me.  I felt very empowered to do whatever was necessary to get the job done.  The people I worked with were the some the best, most knowledgeable folks I have worked with in my life.
cons: I specific group I worked in handled Lenovo service.  Like any other company working in service in the USA, it felt the pinch of the global economy and the VERY thin margins in that business.  My job was one of 5000 that were eliminated in a round of down-sizing.

review_title: The good and bad of a huge company
pros: I enjoyed/respected the amount of trust placed in me.  I felt very empowered to do whatever was necessary to get the job done.  The people I worked with were the some the best, most knowledgeable folks I have worked with in my life.
cons: I specific group I worked in handled Lenovo service.  Like any other company working in service in the USA, it felt the pinch of the global economy and the VERY thin margins in that business.  My job was one of 5000 that were eliminated in a round of down-sizing.

review_title: Many talented people, frequently stretched thin as the company aims to execute on new strategies and existing business.
pros:
There are many people with very good technical skills in the company, and a strong work ethic.  Having been with the company for a long time, in my opinion there is no longer "dead weight" in contrast to 20 years ago when there were still employees with mentality that IBM was a place of lifetime employment regardless of contribution level.  

The career opportunities are especially good for new entrants into the company (college hires).
cons:
The company is trying to execute on new strategies which is both exciting and stressful - the legacy businesses are still critical to maintain which stretches resources thin.  

There are a lot of experienced and hardworking employees with limited opportunities.

review_title: great place to start a career, with some challenges
pros:
amazing work life balance
people are kind, smart, and generally very collaborative
marketing jobs allow for creativity & autonomy - you define your own role
work when i want, where i want - and the Austin office is one of the best IBM sites
it's exciting to be a part of a huge corporation's transformation
opportunities to learn & travel
cons:
one word: hi- er-arch-ic-al
executives and directors aren't questioned or challenged enough
as a new employee, remote working can become isolating & impersonal
budget is incredibly tight
unclear path to advancement + promotion for new University hires

review_title: Senior UX Consultant
job_title: Managing User Experience Consultant/Strategy in South Bank, England
pros: Fast progression into a career that normally takes years. They progress juniors and hand out grandiose titles so they can charge more. Lack of visibility so you can do as you please. Work from home. Lots of time, they tend to charge in minimum time blocks so plenty of time. A week to do what could be done in a couple of hours.
cons: Low quality and lack of real training. All the training is IBM's way of doing things which will not get you a better job. You could be moved off to something else. The seniors are forced to do sales. Everyone is assigned to their own project so no where to go for help. Managers are crap. All anyone cares about is money.

review_title: Good company to start in IT
job_title: Test Specialist in Porto Alegre, Rio Grande do Sul
pros:
- Very complex work which turns out as a good learning experience about processes and job duties
- Good starting salary
cons:
- Very hard to get a salary raise
- If the branch you'll work was created by outsourcing, it is very difficult for IBM to separate customer and company values making it more customer than company related.
- Very orthodox company meaning that suits and ties are almost mandatory if you want to be considered as a "real" professional

review_title: It all depends on the project
job_title: IT Data Specialist in Quezon City, National Capital Region
pros:
- rotation to different projects available every 18 months (employee may prefer to stay depending on his/her performance)
- flexibility in hours (window)
- flexibility on the location of work (you may report to different IBM sites, if project allows)
- work from home
- promotion is employee-driven
cons:
- you may be put in a project that makes you do nothing (I was in a project for almost 2 years doing nothing)
- strict on hours rendered
- applying for a leave needs to be approved by 3 or more managers
- promotion is employee-driven (you have to do a lot of essays in an internal tool though. regardless if you're working so hard, if you haven't done these essays, you will not be promoted)
- there's a lot of online trainings needed to take

review_title: Great Work place and Culture
pros: Thinking and learning is great at IBM. You can propel your career a add a lot of skills and personal growth when you work at IBM. There is a good work life balance that you might not experience at other IT Services Companies in India. Welfare of employees and their continuous improvement is a key goal at the organization. Some great minds work at IBM and you might get the opportunity to meet them in person. The perks are also great.
cons:
Being a large company there are often too many silos.
There won't be too many meaningful conversations you are bound to have unless you are in the top rung.
You are mostly on your own and often cannot grow easily.
Too many rules and policies can curb your process of innovation.

review_title: Constantly Learning and Growing My Skills
pros: IBM has great, smart people and very meaningful work.  IBM as a corporation wants to change the world, and because of that takes on bold challenges.  There is an amazing depth of skills across the company, and for self-starters, you can constantly learn about the new technologies and capabilities that IBM has to offer.
cons: Because the size is big, and it is hard to turn a big ship, it can be a difficult place to Transform quickly.  The workload can be significant, so a person needs to manage his or her work/life balance effectively.

review_title: This is not your daddy's IBM!
job_title: Senior Systems Architect in Atlanta, GA
pros: IBM brings together an amazing array of technology as the basis of real, practical solutions  that power Earth's commerce.  Some people still think of IBM as "that mainframe company", but today's IBM has been transformed into an agile, leading edge technology creator.  As an IBMer, it is amazing to be able to pick up the phone and chat with the very people who are creating and shaping tomorrow.  Blockchain, quantum computing, cognitive computing, and countless other technologies are real-world here.  Yes, we still sell some big iron; but (surprise!) it runs Linux!
cons: No way to hide it -- IBM is a big enterprise, with nearly a half million employees around the world.  It isn't a startup!

review_title: Toxic Environment
pros: I have had the pleasure to work with some excellent, experienced engineers who I have learned an infinite amount about professional software development from. Besides this, there are very few positives.
cons:
Little or no career progression opportunities.
Absolutely zero effort to up-skill staff.
Comparatively poor compensation.
No employee benefits.
An infinite amount of red tape / bureaucracy prevent ANY innovation taking place.
Poor management who are only interested in playing the political game for their own gain. 
Large scale hiring freezes / redundancies, company wide,  while the CEO takes larger and larger bonuses, year on year, despite continual quarterly declines.

review_title: IBM
pros: Large company who is trying to provide services it hadn't before and strives to innovate.
cons: In my experience IBM turned out to be worse than all of the worst things you've ever read about the company,  and that is pretty bad considering the volume of terrible things that are written. The work they acquired from PepsiCo was managed incredibly sloppy, they did not seem to care about their people at all and over time proved to be bold faced liars. The executive team and company had no interest in trying to learn the work before making assurances they could not, and did not deliver. I would be shocked if Pepsi continued to do business with them and renewed the contract here in a couple of years.  Overall my experience after 3 years was that the company was sloppy, careless, and remarkably arrogant.

review_title: Severe work place bullying
pros:
Access to learning resources.
Brand name.
cons:
Growth in terms of promotion and salary is poor.
The managers use the team members to spy and bully each other causing poor workplace team spirit.Its a typical indian scenario of subjugating junior staff .All activites are monitored without logic or need.Every computer actvity is open to tracking and mindless games are played.Best avoid this organization.Average technical capability of staff causes workload to be transferred to few who work.

review_title: Sinking Ship
job_title: Senior Service Delivery Manager in London, England
pros: Flexibility.   This was the only aspect of IBM that kept me working for them for so long.  The ability to work from home,  do the school runs and negate the cost of child care during holidays.
cons: IBM no longer care about their people.  No training,  No pay rises,  pathetic bonus,  constant threat of redundancy with regular consultancy periods announced (3 in 2017 & 2018's chopping 1018 people).   The company has become a joke.

review_title: Cuts to the bone
pros:
interesting work, if you want, you can do a lot, learn a lot, plenty of experienced people (inexperienced as well), working for same customer for 5 years

In 5 years, my wage rose by 63%, but i am a lucky person
cons:
constant cuts, low performers do not need to worry,  money are not well spent, easy to hide., some of the colls are bona fide alcoholics, hard to get education, almost impossible to get certification

Best part are your goals set by your manager, but you have no benefits, so who cares?

If you are on salary band 8 (band 9 is almost non-existent) you are told, that you earn enough, it`s not bad, but there is a thing called inflation...

review_title: IBM is a Good Company
job_title: Human Resources Process Owner in Manila, Manila
pros: Flexibility.  Culture is good.  Family oriented. Overall IBM is a good company to work with. I think any where in the world  can have challenges. But with IBM everything seems manageable.
cons: 1. Less opportunities for client interface roles in day shift.  2. Focused in training employees to learn which is good but those who dont perform at all whose already a burden to their workmates remain in IBM. I think they also need to ensure EVERYONE remain a contributor to work equally with the others.

review_title: It was a great place for a career ... back in the day
job_title: Vice President, Partner in Armonk, NY
pros: You can tackle anything at IBM if you find your nitch.
cons: No one has your back.  Cutthroat is the current model.  No one cares about the client or delivery.  It is all about selling and not about the people.

review_title: Get Out of Healthcare
pros: Big name, lots of room to hide if you do not really want to work and drive results.
cons: Lots of room to hide.  Plenty of "empty boxes".  The GM  and her club of ex-Philips people inherited a mess but did nothing to improve Watson Health.  In fact, the culture is toxic.  The technology does not work.  Watson Health has been the kiss of death for many people including former PwC folks who came over from GBS, the old "bleed blue" boys clubs, and a few rounds of hi-po talent recruited right out of school.

review_title: Great place to develop, though compensation isnt' competitive.
pros:
Solid, stable place to start a career.  You can grow as fast as you drive yourself... but motivation must be internally driven.  

Experience will widely vary by which division that you land in.  Services businesses typically place a large emphasis on number of billable hours worked.  Systems division is always trying to run a more lean business and do more with less.  Software is not uniform as a number of current employees were brought on through numerous acquisitions over the last 5-10 years.
cons: Salary is not competitive with market rates if you stay more than a few years.  Constant revamping of employee benefit programs makes you wonder if HR has anything better to do.

review_title: Not a bad place to work
job_title: Advisory Software Engineer in Austin, TX
pros: It's a large company so you can change jobs without missing a paycheck or losing your seniority.  We produce innovative technology that is exciting to work on and gets used around the world.  And there are a number of really outstanding people to work with.  Most parts of IBM area also very supportive of having a life outside of work, and are friendly to those of us with families.
cons: Red Tape.  IBM is slow to change directions and slow to take up new initiatives.  It also gets political because of it's size.

review_title: A reputable company, a good choice especially for beginners
pros:
It is a global company so that I can work with remote colleagues of a different culture. I do enjoy it.
IBM has rich learning resources, online learning courses, seminars from other departments, education activities, from which I benefit a lot.
I especially IBM to a career beginner, since it is a good place to learn about standard processes, form good work habits, and develop soft skills that are important to your career success.
cons: Career development within IBM is slow. You have to be patient and wait a lot. Also, the

review_title: IBM isn't that great of a place to work.
job_title: Staff Software Engineer in San Jose, CA
pros: There are good discounts with business partners.  It looks good on a resume when you look for a new job (and most of us inevitably will).
cons: Layoffs even when the company's profits are in the billions.  The CEO describes layoffs as 'business as usual'.  We're expected to create world-class products using worthless, freebie tools that don't work properly.  Managers change jobs regularly every two years, leading to instability in every group.  Quotas in performance reviews stop careers from progressing.  The internal financial results our bonuses are based on are always somehow lower than the public results, so our bonuses are always lower than projected.

review_title: Highest Tech
job_title: Advisory Engineer in East Fishkill, NY
pros: Engineers can get to work with the highest level of semiconductor technology the world has to offer.  The 300mm fab is a magnet for partner companies around the world to come and develop the most advanced computer chips.  We have the newest and best processing equipment that money can buy and the most talented engineers who are able to get the best out of the semiconductor manufacturing process.
cons: Layoffs have been happening frequently for the last eight years.

review_title: Senior Management was incompetent, had no vision, no clue about leadership and  no transparency in decision making
pros: Opportunity to work closely with line of business, option to work from home, a known brand in the marketplace
cons: Lack of competent senior leadership, lack of transparency in decision making and information sharing, highly bureacratic procedures with no accountability for operations and support funtions, non-functioning HR, no focus on retaining key people in the organization with a well defined career path

review_title: Stressful
job_title: Staff Software Engineer in Poughkeepsie, NY
pros: Awesome colleagues.  The software engineers I worked with were absolute professionals, hardworking, helpful and most were wonderful to work with.
cons: You never know from one quarter to the next whether you'll still be employed.  Your performance doesn't matter if you're in the wrong place at the wrong time.  You may be given time to find other jobs within the company, but even if you find an opening within your division, the manager may not be allowed to hire you if the overall goal of the "resource action" was to reduce headcount:  They have to wait until the latest batch of "surplus" employees are out the door before filling the position.

review_title: Lead was a used car salesman in better clothes - always wired, arrogant, unhelpful, generally verbally abusive.
pros: It got me into a client that proved to be a good working environment, a solid project, in an industry I knew nothing about.
cons: I was a contractor to IBM, which then farmed me out to their client.  The role was more a project planner than a PM, at a very premature time in the cycle (platform was not approved, no project sponsor ID'ed, no scope done, no feasibility done, no on-boarding done - to IBM or the client...

review_title: A tough business to work for long term
job_title: Global Program Manager in Denver, CO
pros: Large company with many areas to move around in.  Hiring salaries are somewhat competitive.  Working from home really allows people to focus on families.
cons: It is simply impossible to move your salary yearly at IBM.  Even when your a top 10 percent contributor each year, you often max at at 3 percent raises.  I have moved 4 levels in 10 years and am an enterprise level manager, and make less then new professional hires.  Life at IBM is always travel freezes, and Resource actions.  IBM is just not a place you can be a top performer and care about your career long term anymore.

review_title: Procedure over people
pros: Great people, solid middle managers.  Good benefits.  Worked with a team that genuinely tried to get the best work completed.  Our worst enemy was the internal system i.e. input of same data had to be entered into three different databases, all with their own separate nomenclature.
cons: Procedures are "good" for the company, but bad for individuals.  And the procedures are infinitely more important than an individual.  Salaries are below market rate.  Such a large organization has massive bureaucracy.  Working within my team was great, but to get anything done was an exercise in frustration, it was like the company punished us for trying to do our job.

review_title: They used to have credibility but those days are gone.
job_title: Advisory Software Engineer in Ottawa, ON
pros:
Flexible hours and ability to work from home.
I worked with some very intelligent and talented people. (Until they wised-up and found better employment.)
cons:
IBM is now a gigantic money-generating machine for its top executives and largest investors. Employees are treated like disposable parts. Relentless focus on earnings growths has broken the company.
Raises and bonuses are rare.
Low job security. Employees may be let go regardless of absolute job performance. (Hello stacked ranking)
Career advancement is difficult unless you don't mind being a spineless yes-man. They are looking for overseers,  not leaders.
Morale could not be lower.
The company likes to talk about innovation but rarely invests in it.
Demands, responsibilities, and obligations increase while teams are reduced and salaries stagnate.
Products are falling behind in technology and quality.
Excessive processes are used in lieu of common sense.

review_title: It's a mixed bag.
pros: Good benefits, lots of opportunity to learn new skills, matched 401K up to a certain percentage, looks good on a resume.
cons: Huge company, you feel like a number. Poor decisions have been made at employees' expense in the past five years in the quest for share price targets. Resources are a bit of a mess....while they exist, they are somewhat unorganized, and you either have to work within your network to find out how to go about certain things, or follow breadcrumb trails through intranet. Highly matrixed organization---people managers often have little to no interaction with you and gain insight as to your performance from others...highly subjective.

review_title: Pay is competitive, work environment is brutal
pros: You can move around in the company and get new experiences.  The pay is good.  Opportunities are good.  Can often times get training or certification through the company.  Can stay technical and continue to progress career or jump into mgmt
cons: Its not uncommon to work a 60 hour week.  The benefits keep eroding.  Layoffs are ongoing in my part of the business and it happens to really great skilled hardworking employees.

review_title: A good graduate job but 5 years was too long
pros: Global reach, Big clients and projects, some excellent people and opportunities
cons: Projects are over-sold and under-delivered to the point of embarrassment.  Internal processes are awful, and the tools (laptop, phone, software etc.) given to employees are outdated. The company constantly changes its structure causing mass confusion.  Bonus has been pitiful in recent years.  Line managers may have no connection to the employee whatsoever but yet are responsible for their end of year rating.  It is expected that consultants will travel 100% of their working lives, much of which could be avoided with sensible working practices and appropriate tooling.

review_title: A place to grow
pros:
1. Big brand that helps your CV stand out
2. IBM assigns a people manager (apart from the project manager)  who is solely responsible for your career growth. For fresh graduates who are new to the corporate, this can be really helpful as your always have a mentor ready for you.
3. Average age of the employees working at IBM when I joined the organization (2012) was around 40. So you get to interact with a lot of silver haired experienced industrialists. The helps to increase your knowledge.
cons:
1. Compensation benefits are poor along with a poor salary hike
2. The magnanimity of the company often confuses a new joiner. Making your presence felt in such a big organization often becomes tough and competitive be it for onsite opportunities or good rating.

review_title: Working at IBM
pros: One of the best things about IBM is all of the flexibility.  If you're a strong contributor, and are forward about what you want from the company, most managers will work with you to make your goals happen, but you have to spearhead this effort.  Additionally, there are many teams to switch to or between if you find yourself not liking your current role.
cons: You have to look out for yourself.  If you are not careful, many managers will work you WAY more than 40 hours a week, and the job can be very stressful.  Set clear limits about your hours, accessibility from home, etc.

review_title: New Employee
job_title: Anonymous Employee in San Francisco, CA
pros: I joined IBM three months ago and have had an exceptional experience coming in-board.   I've changed companies in Silicon Valley every few years so I have a good baseline for comparison.    I've found the people I'm working with to be eager for and open to new ideas on products and process.   It doesn't seem like the market appreciates the transformation taking hold at IBM and the opportunity with Cognitive technologies which makes it a great time to join the company
cons: There's still a lot of work to do to breakdown boundaries and drive speed but Ginni and her team really are out in front driving change.

review_title: Sum of All of the Parts Not Always Greater
job_title: Client Solutions Executive in London, England
pros: Great legacy and history of innovation. Ginny Rometty has a clear vision and is great at communicating it. Flexible working policy. Great benefits and compensation package. Lots of potential learning and career development opportunities
cons: 16 consecutive quarters of revenue decline makes for a pretty downbeat organisation and a 'middle management' that sucks any sense of fun out of a place.In today's world where agility, pace and passion will win, IBM struggles and feels outdated. As a result of all these things, the culture and values feel contradicted.

review_title: Sales
job_title: Sales Specialist in Little Rock, AR
pros: IBM has a heritage of being a technology leader and developing many amazing products.  In addition, IBM has traditionally been very supportive of its employees.
cons:

review_title: A challenging place to work in a challenging industry

pros: A very supportive organization that struggles with the challenges of being at the leading-edge of a still 'immature' industry (i.e. outsourcing). IBM works hard to keep up with both the constant change of technology that its clients are using and the technology needed to provide 'superior' outsourcing services. Management works hard to stay ahead of both its customers and its customers. Great opportunities are available for those working to be flexible and ready to turn their hand to anything. cons: Some dead weight in middle-management and the constant challenge of integrating the operations of new clients into the IBM Delivery Model.

review_title: Opportunities abound at start, but soon narrow.
pros: Great for software engineers and those with technical expertise. IBM offer a wide variety of platforms on which to work. Might be a great start for those looking to move on to other software companies.
cons: You always here about some great new technology IBM is working on in the mainstream media. However, the chance to get involved in such technologies is very difficult. The organisation is overly bureaucratic with obvious conflict between different parts of the business, stifling the ability to produce some great work. Externally, IBM appear a very modern organisation in which to work. However, once inside, it's clear that IBM is very outdated in it's processes and over-zealous bureaucracy.

review_title: Great brand, overall experiences have been fair,  but not stellar.

cons:
Very large company. It is hard to network. You have to take the initiative to met people and find growth opportunities. The company focuses on the bottom line too much and sometimes ignores it's people. 

Projects can be mundane and boring. Billing hours is a top priority, but this is typical at most consulting firms. Bonuses are small compared to competitors.

It is often times very difficult to balance getting your work done with creating a large enough network of co-workers to get the information that you need. Having a manager only a few levels above you that you will never see and most likely never speak to is not especially endearing for making a career at IBM.

review_title: Good for exploring different technologies

I always felt that I could find better job stability at a smaller company, but I could never find the vast assortment of technologies to work with that I find at IBM.  That's the main reason I like it.
cons: Mentioned in the previous section.

review_title: IBM Research is great but the rest of the company is dragging it down
job_title: Research Scientist in Yorktown Heights, NY
pros: If you are a Ph.D. and want to work in the industry but still be in touch with the academic work, IBM Research is one of the few places that can provide that opportunity. As a research staff member (typically only Ph.D.s are hired), you will be measured based on three things: 1. your project work and how much it contributed to the company in terms of cost savings, revenue impact, or other qualitative impact, or technological advances if you are lucky enough to be working on such things 2. patents you file, 3. papers you publish. Since IBM is a global company, the projects can come from many different industries and many different locations in the world. The Research division enjoys high respect within the company but much more so outside the company.
cons: IBM's obsession with pleasing the Wall Street brings about a short sighted view to its research policy and hence impacts its Research negatively. All parts of IBM unfortunately scramble to meet short term financial objectives and Research is very often called for help, which takes researchers away from their primary roles of inventing and innovating game changing technologies and methods. By definition, research means investing time and money in high risk high reward problems. For instance, Watson was developed over quite a few years with dozens of people involved. That is what it takes to create serious technologies. Watson team had the few lucky researchers. Unfortunately, many researchers find themselves in a situation where they are asked to help the other parts of IBM improve their bottom line. Since other parts of IBM provide research its funding, they have a lot of influence on defining research projects and therefore how researchers spend their time. Since they are hard pressed to meet their financial objectives, they tend to define projects that help their short term financial goals. Such projects are almost always less innovative and tend to have marginal value for the company. IBM researchers are very capable people. IBM hires the very best to its Research. However, under so much pressure to help IBM's bottom line and do it fast, it is hard for researchers to come up with earth shaking innovations, though they would be perfectly capable to do so if they were given some breathing room. There are still quite a few researchers who still get to work on really promising things but their numbers are quite small.

-good for your CV.
cons:
-unpaid overtime, 
-not really a competitive salary related to other companies in the area. 
-Really it depends on the team you are going to end up (most teams are only slovaks and speak just slovak), 
-you have to wait at least 2 years in order to participate in a project

review_title: IBM is a great company
pros: IBM has a number of projects and initiatives that you can take advantage of outside of your "day job."  They reward based on performance and that has always been a selling point.  I had a recent opportunity to participate in the Corporate Services Corp (CSC) program and travel to Senegal for a month to provide free consulting services.  I also had an opportunity several years ago to do a three month assignment in Hursley, England and work with my product's development team.  There are non-travel assignments as well that you participate in and the culture for innovation is very much encouraged.
cons: The down side of working for IBM is changing jobs.  It is sometimes very difficult to change jobs within IBM.

review_title: IBM
pros: Great and very fair company. Legacy of hundreds of years of innovation and market leadership. Highest patent filed year over years in last thirty plus years
cons: Top heavy. Slave of process.... always late to react. Missed opportunities to capture the marked in cloud, analytic. Hope cognitive pays rich dividend. Current culture in IBM is more you are away from client more authority you have and more money you make. Most business leaders in IBM spent more time in convincing internal CFO and COO than serving clients.

review_title: Growth
pros:
1 ) You can climb ladders if you are qualified and having good contacts.
2)  Employees are recognized by their hard work
3 ) Best company to settle down
4 ) Internal  movement is Transparent.
cons:
1 ) Big organization , Growth rate is low as Performance wont be visible to higher management. 
2 ) Recognition is only on papers , it wont reflect in financial terms.
3 ) Tenured resources are not rewarded even though they are critical to company's growth.

review_title: Sales
pros: Benefits plan is in line or better than industry standards.
cons:
- No direction in "strategic imperatives" (Software) that are suppose to drive growth.
- Continued playing of the shell game with alignment creates a poor environment for customers and for the sales force.  
- Aging internal systems and processes are a setback when compared to other smaller more agile companies.
- Management does not join you in the field and therefore is of little value.  Their job is solely to drive an accurate forecast.

review_title: Senior Application Consultant
job_title: Senior Applications Consultant in Toronto, ON
pros:
- Great people within the company
- Wealth of resources
- Flexible working environment
- High profile projects
cons:
- Lack of personal guidance (could be tough for a new hire)
- Often (99% of the time) detached from your direct manager. Performances are simply heard, not seen
- Complex and tedious promotion process. Often hindered by old-timers that believe in time over performance

review_title: Antiquated tools and processes
pros: Big company with lots of big and interesting clients
cons:
Payroll is the weirdest I’ve ever seen. You’re paid in advance on 6th of month because of something that happened in 1970
Leavers have to pay ibm back if they don’t leave on 5th of the month
If payday falls on a weekend or bank holiday it’s processed afterwards
Watch your tax. It’s not often correct.
Too many systems to have to keep updated - so much admin. And it’s on you, because this “innovative” tech company doesn’t have efficient systems
Too much focus on the number and not you
You are just a number - you even have a serial number!

review_title: Technical Services Manager
pros: You have flexibility and can always balance your personal and professional life. You have so many opportunities to grow technically and achieve your personal aspirations.
cons: Specially if you are part of IBM GTS then you very less visibility on the developments that are happening outside the IBM GTS. Your visibility is mostly restricted to the client's delivery. HR engagement is very less. Not easy to switch and jump into your dream roles or skills if there is a dependency on you in the current project. Annual appraisal process needs a lot of improvement.

review_title: Don't waste your time!!!
job_title: Summit Digital Sales Specialist in Dallas, TX
pros: Fortune 500 company on your resume, 6 months of travel and training
cons:
-No organization whatsoever in the digital rotation program, will stick you anywhere just because of headcount
-Out of the blue PAY CUTS. They are giving out significant pay cuts along with reducing benefits
-Management doesn't care. The premise of the rotation program was to find people job opportunities moving out but 80% of the people graduating from the program do not have placements and are essentially unemployed.

review_title: Sometimes, the US is ahead - and why it is different to work in Germany
pros: Top Notch technology and R&D, Best Patent performance for more than 10 years, great portfolio, great elearning and employability activities. Good long term strategy defined by Sam - but sometimes the translation into activities in offices outside the US does not clearly demonstrate where the company is headed.
cons: Bureaucratic, too many processes and stiff expense management sometimes keeping sales people to travel. Restructuring and change management is sometime kept as a top level managmeent initiative and taking employees onto that journey requires a closer knowledge of where the pain is. Discussions about chang ein pension, cut of salaris, unreachable targets does not add to the credibility of senior management.

review_title: Good place to start your career, get lots of training and build-up your core consulting skills.
job_title: Band-8 Senior Management Consultant in Philadelphia, PA
pros: IBM is a top Consulting brand that will look good on your resume. The training opportunities are plenty more than most other Consulting Firms. IBM and Accenture are two of the best Firms to build up your Core Consulting skills. IBM unlike Accenture has more over 40 year old Consultants, so it is a more mature Work-Life balanced culture than Accenture's Long hour Work-days and Spring-Break Weekends.
cons: IBM is too big to notice you as a person. I hate the Partner worshiping. The Coaching and Performance Reviewers just suck. The retirement and benefits package used to be good but they are being cut significantly.

review_title: Good benefits. Average compensation. Not a fun work environment.
job_title: Advisory Hardware Engineer in Austin, TX
pros: A lot of various kind of opportunities within the company. Can do well if you network well. They reward the best employees quite well. Good benefits.
cons: How well you play politics is more important for promotion than your performance. Management doesn't seem to care about employees. There is no sense of a strong company culture. I don't think employees have any pride in working for IBM anymore. Even as a full time employee you feel like a contractor. You know management has virtually no interest in trying to save your job

review_title: Quit managing in the short term
pros: Many opportunities if you want to travel.  Working directly for a client can be rewarding.
cons: Many opportunities, BUT you have to travel.  There is really no work-life balance.  If you are supporting commercial clients, the clients come first above everything else.  If you are in the I/T side of the business, you have no work-life balance.  The 100% expectation is to be "on the road".  Nothing else matters and there is no sympathy from exec management.  IBM has spun the media on this and it is beyond me why the covers do not get blown off on this issue.

review_title: IBM is great if you are not a US worker
job_title: Program Manager, Technology in Phoenix, AZ
pros: Work/life balance is great simply because many of us work from home.
cons: Salary and band promotions are rare regardless of your performance. There is no budget for outside training (classroom). Entire teams are being laid off and replaced with workers from a lower cost region. That is hardly necessary in order to remain competitive, especially for a company with huge profits. It's interesting that the executives making all the decisions still have their raises, bonuses and jobs.

review_title: Good company to work for with lots of opportunities
pros: Work Life Balance, Career Opportunities, Flexible Hours
cons: Getting to the right source for an answer. It is so large that at times it is impossible to get an answer!  It is important to get to know people that can help your career along within IBM.  Since it is such a large company you could get lost in the masses.

review_title: Not the place to be
job_title: Business Development Manager in New York, NY
pros: None that I can think of, management does not care about staff no matter what they say. Talk is chaep and so is IBM. No career coaching no performance reviews excpet once a year with is basically sign it or leave! Absolutely disgutsing everything is a fire drill and must be done right away at management discretion. Projects are mismanaged and the stuff always rolls down hill, partners never do anythign wrong and simply perform a fly by and expect everything to run smoothly. Comp plans are heavily weighted to partners and staff get the crumbs if anythign at all.
cons: Work you to the bone, pay you little and demand demand and demand

review_title: IBM, great place to work...if you absolutely must.
pros: The benefits packages were well above average, corporate discounts available to me as an employee were great, industry recognition of the IBM name.  Company match of the 401k
cons: The most senior managers only care about their stock options and their million dollar pay checks.  They couldn't care less about people and the impact of their decisions and policies on people.  The company is too large to have a feeling of belonging or camaraderie outside a few specific work groups.

review_title: It's still IBM.
job_title: Project Manager in Research Triangle Park, NC
pros: Good work/life balance.  Smart people on the technical side of IBM and IBM Microelectronics.
cons: It's IBM.  Not very responsive to the changing industry landscape.  Does things the IBM way, even if there's no market for the product/service and/or customer will not pay for it.

review_title: Was once a company that care about it's employees, but no longer is true.
pros: The "workers" still have faith in IBM even though management is trying to break that faith.  IBM has very flexible work policy.  Can pretty much work your own hours as long as you get your job done.  That's one of the things that 1st line managers still have control over.
cons: The erosion of benefits, retirement, salary, and off-shoring of jobs has taken a terrible toll on employee morale.  Having been around to see the days of management that cared about employees really breaks my heart to see what IBM has turned into.

review_title: IBM
job_title: Sales Specialist in San Francisco, CA
pros:
Autonomy
Brand Recognition
Competency of Peers
Technical Leadership
cons:
Overwhelming Processes
Sales Model/Sales Support is Challenging
Delivery Support of Sales is variable

review_title: Just another one of the many in the Washington area
pros: Name recognition on the resume, ability to use the "methods" and have hands on experience in a variety of activities, diverse client base, interesting projects
cons: Culture accepting of poor behavior if it means more revenue; cookbook type of consulting - have the rookie read the cookbook and he is now a subject matter expert; work-life balance is not there - the organization runs on billable hours and volunteers to manage it; utilization target and calculations are insane (eg, you can take vacation and training - but make up the hours...kind of like advanced comp time rather than real vacation)

review_title: To work at the leading company in the world is the best experience.
job_title: Payroll Practitioner in Quezon City, Quezon City
pros: The environment is good. Employee are treated fairly as possible, your manager at supervisor are so kind and very concern on what your doing and progress. Each team mate are supportive for every new hired person. The medical Package is Good,Including your dependent and partner. The learning progress is awesome, you can learn online via a seminar and in actual seminar for free. Have a refunded tuition for those taking up master's degree in college.
cons: For those in Fixed Term Hired. Don't expect to be in a regular position. Cause Fixed Term is a Fixed date of work.

review_title: Big company where to learn
pros:
IBM is a worldwide recognized company and as such is nice to have in your CV.
Furthermore there are countless opportunities to learn and be involved  with senior management in huge projects.
cons:
IBM is a cheap company paying very low salary and with no benefits at all.
Furthermore is a company which started many years ago to go offshore therefore it s almost impossible to find a job in a decent place.
The result of this policy is that there are many internal fights between the new centers located in cheap labor market such as Central Europe and old centers located in west Europe.

review_title: Constant worrying about layoffs
job_title: Staff Software Engineer in Poughkeepsie, NY
pros:
8% employee match 401k
True flex time
Work from home
cons:
Constantly worrying if you will be part of the next set of layoffs.  (I escaped it twice, but unable to the third time).
Poor bonus (2-4% on avg and was a consistent 2+ on reviews)
Expectation of every single employee to either patent, publish, or create a new innovation, every year.  Just not possible.

review_title: My experience in IBM till now is "AWESOME"
pros: IBM provides you many facilities which gives you flexibility to work according to your life. One of them is "Work From Home (In certain Conditions)".
cons: Although I see no such drawback, but there are some cons with every company. What I feel bad in my company is their Leave policies. At first, they looks good, but later u know that these are not as good as looks from far.

review_title: Employee friendly company with flexible working policy
pros:
1) Flexible Working hours
2) Flexible Work Location
3) Work from Home
4) Good Salary
5) Brand Name
6) You can chose your Own career path
7) Mentoring Policies
cons:
1) too much of a process ,even for a getting a simple stationery had to follow multiple processes
2) Slow Growth, Band progression is extremely difficult
3) Stringent policies when it comes to choosing a project 
4) Poor Infrastructure
5) You are on our Own, it will takes atleast two years to get used their Policies and work culture

review_title: Well Compensated Machine
pros: Very competative pay. Remote/WFH capabilities a definite plus. Great Intern bonus oppurtunities like lunches, tours, and dinners.
cons: You are treated like a piece of hardware. Using your ID# you are even refered to as hardware. Very impersonal. All meetings were teleconferences so I never met 95% of the people that I worked with on a day to day basis. Outsourced employees are integrated into every level of the business process, even if the language capabilites are not 100% on par for efficint work streams.

review_title: Great colleagues, well meaning, but selfish managment
pros: like being in any team contest, the colleagues that you work with daily on sales efforts, you come to admire and like being with, as you have a common goal: closing the sale, so you can make money and keep your job.
cons: some would say the total lack of an effective strategy from senior mgt to handle the onslaught of new sw acquisitions and integrate them into an effective sales plan.  However, I would say that the layer of sw sales mgt at a regional level is all about themselves, not about the field, all about how they can use you to make themselves look better.

review_title: Poor leadership vision and bad internal climate, good opportunities to grow technical skills
pros:
Outside North America, there is some job stability
A lot of opportunity to get technical experience and trainning, it's all there for you
Probably the best workplace to improve professional skills and move somewhere else - it's like a big school that pays you as long as you put up with it
cons:
Job-life balance promises are sort of a lie
Promotes brown-nosed yes-sayer who put up with anything, never the most competent
Bureaucracy everywhere
Pays below average

review_title: IBM Global Services DC, Czech Republic, Brno
job_title: Job In Service Management in Brno
pros:
Education - several possibilities to class-educations, certain certifications and unlimited online courses.
Internationality - over 80 nationalities in 4 buildings.
Work-life balance - better than in most companies that I know.
cons: Salary - the salaries are waaaay below the market average, it's hard to live on what they pay, all employees are struggeling to survive month by month, and due to this a lot of greatly skilled people are leaving to companies who might be less good and fulfilling but pay better.

review_title: Lots of smart people working on a LOT of hardware related stuff
pros: The company is dedicated to solving big problems and giving their employees the resources, time, and motivation to be creative and innovative. There is a lot of incentive to work on tough problems that nobody has worked on before.
cons: Projects can often get shelved without getting off the ground. It's easy to work on projects that don't go anywhere. There is a big focus on developing patent-able software, but there can be a lack of guidance in terms of what to work on.

review_title: Excellent company that I have worked.
pros:
I would also like to take back my earlier review I have written for IBM.
This is an excellent company. I have joined the company as a fresher and worked for 3 and half years.
After which I have worked in 2 other MNCs. Which are not comparable with IBM.The positives are:
- Excellent Work-life balance
- Less work stress
And many more which I cannot list here.
You will enjoy working at IBM. Finally one thing I feel is, "If you are not happy with this company, you will not be happy at any other company".
cons:
The major cons are, the company has so good work-life balance that you tend to get addicted to it. :)
You can always sacrifice few hundreds of salary for an excellent experience with this company.

review_title: Great for later career, not for fresh graduates
pros:
- Home office work - great when you have kids.
- Multicultural environment and very friendly people.
- Excellent if you already have working experience and need stable employment.
cons:
-You need to be very engaged, have skill and visibility to achieve real progress. You are just one of 450 000 employees unless proven otherwise. Definitely not a good career started for fresh graduates, who are eager to build their career fast but have no working experience and skills from field.
- Almost no real bonuses for standard employees.

review_title: A big maze to get things done
job_title: IT Specialist in El Salto, Jalisco
pros: If you find the right team and the right manager you'll love it.
cons:
Things move slowly and it is common to come across people / teams with a "not my problem" mentality.
There is no ownership of tasks.
Help Desk is poorly trained.
Volunteering can easily become a second job within a job.
There are many incompetent people that have no place working in IBM (I get asked how to use Excel a lot).
A lot of skill is also underused.

review_title: Started off great thirty years ago when employees were valued, over the years shareholders became more important.
pros: Ability to work from home which gives flexibility. It gives good training to students but as soon as they become really useful many leave as the company culture does not value long term employees.
cons: Has become expense driven with managements sole focus being on earnings per share. Product development is compromised as costs are ruthlessly slashed. People are seen as an unnecessary expense.

review_title: Good... but not great
job_title: Managing Strategy Consultant in Chicago, IL
pros: IBM does so many things you could potentially stay in the company your whole career and have 10 different job roles in 10 different areas of the business.
cons: IBM has aligned itself with a 2015 roadmap that's great for shareholders, but horrible for employees. Costs are continually being cut, resource actions are annual when they are not quarterly, and decisions are becoming less and less strategic and more and more tactical.

review_title: Fantastic technology and people, questionable strategy
pros: Access to leading technology, world class talent, many people have decades of experience. Great place to build a resume, write patents and learn. Great work life balance, lots of responsibility given to engineers. Huge company with many opportunities if you can find them.
cons: Change in business strategy to software and services has severely impacted the hardware group and it's ability to execute with questionable financial results. Challenging growth environment given hardware sales decline. Ancient buildings and offices.

review_title: Flailing a bit right now, but great people to work with....
job_title: ITS Client Executive in New York, NY
pros: You will be hard-pressed to find a more dedicated and smart group of peers to work with.  You'll work alongside some of the best and brightest.
cons: The leadership can be disappointing at times... more interested in their own careers than doing what's right by the business or our clients.  The benefits are not nearly as good as they used to be, and the compensation for quota employees is "managed" to make sure that no one is bringing home piles of money.  If you're on track to blow out your number, don't be surprised by a quota increase.

review_title: Cost Saving to the Extreme
pros: The brand name: oh wait, that's not considered a 'pro' on your CV/resume these days by recruiters!
cons:
Drive for low quality: a real "deliver a project and run" culture.
Teams operate in silos and inter-team communication is not motivated
Individual accounts operate in complete silo.
The stress of having to constantly justify your existence or face termination.
The most inhuman company I've ever worked for, and I've worked for lots. You are just a bean counter that cuts into profits in this organisation.

review_title: Advisory IT Architect
job_title: Advisory IT Architect in Toronto, ON
pros: Flexible work hours and work location, Great people to work with in the rank and file, excellent intellectual capital to draw on across the company.
cons: Extremely poor leadership, especially anywhere above second line managers, lack of vision, over paid executive level that are not give the proper incentives to do the right thing for the company or their customers. Lately, cost cutting excellent talent to prop up the stock. The majority of jobs are all overseas now (India, Brazil, Costa Rica, China).  Remaining Canadian talent are doing the work of multiple people that have been released.

review_title: IBM Intern
pros: Everything you are required to do is reasonable (they hired you because you can do it!) and everyone is willing to help you along the way. Being an intern, they try to expose you to more than where you work, pushing you to network and experience other places around IBM that you otherwise wouldn't with just your internship. Overall, wonderful place to be an intern even if its not something you learn you don't want to do.
cons: Currently the company is going through some reshaping, so the idea of opportunities is very vague. If you enjoy your job, being an intern makes you sad that this can't be your real position.

review_title: Run by Accountants
job_title: Human Resources Specialist in Dallas, TX
pros: Lots of learning ops if you like few classroom opportunities
cons:
Company spends billions on stock buybacks, but currently views employees ONLY as expense. The immediate response to bad news is always to cut employees or employee benefits.
Measurements all focus on revenue growth YTY, but we keep selling off huge units of the company - quickly doing what Lou Gerstner saved the company from in the 90s.   
If you're in a major market country, you're in constant risk of layoff.

review_title: Strong leadership, Career opportunities, Flexibility
pros: I worked at IBM for many years, with very intelligent, forward-thinking leaders. Pros include: Strong leadership; clear direction; career growth / opportunities, and work-life flexibility options (work at home; part-time schedule, leave of absence, etc).
cons: Depending on the position at IBM, it can be challenging to truly find work-life balance, due to the size and global nature of the business. Also, as a mobile employee there were not many networking events in my area (that I was aware of) that could bring mobile employees in similar functions together.

review_title: People make the Company great
job_title: IT Transition Manager in San Jose, San Jose
pros:
Good employee benefits.
Work Life balance
Outstanding learning resources for free, you put your own limits on how much you want to grow
cons:
-Bureaucratic as hell.
-Too much pressure is put on people doing the day to day operations with cuts happening with almost no attention on how they will hurt the client or the remaining guys.
-Salary increases have been on hold for the last couple of years, but hey, there is always billions on earnings.

review_title: Technological dinosaur
pros: Perfect place for unmotivated, mediocre people who want to do non-inspiring work from 9 to 5 five days a week. Others should run miles in the other direction.
cons:
Lengthy and unnecessarily complicated hiring process.
Crowded offices: noise, conflicts, lack of management.
Managers and HR staff completely deaf and blind to issues other than their own.
Never ending conference calls and meetings with nonsense topics and absolutely no results.
Yearly evaluation system ignoring one's own achievements but positioning people relative to random strangers.
Ridiculous office policies.
Flexible hours: you can start earlier and leave later if you want.
Humiliating firing process in March every year.

review_title: IBM's going down hill fast, Moral wise and career wise.
job_title: Advisory Software Engineer in Kirkland, WA
pros: Salary and Benifits. Being able to work from home is nice.
cons: The company lacks leadership, guidance under the current CEO. It's a fend for yourself type environment instead of a team building, help the last man standing type place. Managers only look out for themselves and don't create a cohesive team environment..

review_title: Finance Services Manager
pros:
It encourages to to have a good work life balance
It teaches you a lot about procedures and helps you to keep your mind open to new ways of working
It gives you good exposure since it is one of the top 5 companies in the world
cons:
Salary Compensation improvements and  professional growth in general are slow
Burocracy is all around and it requires time to see changes implemented in every aspect
Many employees have stayed in the same position all their lives and you don't breath enthusiasm and motivation in the company's environment.

review_title: Decent Company - I had a awful manager
pros:
- Excellent bonus structure
-  There are some very good people to work with
-  Executive MGMT was very accessible
-  I worked with a great product that their customers loved
cons:
- My particular manager was very closed off meaning that it was his way or the highway
- To many mandatory scheduled company meetings - 4 per week
-  They force you to travel 4 out of 5 days EVERY week - if you don't, you get chewed out 
-  Here is the breakdown - 
-   East VP - Great guy easy to work with/ no issues, 
-  West VP - will micromanage you to death and question everything you do
