review_title: IBM Brno experience
pros: Overtimes and night shift benefits were bigger than is requested by a local law. Notebook and homeoffice. Trainings and certifications. Possibility of being promoted. Clear working rules, lot of things were in good order comparing to other corporations.
cons: Fixed trainings offer, one cannot ask for training of his choice regardless it is related to his job. Not very good human relationship. Especially HR stuff is very unkind. Job was not very demanding and challenging, lot of routine work and paperwork even after I was promoted. Underaverage salary, good for freshly graduated people not for experienced professional. Trend to minimize payed overtimes. Missing newcomer adaptation program was source of troubles.

review_title: No Skill Mapping, clubbed with poor training and management
pros: The company seems promising in the initial phase, with adequate space to learn new skills via IBM Internal archives or on job training.
cons:
1.Poor Management 
2. Lack of subject expert 
3. No process set in place for skill mapping
4. Unaware functional managers 
5. Lack of bottom to top feedback
6. Nexus between a few managers leading to unhealthy atmosphere

review_title: IBM needs to stop changing and start listening to its people!
pros:
- Flexibility to work from home on Fridays 
- Ability to travel to "cool" cities sometimes depending on projects
cons:
- Org change 3 times already in my less than 2 years of time at IBM; very confusing
- Doesn't care about its people as much as it advertises; at the end of the day, you'll be guided into wherever there's needs, rather than your own desires 
- A huge gap between entry-level employees and middle management, which lead to misunderstandings and conflicts at times
- Middle management is basically comprised of white men with age of 40+

review_title: Placed in IBM during Campus Drive in my college
job_title: Assistant Systems Engineer (to Join After Completion of 8th SEM) in Bangalore
pros: My Dream Company ! Right now I can only tell about the recruitment process of IBM, as I am placed during my 7th semester. The process opted by the company for recruitment was at its best. Everything was on time. They were so punctual that I was highly impressed. The written test and interview both were of good levels. The management of the team which came to recruit us was enough to reflect the supportive, cooperative, friendly environment and work culture of the company.
cons: Sorry, as I told I am still to join IBM after completion of my 8th semester since I have been placed during the continuatiion of my 8th semester of Engineering. I can't write words for this field.

review_title: destructive performance review process, immoral and racist
pros: good to have on CV , opens doors, given high responsibility on projects, good insurance and pension plan.
cons: hardly much exposure to client (but it does depend on your role), absolutely soul destroying performance management process- it pushed my mental and physical well being to a breaking point, cut throat competition within the company with people backstabbing being quite common, racist because over 60% of people who were given PBC rating 3 were ethnic minorities, people sleep their way to navigate the politics (it is not unusual for consultants to sleep with APs or other senior managers on projects to get ahead)  , if you can't suck up to senior management constantly you will go nowhere, people DO NOT matter as you are as disposable a resource as tissue paper. I left over 2 years ago and the horrific period of my life at IBM still haunts me.

review_title: Working at IBM in turbulent times
job_title: Sales Representative in New York, NY
pros: Great technology and a world class brand name make selling at IBM easier as far as clients at least being able to talk to you. Innovative technologies like Watson, Quantum computing and BlockChain keep clients interested in talking with you
cons: IBM feels like an organization that tries to compete with start-ups, but with the administrative and middle management overhead of working for a government agency. Changes at a macro scale, affecting where people work, what territory they support and who their manager is, seem to change at least every 6 months, making it difficult to get settled with clients and make good commissions.

review_title: Big Machine
pros: Challenging and interesting projects. Some really great people to work with on project.
cons: I call it blue tape, because it is 3 times as long and 4 times as thick as red tape. It's unacceptable for a company of this size to not have unified time management, single sign on, and so many other examples of poor tooling and processes. They must be losing a fortune in wasted employee time and effort, but they don't really seem to care about the people delivering projects. Shareholder is key. Bonuses are embarrassing as a consequence, even for top performers. Long winded promotion process discourages progression and talent is leaving, fast.

review_title: Being Me Is Important!
job_title: Service Integration Leader Mobility Services in Philippine
pros: I am authentic to what I do. I show what I think is best without any hesitations. It gives me and my colleagues/Management the opportunity to create & experience diversity in all aspect. We have a vast array of support mechanism to help individual explore and be authentic of themselves. Being inclusive in IBM is powerful because it help us understand and find ways to better improve ourselves, processes and tools. I am so happy that I belong to IBM. This company is also my Family.
cons: In most Global Companies, we have such huge bureaucracy especially on the processes. However I can see big improvement that IBM is working on.

review_title: Employees are nobody
pros: 100% compensated sick leave, enless career opportunities if you're willing to rotate to a different sector every 2 years, great team mates
cons: employees are just numbers they can reduce enytime they want, but still expect the same deliverables, in many cases the expectations for those remainig are even higher then before. IBM produces many many burned-down people in thei early 30s. They are cancelling the one compelling benefit employees had - work from home, and there is nothing else people can be motivated to stay.  Salaries are terrible with minimal if even any prospect of salary increase unless you rotate to a different sector

review_title: Senior Manager Product Marketing
job_title: Anonymous Employee in San Francisco, CA
pros: Company has an amazing portfolio and talented engineers. The company is rapidly simplifying its internal processes, roadmap and leadership. They definitely have the lead in AI, Hybrid & Blockchain. Co-location was a good thing for culture and speed. Work life balance is good, and people are very respectful compared to most tech companies in the Bay Area.  I think they're on the right path to turning the company around quickly!
cons: None that I've noticed so far.

review_title: IBM - slow but steady win the race ?
pros: In IBM, processes are followed and there is no deviation to the process which gives an impression that no one is bigger than the inbuilt process. Also IBM is like an ocean so if a person has right skill sets he or she will be on high demand and never be out of projects.
cons:
Nepotism - It is the factory of nepotism and encourages employees to flatter their managers to get promotions.
Slow as rock - Things are very slow to move. As an e.g. it takes 3-4 months for a recruitment to materialise and it adopts technologies already started by other IT cos.
Performance is considered to be least important thing at the time of promotions.

review_title: Stay away from CIC
pros:
- IBM delivers good products and services.
- Are you 18 years or below 27 years then this is a good start to start
- Many assigments
cons:
- Avoid the Client Innovation Center (CIC). This department is not healthy. Many people leave because they are not happy. Developers think they are a lot, lie about others to get better themselves.  Managers do not dare to tell the truth about you and do not try to motivate you to get the best out of you. Many professionals have no assigments from time till time.
- Managers without management experience

review_title: Impression over a 20 year span
pros: Great people, products, and line managers.  Flexible work environment and facilities.
cons:
Little to no investment in legacy product line that still generated good revenue. 
Travel policies that did not take the into account the strain on the employee(Flying coach for 20 hours to  a customer engagement is bruta especially true if one is over 6 ft tall).
Bonus plan for employees in a non sales role almost non existent.  
To much customer interaction done via conference call instead of face to face.  
Preach agile but still takes to much time to get new product releases out the door.

review_title: Great opportunities, for both learning and solving client problems, and great culture.
job_title: Technical Sales in New York, NY
pros:
Lots of opportunities for learning.
Travel.
You have the freedom to do your job how you like. I've never been micromanaged, even in training.
All the managers and execs I've met have been great and very "on-the-ball". Even the ones who are considered "tougher" are still nice and fair, they just have high expectations for themselves and others, which is good.
Good to Great Pay.
cons:
If you don't like travel or flying, don't go into tech sales or sales here.
Some of the other new hires aren't "on-the-ball", use a lot of buzz words etc...... please don't be one of them.

review_title: Working in a best practices company will make you an on-going learner.
job_title: Talent Acquisition Partner in São Paulo, São Paulo
pros:
Honestly, what makes me love IBM is their best practices' characteristic. Over the 4 years working here, I've learned so much about business, process and the corporate world I can't imagine gathering so much knowledge elsewhere - definitely not in an university.
We're also a company that values diversity; we're always getting in touch with people from different backgrounds and that's the core of our strengths as a company.
Besides, it's so cool to know we are almost living in the future here, having so many patents and inserting edgy technology into the market. :)
cons: Of course being a best practices company comes with a lot of bureaucracy. So if hate processes, you're probably going to be a bit frustrated.

review_title: IBM = Work Life Balance
pros:
The Benefits are the most impressive in terms of non-monetary support with 401(k), Medical and Work-Life Balance.  Work Life Balance is the best reason at the moment for my high satisfaction.  I work from Home and at this point in my life and current job is a great match for high productivity and satisfaction.

As a matter of recognition and feedback, IBM allows more communication back to the employee and empowers the employee to provide input to how his job will benefit the company and support results to match that commitments.
cons: Large company and sometime its difficult to move between divisions.  However opportunities are available and its up to the employees to support this growth.

review_title: Life in a large organization
job_title: Systems Administrator in San Jose, CA
pros: It's a great place if your in your mid-life or later-life career. The environment is easy going. Fortunately my management is very much on the order of "give the employee goals and let them at it". This lack of micromanagement style is refreshing considering this is almost a 100 year old company.
cons: Everything is process and procedure. No authority to act in the best interest of the organization even though your judgement is trusted. You need to take the initiative and be assertive on issues. Covering your "ass" is very much in the culture, so beware. As an individual, it takes time to get used to this kind of place and the people who work here.

review_title: A good place to start, but not stay
job_title: Senior IT Specialist in Atlanta, GA
pros: Maybe a good place start if you get on a good project, but never a good place to stay. Management does not care about career growth or achievements, only what are you doing for me now and what I can get out of you in the future ... great work in the past is never remembered.
cons: Management is only concerned about one thing .. utilization. What the utilization is right now and what the 3 month forcast is. There is no long term planning or thoughts. They will have professionals sweeping floors if it helps their utilization. If you do not make your utilization target, you are out the door pretty quick.

review_title: Use caution but it's not too bad
pros:
Lot's of room to move around if you have to but with the lack of communication at times, it's hard to tell if you "need" to move.

Issues that directly affect your position are kept really close to the vest until after the fact. This makes deciding what to do prior to the "event" very hard to prepare for.
cons: You get lost in the shuffle and support for needed equipment is often denied or forgotten. It often takes several attempts to even get an up or down verdict. This is a VERY large ship and does not turn quickly. If you have a lot of patience, then this might work for you.

review_title: IBM and you - a bad marriage
job_title: Senior IT Specialist in Southampton, England
pros: Career Opportunities are great if you put in the hard work
cons:
High Performance Culture regarding salaries is, quite frankly, a lie.  10 years in the company and still grossly underpaid.  Don't stay in IBM too long - you have to leave to get a decent salary.
IBM is still a very arrogant company to work for.

review_title: Good opportunities, but significant infighting
job_title: Director of Marketing in Somers, NY
pros: Solid products and services you can believe in.  Wide variety of business units means lots of opportunity to learn.  Worldwide presence also provides many opportunities to experience other cultures and learn.
cons: The executives (and I was one so I know!) tend to spend most of their time infighting with each other.  They view their peers as competition, because they are so focused on their next job.  Sucking up pays off, giving an executive the honest news but perhaps not what they want to hear can kill your career.

review_title: If you need a big name to work for - IBM Rules
pros:
No.1 Global Business Consulting
Large Clients with lot of opportunities to grow with learning
Knowledge sharing is easy and great
Consulting Team at clients have good skill mix with experienced professionals and some new hires.
cons:
Large, huge, Not easy to get Noticed or Promoted
More paperwork to complete with PA and PBC rather than the work at client site
Promotions and compensation are based on the reporting manager who doesnt know what a consultant is doing - where it should be fro the client project manager or team lead.
Growth from one position to another will take atleast 10 yrs unless we kiss a**
To get a training - Is next to impossible when on a project

review_title: IBM is not a place where u can expect growth financial or vertical.
pros:
Good technical exposure
Good understanding of how business goes and what can be the impact of a error.
Good policies overall, as they are not governed by the Manager.
Good company to sit and enjoy...like if u want no growth or progress in life.
cons:
No HR
No Manager to talk to to, they are there just for name sake.
No importance to individual growth.
Complex processes and policies which u can only learn after making mistake.
Too big a organization to get your good work get noticed.
Too much politics ...which is supported by the manager and you need to have good links with the Team Lead/Manager in case u want leaves...or good/OK rating.

review_title: Used to be great, now ok
pros: Flexibility in work hours and locations depending on project, partially autonomous from IBM Corporate, casual work environment if not working on customer site
cons: Trending towards more offshoring, requiring more and more calls early in the morning or late at night. Moving away from s/w development and more towards delivery and project management of offshore resources. 44 billable hours required. Add another 2 or 3 hrs for administration, education, and giveback. With so much stress on billing you might as well do contract work and get those billable hours into your own pocket instead.

review_title: Feedback for IBM Daksh BPS
job_title: Assistant Manager Operations in Gurgaon, Haryana
pros: Tremendous job opportunities if you have the willingness to grow. You will get access to a lot of educational / learning sites.
cons: This feedback is specifically for IBM Daksh BPS and not IBM company as a whole. There is a lot of favoritism that goes behind the stage for promotions at Mid / Senior level positions and not much of transparency is exhibited. Employees are not  cared well - thre is not much of an employee satisfaction due to which productivity loss is in abundance.

review_title: IBM was a great company to work for but they have been moving more jobs overseas.
job_title: IT Project Manager in Bellevue, WA
pros:
Lots of good people working for the company
Lots of flexibility to work from home and to change jobs.
Good benefits.
cons:
Many employees were overworked.  
Many U.S. employees were being laidoff and their jobs given to IBM India employees, also to Brazil and Argentina.  
In the past few years I was considered the lucky one if I received a 2% raise. Some depts were given pay cuts.  
The PBC appraisal rating system needs to be scrapped.  I hated receiving a large list of PBC objectives from management that were outside of my control.

review_title: Good place to work
job_title: Senior IT Specialist in Charlotte, NC
pros: IBM treats you well, both in compensation and professional / technical education, while you are there. You will be offered continual challenges and are expected to make your own way.
cons: Surprisingly, IBM offers no job security, or stability, even for outstanding achievement. You are expected to make IBM successful, and your reward is in your paychack. There is no guarantee that your achievements will be considered during the continuous "musical chair" strategy IBM uses. Best advice - Get in, excel, and be prepared with an exit strategy.

review_title: Too much admin not enough work
pros:
Large company
Looks good on CV
Tools are well implemented e.g.. remote access
cons:
Work life balance doesn't exist for Managers in IBM.  Level 1 Managers are glorified admin people expected to run spreadsheets and statistics rather than spend time managing their staff.
IBM treat their staff as a number, no flexibility in their work conditions, if it doesn't fit policy then it is not allowed.

review_title: The Rochester COE is a Black Hole.
pros:
1.  Benefits - pretty decent, health and dental insurance you can get for free if you sign up for the basic plan.  401k match is up to 6% after you've been there 1 year.

2.  Flexibility -  Depending on how lenient your manager is (mine was) you can work from home if you're sick or out of town without taking any PTO.

3.  Co-workers -  Basically all of the FA's are 20-somethings, so you'll be able to work alongside some good people.  Then you can all go to lunch and talk about how stupid your job is.  True story.  Happened a lot.

4.  Good resume builder

5.  Ping-pong.
cons:
1.  Compensation - Starting salary is 40k with a sign-on bonus of $1,500..  Not bad for a recent college grad just starting out, I'll admit.  But don't expect to see a raise any time soon.  Or a bonus.  You'll likely see that same paycheck twice a month for years to come.

2.  On-the-Job Training - This was how I figured out IBM was a joke within the first couple weeks.  My previous manager told me on the first day, "you'll think we've never trained somebody in before."  He was right.  Although they offer training classes, these are basically a formality for all new hires.  These sad excuses for classes won't actually help you do your job.  The person I shared an office with basically taught me everything.

3.  Job Satisfaction - I worked some not-so-fun jobs through college.  I sold shoes, did janitorial work, cleaned horse stalls.  Even at $8-10 an hour, these jobs were still more enjoyable than being a Financial Analyst at IBM. 

4.  Cost-Cutting - This is my biggest problem with IBM as a company.  IBM actually just laid off about 1,200 employees from their US workforce in the week I wrote this review.  Some from the Rochester plant were included in this.  If you're thinking about starting a career at IBM by taking a financial analyst job, consider this:  From 2007 to 2011, the US IBM workforce has shrunk from 135,000 down to 98,000 employees.  They have been shipping these jobs overseas and will continue to do so because the labor is simply cheaper over there.  IBM could care less about their employees.  It's all about making the shareholders money, even if it means canning people that have been with the company for almost 30 years.

5.  Work-Loads - Although some of the work is being shipped overseas, a lot of this work is just being piled on to current employees' workloads.  Now I understand that the longer you stay with a company the more work you'll have to do, that's a given.  But along with that usually comes a pay increase.  As a Financial Analyst I guarantee you will be given more, and more, and more mind-numbing work to do.  And to thank you for your efforts, IBM will let you use their bathrooms.  Sweet deal, right?

This job does provide good finance experience for a recent college grad, but that's about it..  This isn't the place to build a career.  In my opinion, the entire COE will be shipped overseas in the next 5-10 years.

review_title: Great resume builder, flexible, extremely poor pay
job_title: Senior Financial Analyst in Rochester, MN
pros: Extremely flexible company, as long as you get your work done.  Opportunity to work in wide variety of areas to build professional experience.
cons: Pay is OK for entry level position, however as you progress in your career and take on additional responsibilities you might be lucky to get one promotion (8% raise). To put it another way you could work 20 hrs / week doing the bare minimum and get paid the same as a top performer who is working 60+ / week. There's no motivation to perform.

review_title: Amazing company to work for
pros:
Extremely vast portfolio; if you move from one business to another and keep doing it every 2 years, you will retire without fully knowing & exploring the company.

Ethical and very good business practices

Let's you take challenges and presents huge opportunities to work on, which you would not imagine anywhere else.
cons:
RED TAPE, RED TAPE and lastly RED TAPE! If 10 people are pushing you for a business deal, there are another 20 in line to question you why and why not to do the deal. Why is fine, but the way the processes are structured; the 20 hide behind them and say NO in the first go.

HR is actually administration. Manager is GOD.

review_title: GOOD
pros: One of the largest Global MNC
cons: Very Poor Growth rate(Personal opinion). Here Managers drive monopoly.

review_title: work flexibility is highly dependent on your manager
pros:
- Flexible work hours
- Company pride/reputation
- Opportunity for personal development
- Worldwide organization
- Connection to academia
cons:
Company policies on work flexibility are only as good as your manager's opinion of them
Salaries are lower than market
Large corporation means slower to adapt to new technologies
Benefits could be better
Little training for new managers/emerging leaders
Training has to be approved by your manager; you can't always take a course for interest to grow your career

review_title: I couldn't ask for a better place
job_title: Senior Managing Consultant in Armonk, NY
pros: Incredibly dynamic and engaging organization given it's size (we're not talking startup here). Opportunities for career development are abound and there is a lot of flexibility if you are willing to step up and drive your career.
cons: IBM has been a bit too focused on cost cutting which is hurting employees - salary raises, 401k contributions, IT equipment, etc. Most of those can be overcome with the right attitude and if you're a high performer you will still get the recognition (financially) that you deserve.

review_title: Started out great.. then went off a cliff
job_title: Senior Software Engineer and Architect in Austin, TX
pros:
When I first started working at IBM I worked with amazingly smart people who mentored and helped me grow professionally and academically.  I was allowed a flexible schedule to be able to continue going to school and finish my MSEE and start on my PhD.  

However, IBM began to pigeon hole me and would not allow me to do new work and I was stuck on a project that I wasn't able to get out of or attempt to correct some problems since it could slow down the rate at which new features were being added.
cons:
-Messing with benefits constantly
-Salaries are low
-Raises are non-existent
-Ability to move jobs within IBM is meager at best despite what they tell you

review_title: Dissatisfied Employees
job_title: Senior Software Engineer in Poughkeepsie, NY
pros: 4 consecutive years of record earnings, record profits, and record cash on hand.  Ability to work remotely can be very helpful.
cons: Recent management actions show a lack of concern for employees.  In spite of 4 years of record profits, layoffs continue, 50% of employees get no raise at all, health care benefits continue to decrease, retirement plan in place at time of hire was completely taken away, with 61% profit in our business sector in 2012 no bonus was paid because "we didn't meet the target".  Employee morale is the lowest I've seen in my 31 years with the company.  I literally have to buy my own pens and paper.

review_title: My experience with IBM was disappointing
job_title: Resource Deployment Manager in Chicago, IL
pros: Brilliant minds. Dedicated employees. Several positions allow home based offices.
cons: No raise for 10 years. No chance for advancement. Direct management and second level management had little power.  Zero budget for training or even work related expenses.

review_title: Great place for gaining experiences
pros:
The basic beliefs of Thomas J. Watson left great legacy and trained a generation of great IBMers.  Unfortuantely, it is fading away over the past 10-15 years.

The original basic beliefs are are:  

Respect for the Individual
 ===================
 Our basic belief is respect for the individual, for his rights and dignity. It follows from this principle that IBM should:
 1. Help each employee to develop his potential and make the best use of his abilities
 2. Pay and promote on merit
 3. Maintain two-way communications between manager and employee, with opportunity for a fair hearing and equitable settlement of disagreements.
cons: Lost focus on technology invention and innovation recent years

review_title: Tough Climate
pros: Lots of opportunities to learn new technologies. Education is pushed heavily, so if you want to learn the IBM product stack, you'll have the opportunity.
cons:
Where to start? The 2015 business plan is sucking the life out of employees. Raises are almost non-existant (even for top performers), as is any type of bonus payout. Resources consistently leave, and there is almost no headcount to replace (at least in most areas). The emphasis is driving EPS for stockholders, with little to no regard for the employee. 
IBM has been in business a long time, and I'm sure they will weather this storm, and at some point change strategy. But I don't see that happening in the next few years, which gives me no confidence in them as a current employer.

review_title: A decent company, albeit a shadow of what it once was.
job_title: Support Services Representative in Costa Mesa, CA
pros: Relative stability, some people still recognize the company. IBM still has great potential and depending on what division you work for experiences can vary greatly. There are opportunities to work anywhere in the world.
cons:
Once founded on the principle of respect for the individual, today it is just another shareholder pleasing mega corporation.

No promotional opportunities, workload increases with no pay increases, limited opportunities and low wages. Being a large company means change is very slow, many processes are obsolete.

review_title: No value on employees.
pros: There is a global work force and you get to meet people from other countries.   Working from home is possible.   Lots of custom tools and local support.  You get to share an office with another employee in your team.  You are not micro-managed and you might meet with your manager once a month.
cons: No real support for Hardware development from the CEO.    Open source of the Power Architecture to anyone shows that IBM is looking for someone else to build the hardware and IBM can just be a software company.

review_title: Professional growth until...
pros: You'll be involved in top notch projects and get a lot of experience that teaches you from the up and downs of the IT Industry. Clients are usually among the highest ranked in town which gives you also a lot of networking and visibility.
cons: It always depends on having a good project manager. Most of them are disastrous and the projects tend to become chaotic making you life miserable at certain points. There's also poor or non existent coaching or mentoring, you are on your own about career growth, especially if you are part of the subsidiary and not directly with IBM; in which case you're kind of a second class citizen.

review_title: Program management with broad set of complex business problems in a global setting
pros: Very rewarding and a great team of coworkers, great international exposure, broad business exposure and challenges with multiple lines of business, and multiple country legal requirements. Management recognition of high performance contributors.
cons: Working in a global deployment with teams in time zones that contribute to long hours in order to support the development and test teams. Weekend work, reduced personal growth as a result of cost cutting and job eliminations.

review_title: Dehumanizing
job_title: Senior Service Delivery Manager in Washington, DC
pros: Some of the people with whom I worked were pros for this organization - some of my peers, the technical line staff, and occasionally an executive who understands the balance of delivering well with ensuring overdelivery is avoided.  Executives take the manager's side on most manager-employee disputes.
cons: They offer very poor compensation vs. the market, and offer no consideration of work-life balance.  People at sub-executive levels literally live in fear of "resource actions" that are executed annually to move more resources offshore for a (currently) favorable price model.  Repositioning the truth to the customer to reflect internal changes in policy or strategy is commonplace.

review_title: IBM is in decline, management decisions are short-sighted and just focused on the next quarter.
pros: Flexible work schedules, ability to work from home for many positions, good pay, and interesting work
cons: IBM is in decline, management decisions are short-sighted and just focused on the next quarter.  Cost cutting and layoffs are common, and moral and motivation is very low.  The cost cutting and layoffs are damaging IBM's ability to remain competitive.  Raises and bonuses have been almost non-existent the last few years.

review_title: Don't get lost in the shuffle!
pros:
Instant brand recognition with customers - easy to get in the door
A wealth of support, development, and management resources available
Clearly defined career paths - management encouraged to help with this
cons:
It is easy to get lost in such a massive organization
Yearly review process is setup so that somebody on the team must get a low mark, regardless of work output
Very difficult to get raises - negotiate a salary you'll be happy with for a while

review_title: Designer
pros: If you end up on the right projects, you get interesting challenges and the chance to learn a lot about dealing with large cross-disciplinary teams and messy problems, and even as a recent graduate you can have a really big influence on major products—if you end up on the right projects. You work with some great people, and everyone is really friendly. The design studio (and by extension designers) currently have relatively strong political backing and a lot of pull within the company, so in some cases at least, you get to drive strategic discussions and sit at the table with product managers, dev leads, etc. A lot of big companies are trying to make design work for them right now, and IBM has one of the most serious efforts in this area, so you can learn a great deal about how it might work and how to go about helping an organization become more user focused. A lot of what determines your experience also depends on your attitude and expectations—if you look at challenges as something to learn from, you will learn—if you want an easy job where someone has already figured everything out... You will be disappointed.
cons: A lot of teams are quite dysfunctional, sometimes for reasons internal to the studio, but usually because of the widespread bureaucracy and politics within the broader company. Also, lot of people choose to work at IBM because they can hide in the vastness and get away with doing next to nothing, so mediocrity and lack of motivation are the norm outside of the design studio. A lot of people are completely out of touch with current trends in technology and design, at least as far as user interface stuff goes. Another downside is the fact that even within the studio, the real goal is just getting to a place where design best practices can be applied, not pushing the field of design forward. There is no need for real innovation or flair, just for applying techniques that were worked out ten years ago to problems defined years before that. While what IBM Design is doing can be quite exciting, there are a lot of exciting things happening at the intersection of design and technology right now, and a lot of them are much more exciting than IBM. Also, expect to be around a lot of people just out of college with little to no perspective.

review_title: Associate PArtner
pros: Very dynamic place with a flexible workplace environment. Is a big company and you can change a lot of different jobs even if you are always in the same company.
cons: Very burocratic in the day-by-day processes (you still need to use tape to put the receipts on a bigger paper sheet!) and internally is not the best of breed. Managers are not accountable for their decisions but they have only to execute. If numbers and budgets are not reached none learn from insuccess the only action is to get rid of some people to reduce costs.

review_title: OK Place To Work
pros: The pros are having a job to go to every day. There are so many nice people working there and they help whenever they can. Employees are encouraged to participate in a lot of community involvement and diversity is respected.
cons: No pay raises ever and they tend to pay under the national and local averages. Managers are not given head count to meet the growing demands of the business.

review_title: IBM GBS Consulting by Degrees (CbD) Program
pros:
- PEOPLE: you get to work with some of the greatest and brightest people if you're lucky. You'll get close to your start class and it'll feel like an extension of college. 
- PAY: if you went to a target school, then your pay is probably pretty good compared to your peers' starting salaries at PwC, EY, etc. (hey, that's how they trapped me here)
- TRAVEL PERKS: if you enjoy traveling, then you're in the right place to rack up miles and hotel points. You can also do alternate travel and fly somewhere else for the weekend, which is pretty nice.
cons:
Despite what the recruiters/interviewers tell you, IBM is NOT a management consulting company. Yes, we do talk to C-Suite, but only the CIO, and when we do, it's because we're either selling or implementing IBM products/solutions, not because we're trying to help you figure out why your company's profits are declining. 

Given the sales-driven and margin-driven nature of the company, here are some cons if you don't do your research thoroughly...

- MENIAL, MINDLESS WORK: as a CbDer, you're hired in to do PMO, testing, and note taking. People have this misconception that CbDers are their assistants, and will treat you as such, making you schedule meetings, book conference rooms, upload a document onto Box. There's no analytical or critical thinking required whatsoever, and definitely don't expect to be challenged. 
- LONG DURATION OF PROJECTS: IBM projects run longer than typical consulting firms, usually ranging from 6-9 months. Again, because they are mostly implementation-type work, you'll be doing the same thing (e.g. testing) the whole time. Don't expect that much exposure to different industries or types of projects. Your first project pretty much pigeon-holes you to do the same thing for the rest of your career, unless you really fight HARD to get onto something you want.
- LACK OF PROFESSIONAL DEVELOPMENT: in the CbD program, you have 3 mandatory trainings. They're a lot of fun, because you get to hang out with people in your start class. However, the stuff you learn is absolutely useless for your job. They hire a third party vendor to conduct these sessions. They teach you things like how to present better, but it's useless because you'll never be given an opportunity to present to anyone.
- CONSTANT REORG: there's been I think 3 (?) reorgs during the 2 years that I've worked here, both GBS-wide and CbD-specific. Despite IBM being an established corporation, the consulting arm is still relatively young (acquired from PwC a few years ago), so it almost feels as if we're going through the growing pains of a young company... just a general lack of clear direction and constantly shifting corporate strategy.
- LAYOFFS: during my time here, I've seen maybe 3 rounds of layoffs, which has affected people that were on my team, as well as people in my start class (yeah, THAT young). If you think you're immune from layoffs because you're a fresh college grad, think again. No one's safe here, and everyone's always on edge.
- OUTDATED INTERNAL TECHNOLOGIES: it's embarrassing how bad IBM internal technologies are being that we boast we're at the forefront of technology. Most tools employees use (expense system, travel booking system, lotus notes) SUCK. They haven't been refreshed since the 1990's and are extremely cumbersome to use.

cons: Poor compensation, compensation is not tied to performance, bonuses are poor, unclear promotion and compensation criteria.  In consulting, one of the advantages is supposed to the ability to be vendor neutral when recommending new systems for implementation.  However IBM tries to force IBM hardware and software to its consulting services clients rather than going with the best vendor for a particular situation.

4. You actually feel mental piece . Before experience point number "4" you please go and join  3 or 4 other company and resign those company and then join "IBM INDIA pvt ltd" then only you will realize the value of point "4"
cons:
1. Low hike (yearly )
2. People manager's are some times insane

review_title: Not a technology company any more
pros: A large company, with a range of opportunities operating in most countries of the world with a strong commitment to treating people equally.
cons: IBM has forgotten that behind each resource there's a person. They are walking away from existing lines of business with indecent haste and are crushing people in the process. No effort is made to bring the team along for the ride.

review_title: Lost Focus
pros: Multitude of opportunities, eclectic interest groups, broad geographical dispersion of jobs (where do you want to work?), work from home possibilities
cons: Company was more interested in diversity than shareholder value, being politically correct than increasing sales and profitability, cutting US workforce and outsourcing jobs than maximizing employee potential.  More than once I heard "this is not your father's IBM," and sadly, it was true.  Pay increases were nonexistent, even for top performers.  Advancement?  Forget it, especially if you were over 40.  Month-end focus?  Check.  Long-term focus?  Nope! Everything was built around Wall Street expectations, which were never met.  IBM is yesterday's company, not tomorrow's.

review_title: Too much downsizing
job_title: Staff Software Engineer in Markham, ON
pros: Great people who are very passionate about what they do and the products that they work on.  Easy to collaborate with peers.
cons: Work environment has become toxic with continual downsizing of great people.  Work-life balance has become a thing of the past as those left behind have to pick up responsibilities of those who have been let go.  Good performance does not seem to matter to those making the decisions - everyone is just a number to them.

review_title: A good place to learn B2B Marketing
pros:
- Accessibility to materials, data, information.
 - Good life/work balance.
 - Friendly and open minded colleagues.
 - International environment.
 - Business trips (occasionally).
 - Good place to develop your multitasking skills :))
 - Good employees are rewarded (not necessary with salary increase, but you will get Blue Thanks points to buy some things on them, or you will be recommended to go on a workshop in US or somewhere else, or you will be eventually promoted IF you really want it and you get involved in add big projects AND your manager knows about it)
cons: - It takes quite some time to establish a clear process, but this is more because too many people are involved (risk of working in big company)

review_title: IBM Software Sales
pros: Great breadth of products to sell, including cutting edge technologies such as Watson. Name recognition in all areas of information technology, with a 100+ year history of helping companies solve business problems with technology. Best of breed software products built through development and key acquisitions.
cons: Due to its size, IBM has challenges in changing to meet volatile market dynamics. At the individual client level, sales strategies are often driven by constantly changing compensation plans.

review_title: Mediocre in India, it's better than the Indian companies, but still unethical
pros:
Work from home
Employees are treated with respect (in terms of how people talk to you)
You get time to learn and improve your skills
Good work life balance.
Good amount of leaves.
A lot more ethical than Indian companies.
cons:
Perhaps the biggest penny pinching company among the bigger firms.
Movement across projects is hard to get.
Quality of work is average.
No free tea or coffee
No parking space or company infrastructure in spite of the fact that most employees work from home.
Internet speed at office is slower than a dial up.
Average pay, very low hikes, almost zero variable pay and bonuses.
3 months notice period only in India.

review_title: IBM Ireland
pros:
Tons of free training
Nice people to work with
Canteen quite ok
Health insurance (100 % for you and partner, 50% for a child)
Working from home
Pension higher than in other companies I worked before
cons:
Slow, bureaucratic...
Be prepared to receive at least 10 absolutely non-related and useless emails a day.
Lotus Notes (you would not believe how much pain this is until you are forced to use it)
Everything takes "ages" - no matter if it is software release, deployment planning, or career change. Things are not done promptly in IBM. 
Terrible location of IBM Campus (Damastown) - far from everywhere (unless you live in Blanchardstown)
Outdated office (open spaces looks really worn out - at least in Building 6 - Software group building)
You will be called "IBMer"...

review_title: Great big company, but maybe a little TOO big
pros: Competitive salary, flexibility, good work-life balance. If you have a good Manager (I did), you have a lot of autonomy.
cons:
Benefits while very good are also very pricy. You’d expect much lower premiums than you actually pay. 

If you work from home, there’s a reason it’s called “I’m By Myself”. Desktop support is a last resort when you have an issue. And you literally have a serial number. 

They fill your head with “so many opportunities!”, but the reality is that it’s just as difficult to move around in IBM as it is to get your foot in the door - you have to know someone.

review_title: Rich Product - Poor Management
job_title: Architect Advisor Bluemix in Dublin, Dublin
pros:
- Great Products 
- Great Work / Life balance (nobody cares about you so, it has its own advantages)
cons:
- Dublin IBM office is not a good place to work - if you want to work for IBM on business side (sales or tech sales), you need to be in-country (Germany, UK, France...). 
- no investment on resources - they prefer to let you go than increasing salaries. It is a cost center, revenues are attached to the country
- very poor managers skills (same reasons as above, dublin office does not have any attention, it is the poor parent of IBM compare to in-countries offices). I even had my manager making racial comments (on my nationality)
- no benefice - you have to pay for your private health insurance, no food, no coffee, very far from the city

review_title: Great people, good flexibility, highly bureaucratic
job_title: Digital and Social Lead in Austin, TX
pros: People, flexibility, work/life balance is pretty good in Austin (might be different in other markets), culture in Austin is really good, lots of opportunities to move around the company if you want to, salaries are pretty competitive, incredible paid family leave policies and good benefits and 401K match
cons: Heavily matrixed, highly bureaucratic and political. The "escalation" culture is a problem in many parts of the business leading to poor decision making and sub-par work because someone more senior demanded.  It is very challenging to get into senior leadership unless you're willing to participate in the politics. Success often means taking on 2-3 different jobs at a time. Bonuses are non-existent inside of marketing.

review_title: IBM -- It Could Be Better, but its not bad
pros: Smart people, challenging projects, name recognition of your company. It can be a fun place to be, and you see a lot of useful information that comes across the transom almost accidentally. If you hunt, you can find some info that just isn't available anyplace else.
cons: The smart people aren't always where you are, the challenging projects aren't, either.  There's a lot of grunt labor that has nothing to do with the stuff that generates the name recognition. Pay isn't very good unless you're a star. The sense is that senior management is running scared, and their paternal style doesn't allow them to frankly ask for help.  They do try, but only intermittantly.

review_title: Big Blue Is Not What It Used To Be
job_title: Staff Software Engineer in London, England
pros: You have very good job security and flexible work hours at IBM. My current manager permits me to work from home, which is terrific. Not all managers at IBM are like that, though.  I really like that there's a credit union on site. The fitness and recreation center is nice too.
cons: Red tape and bureaucracy are burdensome. The "climate" varies dramatically between departments and projects. It's really hard to stomach the fact that Sam "earned" a $40M bonus, and many of us have not had a raise in several years. There are internal hiring rules that prevent an employee in one division (SWG) to obtain a new position in another division (STG).

review_title: IBM - A Good Place to Work
job_title: Senior IT Architect in Philadelphia, PA
pros: IBM fully supports diversity in the workplace.  It has strong programs in place to promote women and minorities.  People managers are given wide latitude to deal with personnel problems and to work with their direct reports in resolving issues.
cons: It's very big.  Because of the number of people and the 'layers' required to manage an organization as big as IBM, it's sometimes difficult to find the right person to talk to.  It can be difficult to navigate through the processes to get assistance with issues related to work being performed for a client.

review_title: Great place to develop technical expertise
pros: Cutting edge innovative company that values its employees. Be ready to work very hard but be paid fairly for the work that you do. Great learning opportunities are available for all employees. Company values its position in the market and is constantly innovating in order to meet customer needs.
cons: Big company so implementing new ideas can be a tedious process. Work life balance is not great if you really want to get ahead. If you are not looking for speedy advancement, then good work life balance is possible. Some employees have been around for a many years and believe they are entitled to things because of their seniority. This can create problems for younger employees like myself.

review_title: Great innovation, decent benefits, fat upper management
pros: Great opportunity to move around during your career. Excellent education opportunities.  Great innovation with large dollars spent on R&D (#1 in patents for 15 years).  Decent benefits. Very flexible work hours. Working from home with budget for home office.
cons:
Off shoring, downsizing, forced moves, too much work per technical worker, bureaucracy abounds, fat upper management.  

Respect for the individual has declined, but all companies now days treat employees as an asset instead of a person, until you are not longer considered an asset , thus terminated.

review_title: IBM is a great place to work if you are patient
job_title: Senior Consultant in White Plains, NY
pros: Excellent learning opportunities and very supportive culture.  This company does a very good job of capturing knowledge and promoting continuous education.  Time and learning materials are provided to employees and you are given the freedom to direct your learning activities as you desire to reach your personal career goals.  If you like travel, learning and people then you will like this job
cons: bureaucratic advancement scheme and occasionally a lack of challenging work.  It can be difficult when you come off of a high paced project and don't immediately have a new project to begin.  This, however provides a good opportunity to support knowledge sharing and take some courses.

review_title: Good wages, good benefits with constant job insecurity.
job_title: Client Solutions Executive in Chicago, IL
pros: The work and working conditions are very reasonable for the wages paid. Work at home is a great incentive that actually improves productivity while increasing flexibility.  Managers generally allow for a great deal of autonomy and trust in their employees. The means and accommodations when traveling are comfortable (no Motel 6).  The opportunity for promotion and variety of profession is very good.
cons: Constant threat of "resource actions" that could cost you your job (annual occurrence). As with any large companies, the processes are so cumbersome as to cause business losses to competitors. IBM remains the most expensive provider or products and services, but they are likely to survive downturns when their customers need them.

review_title: Overworked and Under appreciated
pros: Great Global  Connections.  Leader in the forefront on green technology.  Professional coworkers.  Great for working from home or in mobile offices.
cons: The culture at IBM is to work all day everyday.  If you were to close your laptop and leave around 5ish you would  feel guilty.  Project Managers from other departments create additional work for the understaffed finance departments.    Professional movement up the ladder is bureaucratic at best and very tough to do deal with.

review_title: Trying to push Innovation inside IBM
pros: There were a lot of good reasons to join IBM in the past. Nowadays, it is limited and senior management is selecting managers not for their experience and originality, but to look similar to them, reducing opportunities for innovative people. The long-term performance seems to be guaranteed though.
cons: Lack of innovation, weakness of middle management, syndrome of "not invented here", too much US-centric despite its globally integrated enterprise strategy. Jobs in emerging countries are booming while decreasing in the US/Europe.

review_title: Overworked and Under appreciated
pros: Great Global  Connections.  Leader in the forefront on green technology.  Professional coworkers.  Great for working from home or in mobile offices.
cons: The culture at IBM is to work all day everyday.  If you were to close your laptop and leave around 5ish you would  feel guilty. review_title: Decent work environment
pros: IBM, as a brand, has been there for over 100 years now. As such, it has diversified into a lot of different industries. IBM Hyderabad is a wonderful location to work for. The work culture is good, stable working hours and flexibility, managers usually listen to what one has to say, and the work that is being done here is exciting to say the least.
cons: Very hard to get ahead in terms of career. Moving from a business unit to another is extremely difficult, and getting into higher echelons of management take forever.A lot of bureaucracy involved as well.

review_title: Mixed
job_title: Program Manager in New York, NY
pros:
+ smart colleagues
+ LOVED the working from home
+ good starting salary (but see below - they gave COL increases but raises weren't great)
+ tons of autonomy and challenges
+ lots of opportunities to transfer internally
+ Research group is great
+ client focus
cons:
- work being moved offshore -- constant threat of lay-off -- very unnerving
- managers are useless politicians
- employees below exec level (so, band 10 and under) treated like muppets
- senior mgmt detached & largely clueless
- mandatory rah-rah conferences in vegas 
- stay out of GBS!  they work consultants to death
- small salary increases

review_title: The "Roadmap" to Hell is Paved with Good Intentions
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Hopewell Junction, NY
pros: Lots of smart people.  A pretty good reputation across many industries and job roles.
cons: The 2015 Roadmap as published to Wall Street is driving stupid decision, after stupid decision, after stupid decision.  The top doesn't seem to notice or care that things are breaking everyday, with more and more consequences for those who remain.  It's like plugging holes in the dike when the rain is pouring down and every minute there is a new leak.  Eventually the dike breaks.

review_title: Learning about working on a international company
job_title: Security Compliance Coordinator in Buenos Aires
pros: You learn a lot, company politics, quality process, relate with people of different areas. You also discover the inside of a whole new world within that sometimes will help you to become a better worker.
cons: Working on a international company will show you that sometimes your effort is not enough. Corporate policies are not fair most of times and in most cases the people that are managing you will not help you out to become a better worker or guide you.

review_title: Flexible workplace but not the greatest pay or hours.
job_title: Advisory Hardware Engineer in Poughkeepsie, NY
pros: Pretty flexible work times, except if you have to work with ibmers overseas you have to use your personal hours, dinner/breakfast time to be on calls with different time zones. No personal time available anymore.  Work comes in waves.  When it's busy it's really stressful.  We are finally starting to hire some new hires and new blood into the company.  Still pretty top heavy and hard to move up.
cons: It seems like our budget for anything is smaller and smaller every year when we are reporting record profits. Healthcare benefits aren't great. A lot of out of pocket costs.  They are outsourcing a lot.

review_title: Not the Same IBM
job_title: Senior Technical Staff Member in Raleigh, NC
pros: The company is determined to increase shareholder value by reaching their 2015 goal.
cons:
They will do whatever it takes to get there. So much for respect for the individual as a basic belief.

I joined IBM 29 years ago as an engineer. At that time engineers were recognized as the core of the company. Now engineers are a seen as necessary, but are largely ignored by upper management. Management is now focused on  vague marketing slogans like cloud computing and smarter planet. Engineers are cut when the aggressive division goals are not met.

review_title: Great work-life balance, as a part of a great group of technology leaders
job_title: Software Team Leader in Tel Aviv-Yafo
pros:
- Leader of technology
- Encourage education and improve employees knowledge base
- Stable and "long term" approach
- Work-life balance
- Work with some of the best minds in the world
cons:
- Heavy and hard to make a change
- If you are not part of the IBM core business projects (which is something that change all the time, with the market) - you may find yourself in product that is being "dried out" that serves as a "money maker", with little innovation and risk taking
- Hard to leverage whole the "benefits" in this huge system (and there are ALOT) - in practice, geography matters, divisions matters - depends on where you are at, you will have different experience

review_title: Great learning opportunities, great people, but lots of bureaucracy and politics (expected for a company this big).
pros:
- Lots of great learning opportunities - good projects, roles, responsibilities
- Great people - everyone is very sharp, lots of very-experienced practitioners
- Friendly culture and chummy collegial atmosphere
- Very flexible work-life balance; can work remotely and at your own schedule
cons:
- Very difficult to get promoted - lots of bureaucratic processes required
- Large amount of politics at the high-levels, which rubs off the wrong way on all the rest of the employees
- No pay raises or bonuses
- Company is going through difficult times

review_title: Good Company, not highest pay
job_title: Online Commerce Consultant in Tampa, FL
pros: IBM is a great company, that provides top corporate benefits.  Very flexible with work/life balance, vacation, etc.  Working here will give you exposure to top solutions and innovations in industry
cons: Typically the pay scale/earning potential is lower here compared to smaller technology companies.  In addition, this environment creates complacency with the employee.  If they don't believe they will be rewarded then why go the extra mile.  In addition, large company that is changing direction in changing industry means regular resource actions resulting in many lay-offs.  Lay-offs happen that are not always based on Job Performance

review_title: A big, stodgy, mismanaged ship that's sinking
pros:
- Flexible work schedules and locations, work from home options, offices everywhere
- A big name company
- So big and poorly managed that you can coast while you look for a new job
cons:
Everything about IBM's software group is so backwards, behind the times, and inefficient - the leaders, the technology, how they work, etc. 

They only people who speak well about IBM are those who have been with the company since they were 22 and have pension plans waiting for them.  The positive reviews here on Glassdoor are all fake and from their HR department.

review_title: Keepin' it real...
pros: Got a chance to work with a company who is transitioning to a better future
cons:
Overworked, underpaid, and managment/leadership does not care about the contractors not the other IBMers that work underneath then

There is a glass ceiling for all races, genders, sexes, etc for EVERYONE to break through as far as advancing your career

No time given to take the IBM endorsed course that could give you the skills you need to advance

Many people hear your ideas, concerns, or suggestions but do not do anything to improve how the team functions as a whole (and when they do listen, they pass your ideas off as their own)

review_title: Human Centered Design at IBM
job_title: Human Factors Engineer in Portland, OR
pros: There are a lot of great reasons to like my team and position: I work 100% remotely and get to partner with people all over the world; my schedule is usually pretty flexible; I get to work on a variety of interesting projects; and I work with really smart and creative people and have learned a lot from them.
cons: Working 100% remotely can be a bit isolating, but the pros far outweigh the cons of this. Many positions are contract so if you're not comfortable with that, might be hard to get on with the company.

review_title: Flexible but not challenging
job_title: Advisory Software Engineer in Dublin, Dublin
pros: The environment is lively loads of projects, and they are now opening to use some of the latest technologies, the work from home is a very good benefit, especially if you're an expat.
cons: Some of the projects are stale, and the people working on some team are not the most talented, dependency on US is sometime affecting productivity, campus is far from city centre, so consider commuting options.. Meritocracy is shadowed by some sneakier ways to build your career.

review_title: HR Talent Sourcer
pros:
Friendly atmosphere, great team, informal workplace. 
Challenging work
Working hours are very flexible. 
Possibilities of education and following promotion in any business you choose.
cons:
The process of adaptation takes a while before you get access to all systems you need to do your job properly. 
Workload and level of stress are both pretty high.
Overtime is not paid. 
No traveling or food allowances. 
Internal communication can sometimes be a pain. 
IBM is very large company so it is hard to be heard and hard work sometimes may not be recognized.

review_title: Small cog in Antikythera mechanism
job_title: Senior IT Consultant in Washington, DC
pros:
-Brilliant people. 
-Diverse teams.
-Great happy hours.
-Job security (in Public Sector in DC).
-Best benefits in industry.
-Awesome work/life balance
cons:
-Government clients are morons, though I guess that why they need us.
-Management is doing its own thing, meaning not thinking about you.
-Bureaucratic assessment and promotion system is tedious and useless.
-Separate day-to-day manager and career manager (who you may meet once if you're lucky). 
--Guess which one is responsible for your promotions?
-Worst salary in industry.
-Working in government office because they are old and dreary (in Public Sector in DC).
-Working with out-dated technology  (in Public Sector in DC).

review_title: My Experience
job_title: IT Risk & Compliance Analyst in Chicago, IL
pros: You are allowed to work independently or as the member of a team with minimal supervision.
cons: Management is following the direction from above to reduce costs wherever possible.  Unfortunately, this does not align with the company publicly stated goals.  While the company states that customer satisfaction is top priority, key resources are stripped from account support teams and moved over to lower cost labor pools overseas. Service quality is reduced, overall morale is low, and many customers are supported by teams that have little or no understanding of the systems that they support.

review_title: Culture change
pros: Great place for early career learning, both on the job and company sponsored education. Lots of opportunity to grow responsibilities and your career. Somewhat flexible work arrangements have been ratcheted back recently, but lots of options still exist.
cons: Personnel management is terrible at middle and executive levels. All the focus is on business drivers / metrics, Too much pressure on short-term financial goals for personnel managers to spend time with employees.

review_title: Good experience
pros:
Great experience in getting know how big companies work.
Super talanted co-workers almost always ready to help.
Good work/study/life balance.
Good (or even great for some) opportinities to grow.
Good benefits like discounts for gym, some brands, etc.
Great culture.
cons:
Often interns are left without proper tasks. It makes work (doing nothing) extremely boring. As a result, one can't show his/her talents and doesn't get a full-time job offer.
Payments could be higher. Just a little bit.
Huge inter-company competition. This makes divisions not just compete for good, but hate each other.
All of the paperwork, and permissions, and approvals, and similar stuff steals a shedloads of time.
Big blue brother is watching you.

review_title: Growth through rotation and transformation
job_title: Global Procurement Leader in Raleigh, NC
pros:
- There are many exciting paths your career can take...there is no excuse to be bored!
- Leadership recognizes and values diversity.
- IBM is willing to invest in your skill development as long as you are too.
- While a lot is demanded of you as an employee, IBM is an empathetic company that recognizes the importance of work-life integration and balance.
cons:
- Because there is never a dull moment, you can wake up and 20 years have passed
- Transformation never stops at IBM, so catching your breath can be hard

review_title: IT Specialist
job_title: IT Specialist in New York, NY
pros: Great place to learn and be able to do whatever you like to do, you aquite on your own.
cons: You can give your heart out and company will not appreciate you, no holiday parties, no bonuses, people are all over the place, you totaly on your own.

review_title: IBM Transformation
pros: Its been a paradigm shift IBM has been going through, by aligning self, in response to fast changing market climate and client demand. Focus on Digital, Cognitive, Cloud and Automation has been at top.  Challenging but for sure IBM is on the right direction to capture growing market in these areas.
cons: One of the key challenging part would be how fast we can cross skill the existing employees in to these up coming area, so that we are ready to take up client demands in those space.

review_title: Big company, many opportunities, going through transformation
job_title: Business Transformation Consultant in Washington, DC
pros: IBM has a large amount of opportunities. The more you take advantage of them, the more you get back. I’ve found a large majority of the people to be extremely friendly. You also have the ability to build your career by the projects you work on and the people you network with.
cons: The company is so big and can be confusing at times. It’s currently going through a huge transformation and I don’t think the C-Level’s have a clear end goal in site. There’s a lot of bureaucracy. It leaves a lot of talent untapped.

review_title: Systems Administrator
job_title: Systems Administrator in Essex Junction, VT
pros: IBM is a great place to start a career.  Good benefits as well as work-life balance.
cons: Don't stay too long.  I didn't see much of an opportunity for professional development or upward mobility.  In 18 years I saw very few people who were able to move up in the organization beyond a band level. .  Training budgets were always minimal.  There was also an ever-present threat of being laid off .

review_title: Futuristic Research
pros:
The company has invested in futuristic research and looking ahead in terms of solutions that bring a great positive impact to the world.
So, you get to know and work on the latest technologies.
The plethora of learning modules are open to every employee to get upskilled.
It is in your hands if you want to make use of IBM as its a great enabler for intrapreneurs.
cons: Some of the processes are old and the folks who have been here for a long time has to change their mindset to be open. But we are seeing those changes happening, so its good progress

review_title: IBM-Best company to learn and grow your career
job_title: IT Applications Architect in Detroit, MI
pros:
IBM is a great company and another face of innovations which make impact on world. It is having great work culture, tremendous opportunities to learn on job as well as through digital offerings. You can choose the technology of your interest and excel into it. IBM provides great opportunities to work in all domains when you are ready to take the challenge. 
Provides great work life balance and you can reach out to great fellows in IBM who authored books which you used in your engineering education.
cons:
Compensation growth is slow, not at par with market.
Large organization so difficult to navigate through different business units.

review_title: Non-Trusted company that can't keep their own words

review_title: Experience completely depends on your department and division
job_title: Sales Enablement Manager in Research Triangle Park, NC
pros: Flexibility and very challenging work assignments in CIO organization.  Company has improved in many areas in the last few years making it more inviting to "junior" level workers.
