review_title: ho-hum
job_title: Advisory Software Engineer in San Jose, CA
pros: It's software technology and patent portfolio are impressive. At IBM you can work on software projects ranging from mainframes to PCs and the disciplines vary from firmware, operating system and compiler development. Development labs are scattered but multi site software development has been something that IBM has always embraced and known how to do. Being close to IBM Almaden was good as we could cross polinate with research and bring some of the research ideas into products, sometimes very successfully but other times not so. IBM seems to have its fingers in every pie and this was one of the reasons why it appealed to me to work there.
cons: Outsourcing threats. Building up teams outside of the United States in China and India.

review_title: IBM doesn't care about its workers
pros: Flexible work schedule and the ability to work at home.  Communication and technology surpasses most other companies.
cons: Sr Mgmt cares little about workers.  They are seen as dispensible.  IBM states they are fair in evaluations but then they put limits on the ratings employees can receive.  IBM is claiming they are leading the way in salaries but their marketing tool is that they are now bringing salaries up to the midpoint of industry standards.  In the end, it is shareholders that IBM cares about - not the workers.  Its a tough environment to excel compared to your peers while still balancing work life issues.

review_title: Working for IBM is a short term opportunity. When the company stops working for you - leave
pros: During my 10 years with IBM I was able to work on things that I would not have been able to do elsewhere. I also worked with some excellent colleagues.
cons: Money. I had positive feedback on my assignments, I did "giveback", I got on really well with the customers. I got nothing from them. I had no pay rise in my last five years with the company. I believe the last pay rise that I did get, was because I caught my manager lying to me, and he was embarrassed.

review_title: Dog eat dog workplace these days
job_title: Staff Software Developer in Markham, ON
pros: Flextime, flex workplace help with personal/work life balance.
cons: Annual ranking system can be oppressive, and ranking results seldom reflect the real contributions of "quieter" employees.   Solid performers who prefer to shun the limelight are frequently left lower in the rankings than they should, and this in turn can have negative repercussion on their salary levels and employment security.   Too many managers reward flash in the annual rankings, even unproductive flash, ahead of solid contributors working out of the spotlight.  Downsizing and threat of further downsizing is creating a culture of climbing over coworker's backs at any cost to stay ahead of the pack.

review_title: Great for resume building
pros: resume builder, experience, ability to learn from others.  The benefits are very good, hands down.  The 401k match is the best in the consulting industry.  You will be able to learn a great deal in a very short time frame
cons: very large, too bureaucratic, managers with poor people skills.  There are a good number of managers who are out to benefit themselves and no one else.  They get bonuses based on their staff utilization and meeting numbers.  Many IBM employees are just numbers to the staff.  Its all about who your manager is at IBM.  Bad manager = bad experience.  Good manager = good experience.

review_title: Flexibility, work life balance without competitive paid
job_title: Staff Software Engineer in San Jose, CA
pros: Flexibility and the work environment is very professional.  Everyone is willing to help one another and there are abundance or resource when needed from either peer or co-worker.  It has a large supporting network.
cons: The pay is not as competitive and advancement within the company is very minimal.  More over, there are many layers of redundancy in the company that can be eliminated.  Sometime it feels like too many management personnel running around asking for the same status.  It's like going in circle asking each other for the same status.  Bottom line, too many people asking for status and not enough people working on the actual problem.

review_title: Really not an MNC culture
pros:
1. Work from Home option
2. Broad spectrum of work opportunities
cons:
1. Culturally it is like any other Indian companies - Leaders do not give personal space to produce results, work is done on an adhoc basis, managers only delegate work, are not competent themselves, managers just want to hear "yes" to all work given
2. Company is worried only about billing.Utilization is the buzz-word.
3. No employee development/learning
4. HR is literally non-existent. Heard them only during induction into the company
5. Feedback mechanism on work done is done only during year end

review_title: On the decline
pros: One good thing about IBM is that you can move between jobs in different areas and get a lot of different experiences. With the poor economy this is harder than it used to be, but still is possible.
cons: Sales jobs are just terrible. The quotas are not reasonable and intense micromanagement. The sales management tools are just archaic and are not integrated so you have to enter the same data multiple times on a weekly basis.

review_title: The shell of a former great company
pros: Name recognition. IBM still has the name brand recognition and cachet cachet that goes with a technology company which certainly helps with resumes. The majority of the people working at the company are intelligent, trustworthy and competent.
cons: There is too much focus on expenses, awards are nonexistent, salary increases are a joke, and even performance pay is taking a hit to where you are slowly being trained to not expect any at all no matter how good of a job to do.

review_title: Big company with even bigger politics
job_title: Sales Manager in New York, NY
pros: IBM is a company struggling to find its identity.  It has purchased many companies over the past few years but it doesn't seem to know if it is a software or consulting company.  If you are a rep and get a good commercial territory you can make money.
cons: Very political.  If you are part of the insiders club, and are willing to be a yes man, then this is a good place to work.  Fly above the radar and have original thoughts and you will get your wings clipped, regardless of how smart or successful you are.

review_title: Management needs to learn to walk the talk
job_title: Customer Support Manager in Ottawa, ON
pros: Good salary. If you have a good manager opportunities are endless.  If you like to work at the same level for a long time and promote yourself well when speaking to senior management you will do well.
cons: IBM promotes a culture of good management and flexible work schedule but most often the demands of the role and the inexperience of the manager means a lot of extra hours and a dislike for requests for flexibility.

review_title: Interesting but mostly forgetful
pros:
You get to understand and work with a truly global team. All IBMers across the field are accessible via intranet.

One is somehow always proud to be an IBMer.
cons:
As with most large companies, lot of politics dominate the workplace. Promotions are given based less on merit and more on how well you know the manager.
The change of moving to a more interesting role within IBM is possible but extremely hard because of this red tape.

review_title: High pressure workload and expectation to use up weekends working without pay
job_title: Senior Software Engineer in Dublin, Dublin
pros:
Highly respected name
Good exposure to unusual management practices
Multicultural working environment
Ability to work from home when required
Flexible up to a point
Emphasis on innovation
cons:
Promotion esentially time served based rather than merit based
Lack of training
Too easy to get trapped in a muddy backwater without gaining transferrable skills
Mushroom management
Too hierachical, with multitude of managers with overlapping responsibility
Stupid cost controls, you can get a brand new laptop no problem, but forget getting a bag to put it in, or even a pen to write with.

review_title: Strong base of consultants, but lack of focus on individual is discouraging/pushing out some of the best staff.
pros: Large Clients; good place to learn fast; strong peer group
cons: slow decisions making; cumbersome internal processes; lots of politics and turf wars; inconsistent compensation policy

review_title: Enriching experience with lots of opportunities for learning.
job_title: Tier I Security Analyst in Hortolândia
pros:
Great place to meet people that can teach you a wide range of subjects.
Experience a highly process oriented work environment.
Oportunity to work with high end softwares and systems.
Oportunity to develop projects on your own, and develop them to help the company.
To see your efforts rewarded to you in a very professional manner, and exciting manner.
cons:
Burocracy sometimes is an issue.
High rotation inside the company.
Sometimes work/life balance can be an issue, but its rare.

review_title: Long working hours, poor management, under market average pay, good place to gain experience
pros:
Great chance to learn.
Stable workplace.
cons:
Extreme targets.
Very few positive motivators.
Low pay compared to same roles in different companies.
Direct management (1st line) has no power of decision and seem to be brainwashed.

review_title: Great work life balance. Slow to change
job_title: Senior Software Engineer (B7) in Dublin, Dublin
pros: The work life balance is great. You can organize your working times (within reasons) around your family/personal need. Working from home is accepted if the job gets done all the same.
cons:
The company counts every cent they spend. A part for the salary and the usual benefit (VHI, pension and so on) employees won't receive any other benefits. Sometimes even getting the essential (like a good chair or a monitor) requires lot of time and lot of pushing. 
The company is  huge and teams more often than not spread around the word, so you might end up being the only person in your office to be working on a given project. This does not facilitate good team behaviours and engagment.

review_title: mehh
pros:
Very good people that are a great joy to hang out with, especially in the graduate program. 
You have access to big clients and the stakes are quite high
cons:
Salary is way too low and you get very disappointing "bonuses and salary uplifts" even if you perform top. 
Bureaucracy and stratification kills every creativity or desire to do anything. No grassroots are truly empowered, unless they are grassroots organised as part of a top down strategy on a specific topic. 
Culture and management are completely outdated for a tech company.

review_title: Average Compensation & Benefit / Flexible Work Schedule / Bad CEO
job_title: Senior Managing Consultant in San Jose, CA
pros: IBM has flexible work schedule for consultants. You can work from any location. That is very productive.
cons: No incentive for the employees to work hard for the company. The yearly employee performance review/rating is based on your contributions to the company relative to other employees in your team. That does not make sense to me. My team had very strong results last year and all members in the team have  similar contributions, but under the current rating system, there is only a fixed percentage of members who can receive the exceptional rating, which is not fair in my opinion.

review_title: Average Compensation & Benefit / Flexible Work Schedule / Bad CEO

pros: IBM has flexible work schedule for consultants. You can work from any location. That is very productive.
cons: No incentive for the employees to work hard for the company. The yearly employee performance review/rating is based on your contributions to the company relative to other employees in your team. That does not make sense to me. review_title: Managements Concept is a round peg in a square hole... it just does not fit in the IT industry.
job_title: Technical Support Specialist in Dubuque, IA
pros: I really wish I had some... I have been around IT for decades and used to really respect IBM... they have lost their way and I dont think they can recover.
cons:
Horrible leadership
Micromanagement
Horrible hiring practices
Unskilled and untrainable personnel
Little to no promotion or raise potential
Dubuque site is just an slave labor sweat shop
High burnout and stress with no help or care from management
Good talent is constantly pushed away while the horrible people are promoted and allowed to keep doing a horrible job.

review_title: Excellent experience overall, but major changes over  last 5 years don't align with a productive business model.
pros: History of this company is exceptional. Training was excellent at the time of my transition in. Professional employees who are dedicated, competent  and personable. Workload fluctuates and expectations are relatively clear and communicated well in certain divisions.
cons: Values used to be strong and clear, but these have disintegrated and moral has diminished greatly. Individual employee value seems almost non-existent.

review_title: Good place to work and grow if you can build a good network
job_title: Senior Managing Consultant in San Jose, CA
pros: Working in a big company such as IBM can provide lot of opportunities and diverse roles to don. Your work can take you to different places and get you to meet diverse set of people. If you have joined the company with a good salary it can work out in your favor. The brand name can help you if you intend to switch in the future.
cons: As any big company it is extremely bureaucratic, so its absolutely necessary to build a strong impactful network if you want to get things done or even to grow. Bonuses are a joke. Growth can be painfully slow if you can't find your godfathers or godmothers in the company.

review_title: I had an amazing career at IBM in 2 countries and many technical and sales roles developing a broad set of skills.
job_title: IT Service Sales in London, England
pros: IBM has a lot to offer for individuals who are ambitious to develop their career. IBM adds most value and delivers the strongest in complex business opportunities and projects. It is offers a good range of perks like pension, car allowance etc.
cons: You have to look after yourself as that is expected by IBM who used to look after their employees when I started at IBM in 1984 much better.

review_title: A good company to start at and get experience to kick start a career.
job_title: Applications Development Specialist in Baton Rouge, LA
pros: The company pays for an excessive amount of training. The experience provided from working with the company is priceless.
cons: The company has issues keeping the employees on project due to many new hires having little to no experience. As well there is no room for growth and pay is below market average. Most stay for a year at the longest to get the experience and training. Managers have a hard time keeping qualified employees. Another issue is regardless if you work 40 hours a week or 500 hours a week you get paid the same. Some spend much of their time working getting paid little.

review_title: Proud to be a IBMer But worst salary growth & Indian management
pros: I have worked for 5+ Years at IBM. Proud to be an IBMer, give best feeling of working in such a great Brand Name (Specially glorious History). Really like its process Management.
cons: Even after 5+ Years, mgmt unable to present any customer side escalation. Every year Management have same excuse for not increasing salary "Project is not beneficial".  you can't feel like a MNC salary. Management think first or second line employees are fool as they do not have statistics.

review_title: Great Place to work
job_title: Global Systems Administrator in Winchester, NH
pros: This is a great place to work, there are many different things that you can get involved within and it has such potential for students who are looking for experience.
cons: You can very quickly be overcome with the amount of work that you take on, you must be careful and manage your time correctly. As there are so many options choose the primary ones you would find most helpful for your future career.

review_title: An awesome place to start (and proceed)
pros: Nice and dynamic work environment. Fair salary and decent work hours. A lot of effort is taken in employees personal and professional growth. You have the possibility to see a ton of different aspects of enterprise IT, since the company spectrum is very wide. Diversity end equity is addressed with a nice approach.
cons: You usually have to work with very articulate processes, so you have to be flexible to adapt to them (and not the other way around). Also sometimes corporate strategy guidelines are a little distant from the peculiarities of a specific country

review_title: Upper management is out of touch
pros: Work life balance is nice.  I travel alot in my free time and the hours are flexible to accomadate that.  Great teammates.  The job is fun.
cons: Upper management doesn't have a clue.  Keep laying off older experienced employees but don't hire anyone to replace them.  They also slashed bonuses this year while rewarding the CEO/board

review_title: Focus on keeping your current employees!
pros:
Innovative company, which is serious about it
Big chance, that your ideas will be listened to
Lots of education, lots of think to learn
cons: When you start on a low position, expect a low salary, which is not gonna raise. And in general, the salaries are rather low at the Client Innovation Centre, where I work. When I started, it was at a low ranking position with low salary. Then, it's really difficult, if not impossible, to get a raise. In contrast with that, people hired from the outside get a high salary immediately. This is NOT how you create loyalty!

review_title: Good place to work, but no room for advancement
pros: I worked in tech support in the Montreal office doing support for a large investment bank in the USA. The work environment was pretty good. It had a large open environment, with modern cubicles, and adjustable, standing desks. I had the option to work from home, which was great and I took advantage of that usually once a week. The team I worked with was great, and the team leader I had was fantastic. However, I was lucky, and other management I seen was terrible.
cons: No room for advancement. If I would have stayed at IBM, I would be doing tech support forever. Evening/Night shifts were sometimes required (but only occasionally as other team members opted to do it).

review_title: Letting go of Great Talent
job_title: Presales Technical Consultant in Hartford, CT
pros: flexibility, life/work balance, recognized name
cons: lack of loyalty, short sighted, unethical

review_title: Product line is half baked, direction of the company makes me concerned.
pros:
-Flexible work schedule
-Great benefits (health, 401k, adoption, maternity/paternity leave, health wellness incentive)
cons:
-The products are released and marketed as if it's ready to be used but that is rarely the case
-Too many similar tools are used and so it takes up a lot of time to figure out where to go for what 
-Management does not help provide actual career development. HR is reached through an employee service line; no real human contact

review_title: IBM only cares about the shareholder dividend and nothing else.
pros:
1. Some smart people at the lower levels. 
2. Work from home option.
cons:
1. Yearly layoffs for the last 15+ years. 
2. 1000's of US jobs moved to other countries for cost savings. 
3. No useful training. 
4. Upper management out of touch with day to day activities at lower levels. 
5. No value and respect for the employee. 
6. No respect for their customers. 
7. No innovation. 
8. If you think IBM is good place to work you have been fooled by them.

review_title: Great place to work
job_title: Release Manager-Project Manager in Dublin, OH
pros: Innovation, good work/life balance, good benefits, great, wonderful teammates. Watson has the potential to change the world.
cons:
IBM hasn't met their market targets for 20 quarters. Unfortunately, this results in IBM's continued need to lay off workers. 

Career opportunities used to be endless with IBM's remote work policy. However, IBM is moving to a collocation philosophy, which makes career moves within the company much more difficult.

review_title: Senior Associate Offering Manager
job_title: Senior Associate Offering Manager in Austin, TX
pros: 3 months training on Design Thinking is a great experience! You learned a lot about how to work with customers and teams to figure out the optimal buyer journey which is the greatest starting point of building a software solution. A lot of learning opportunities offered in the company.
cons: Be careful about the team you are joining. It varies a lot from team to team. Be careful about bureaucracy and old-management style of your manager. It might destroy your career there.

review_title: IBM 's  Review
pros: Huge Company, varies disciplines just like vast ocean of opportunities.
cons: Pay to the normal employees is pathetic, when informed to the higher management we get a common statement company has not performed well or IBM can't afford a good pay since it one of the biggest company with highest employment rate. So are you saying you bothered of the brand IBM but not of the brand value of the employees working in IBM?  Too many people in higher management for unnecessary roles

review_title: My 12 years tenure in IBM
pros:
1. Always being an employee friendly and never thought of switching after joined as fresh graduate hire from my university.
2.  If you want to lean any language/any technology, IBM is the right place you can think of. 
3. Policies are clear to every individual.
4.  Will get every opportunity to present yourself in larger group of technical forums, inside and outside of the company.
cons:
1. Pay structure always being a pain in IBM.
2.  that is the only challenge I can think off.

review_title: Technical Engineer (Mainframe)
pros:
Plenty of Opportunities to learn and grow within the organisation
Flexible working environment
cons:
Can't really think of too many - it all depends on the boss - if you have a good manager who is willing to let you learn and explore new opportunities within the company, nothing like it.
At an organisation level, its a huge company with plenty of tools and processes - which comes with its own set of challenges and opportunities.
IBM is always evolving!!

review_title: Technical Engineer (Mainframe)

review_title: DPE
job_title: Delivery Project Executive in Toronto, ON
pros: Recognized leader in the industry, innovative, and a global company. Working from home is an asset. I love my job and IBM allows me to manage my accounts while senior management is readily available to provide leadership if required.
cons: My job requires long hours (7/24 availability) to ensure customer support and satisfaction. On daily basis I have to put my work ahead of my personal life. IBM does not truly recognize and actually "expect" nothing less, nor does IBM compensate for breaching  work/life balance.

review_title: Great place to work in Guadalajara
pros: I love IBM for the flexibility that gives us, at least in my area. Here in Guadalajara is very uncommon to have a company where you can work from home very often, with flexible hours, many days of vacation, free transportation from the city and have a young environment in the workplace. That makes a lot of difference from my perspective.
cons:
The site is in the outskirts of Guadalajara, very close to the airport. And at least for the ones who drive is a very complicated route to get there, depending where you come from, but at least 40 min drive. 
Also, in the most mature areas is very complicated to keep growing unless someone retires, or leaves the company.

review_title: Not bad so far but lets see!!
job_title: Lead Generation Representative in Toronto, ON
pros: Big Name in the industry. Excellent place to learn. Excellent colleagues. Helpful at the job
cons: Bad salary, growth potential in the company is very low. Everybody seems to be judgemental. There is a lot of unsaid politics. baaahh baaah baahh baahh baahh. i am finding it hard to find the downsides yet as I have not been here for a long time but from the people - i am finding out that they pay you peanuts and dont really care much about your future. Lot of people quit the company before 2 years. I guess i've now completed my 100 words, lol

review_title: Good coworkers, bad upper management.
pros: Flexible hours are good.  Working from home allows this flexibility.  The people that are left are good, but overworked due to outsourcing.
cons: All technical jobs are headed to India.  First they "leaned" 50% out, then outsourced the rest to other countries, that cannot complete the job satisfactorily, which leads to more work for the competent here.  There no longer are company parties, where families are invited, limiting the "family" feeling you get when you are able to meet and learn others outside of work.

review_title: Communicate the real strategy
pros: Building competence and technical skills. Ability to work in a global enviroment. Skilled co-workers. Great name in the industry that open doors. Stay for a while and leave when you built network and skills. IBM Background will give you a good foundation to look for new opportunites in the industri.
cons: Processes, overstated targets that allows only senior management to overachive. Compensation only for senior management including a large fleet of jets for the invited elite. Fear of doing something wrong drives most employees and managers. interest in doing something different do not exist as this will cause a risk to get fired.

review_title: IBM: Innovative firm that provides significant growth opportunity for driven individual.
pros: IBM is an innovation driven firm, focused on sustainable growth and the continuous evaluation and development at the enterprise, brand and employee levels.  IBM provides extremely competitive health care and 401(k) benefits, a mentoring program and substantial training and development opportunities.  There are ample career paths to choose from at IBM.  At IBM you are provided the tools to make your career your own.
cons: As a member of a extremely large company it is easy to feel as only a number.  While there are ample career paths, it can be challenging to navigate to a significantly different career path.  The salary compensation appears to be average.

review_title: Great company going to waste
pros:
Looks good on the resume
Some very talented people work at this company
Tremendous resources that can be brought to bear - financial, talenetd people, geographic reach, technology
cons:
Old boy network - very hard to break into
Consulting business model is broken - billable utilization target is 95%!!
In GBS people are commodities to be hired out on ANY project irrespecive of whether or not it fits your skills and interests
In GBS salaries are usually lower than the market
Most leaders are rewarded based solely on business generated - no incentive to look after their people or invest in innovation

review_title: Big Blue
job_title: Hardware Engineer in East Fishkill, NY
pros: There are smart, technical, helpful, and hard-working engineers working on cool, challenging assignments.  An open environment to try out new ideas and methods all in the name of getting the latest products out on time.  Good team atmosphere.  Good pcs and technology.  Flexible with working from home.
cons: At IBM, as in hardware companies in general, we are being asked to make more and more complex products with less and less resources/people (due to computers (vs. cars, milk, and most other products) becoming cheaper with each passing year).  Technical leaders are not promoted as often or as high as managers, in most areas.

review_title: The downside of working as a consultant for a big company
pros: I still work for IBM because I like the project and the client that I am working for. The location is perfect and I have been working with this client for the past couple of years. I have considered looking for another job but the timing is not right.
cons:
Employee manger is located some where else and there is no direct communication.
Manager is the one who decide on promotion and bonus even though he does not work directly with the employee. Reimbursement for tuition is very hard.

review_title: Not a demanding job, but has its headaches
job_title: Software Engineering Manager in Chapel Hill, NC
pros:
Lots of opportunities for doing completely different work
Great flexibility -- in where and when work is done, allows easy work/life balance
Supportive direct management
Great tools to get work done remotely
Decent salary, benefits and bonuses
Good recognition for high achievers in the right part of the business.
cons:
Clueless senior management
Too much deadwood in employees and management
No clear direction for the future
Big raises are no longer available
Can get stuck in poor performing businesses and be at risk for losing job through no fault of your own

review_title: If you like to work 16 hours a day, sign up
job_title: Sales Specialist in New York, NY
pros: If you can find time between the very long hours in sales, you can try to stay current with technology. The people you work with are all top notch, A team.
cons: Very long hours. When you get home, you log right back on to do hours of email, conference calls, and adminstrivia. The level of inspection on each deal is absurd. The quotas are not attainable, just set high to control your earnings. Extreme pressure to make monthly goals. Administrative systems to track your attainment has been grossly inaccurate for years. This is handled out of Brazil, making it nearly impossible to rectify errors.

review_title: It is easy to get lost in the shuffle at IBM.
pros: There are some great benefits (health, vision, dental) at IBM.  People come from all sorts of backgrounds and it lends to a nice experience in diversity.
cons: Opportunity for growth seems very limited, as the company is so large.  This leads to certain managers playing favorites.  It is easy to get lost in the shuffle.

review_title: IBM is a big body shop, not really an ISV. Not a good place for a Software Engineer...
pros:
- Some of the projects can be very interesting, as a developper.
- Innovation is very much encouraged.
- Management is quite flexible about tools and processes used for development.
cons:
- Competition among people in the same team, no team spirit possible
- Technical expertise is completely ignored.  You'd better be a good talker and in front of the customers rather than a good developper actually producing something.
- Career is something that's very much talked about, but not much is done.  And nothing is done wrt to technical expertise.

review_title: Work with very smart people on cool projects
pros:
Work with some of the most talented people in the scientific research community.
Great place for research -- good balance between academic and industrial research.
Opportunities to work on some cutting-edge research projects.
Encourage publishing in conferences/journals and development as a scientist.
Pay well compared with other companies for a similar position.
cons:
Too much bureaucracy, and too much paperwork for everything.
Despite the high stock value for IBM, none of that seems to make it to the employees.
Hiring freezes and restrictions on travel spending every so often -- higher ups don't seem to be managing the budget very well.

review_title: Great benefits and pay but no work/life balance, long hours, profit driven at expense of employees
job_title: Technical Service Professor in Omaha, NE
pros:
Salary and benefits are competitive
People I worked with were some of the best
Lots of interesting and challenging work
cons:
Company always trying to streamline work and become more efficient, this always resulted in more work with less people and longer hours.
A lot of hard work put into standardizing processes which results into easy migration of the work overseas.

review_title: Great experience with lots of challenging projects and great colleagues.
job_title: Advisory IT Architect in Toronto, ON
pros:
-flexible work environment with the ability to work from any office in the city and from home
-Ability to work with leading edge technologies
-opportunities for career growth and learning
cons:
-Very bureaucratic organization with processes for everything including promotion eligibility
-Career growth is what you make it, need to look for good opportunities as managers often cant see outside their immediate area
-compensation is low compared to rest of industry
-Bonus is tiny and yearly salary adjustment is low since the 2009 recession, under 2%

review_title: IBM Global Services
pros: Exposure to large commercial accounts. Employee stock purchase plan. Access to education classes, materials and certifications. Work from home. Partnerships with other large companies provide for good networking.
cons: Opportunities for advancement are limited in some positions due to a tendency to pigeonhole employees in current role from lack of availability of trained resources to assume responsibilities. Extreme cost cutting measures especially in Q4 limiting education, travel and hiring. Many layers of management to navigate. Distribution of work across global regions slows down delivery of projects. Salaries below market value. Recent 401k changes are viewed as unfavorable to employees. Overall low morale.

review_title: Hard work, occasionally rewarding,for a Co. that seems wedded to using what worked in the 80s to drive excellence today.
job_title: Senior Project Manager in Pasadena, CA
pros: - Left Brain: 'Performance-based culture': you can rise quickly and gain access to top people and a great many resources when you have success...
cons: - Right Brain: 'Performance-based culture': perform within the confines of a near-soulless formal organization, working with, but also to best your valued co-workers who are similarly numb - so that you can continue to do what you do...

review_title: Fantastic people but people are "costs" not assets
pros: There are few better places to learn than in IBM where you will be surrounded by excellent people.  Also, the company is so vast that there are opportunities everywhere so you could stay in IBM for your whole career and end up with a varied CV at the same time.
cons: IBM is great because of the fantastic people but those same people are now only seen as costs; the focus is on profit margin at the expense of all else.  Also, while IBM is full of internal opportunities, many of these come with no financial remuneration.

review_title: Fantastic people but people are "costs" not assets

cons: IBM is great because of the fantastic people but those same people are now only seen as costs; the focus is on profit margin at the expense of all else.  Also, while IBM is full of internal opportunities, many of these come with no financial remuneration.

review_title: Digital Sales Summit Program Review
pros:
Training effectiveness: IBM commits 6-9 months of devoted training time to new hires for their sales roles if you are an coming out of school, and 3 months for experienced hires. It is a wealth of knowledge and their is a lot of development that you receive through this program.

Mentorship: This really boils down to personal experience, but not for a lack of availability. The people here are definitely open to be mentors during your time at IBM, and they will continue to work with you if you show initiative during your time.

How Summits are treated: It is really nice to come to work and have a big group of other summit hires that you work alongside (this may be different depending on where you work). They provide you with enough resources to succeed, and continually try to improve the experience. 

Shadowing experiences: This is up to you. It is highly encouraged for you to reach out to other IBMers. IBMers will be open to this, for the most part. They are very valuable because IBM is such a large company. There are tons of shadowing opportunities that can lead to opportunities or a deeper level of understanding.

Sales training & curriculum: This is very extensive. They have 6-9 months of training about sales methodology, IBM products, IBM processes, and building a strong foundation of knowledge. You will get what you put into the experience. 

Hands-on (in-field) experience: The training gives you experience in around 20 client conversations with sales advisors (IBM employees who were very successful salers). They believe that you learn by doing, and this environment is conducive to a less-pressured approach to just learn, and succeed when you do go on quota.

Quality of peer group: There are tons of smart, hard-working, and very nice employees. For me, the people that I work with are great. They challenge me and do so positively.

Interview: I spoke with an IBM representative at a college networking event, completed a phone interview, and attended a hiring event that gave more information about IBM, included 4 interviews, and a team presentation. I was given an offer a month later.

Community culture: IBM is changing a lot. Before really understanding IBM, I had a skewed view of the culture. It is a great culture for me: collaborative, hard-working, and generally trying to improve as people.
cons:
Training effectiveness: This program is really tailored to client-facing sellers. There is a gap in training for digital sellers. There is training that is supplemental for digital sellers, but it can be improved to greater address learning gaps.

Mentorship: None.

How Summits are treated: Some sellers will be hired directly onto teams. Others will need to get the job at IBM, and then they will need to connect with a team to work for after training. It is a little frustrating to think about and act on, but is definitely good practice to connect with a lot of other people at IBM.

Shadowing experiences: If you ask, you can find good experiences, but you have to provide value if you can. 

Sales training & curriculum: N/A.

Hands-on (in-field) experience: It would be nice to have set in-field experience, but this really depends on the teams which is why it isn't scheduled as part of the official training.

Quality of peer group: Some may not enjoy or click with their group. There are a lot of people that work at IBM.

Teaching team: N/A

Management style and effectiveness: There may be some micro-managing, but it depends on your team and manager.

Interview: It was frustrating in terms of timeline. They would not be very good at communicating what was happening. I received duplicate messages from different people, and some logistical conflicts. I suggest being proactive about reaching out to your contacts to confirm next steps, follow up, and stay top-of-mind for the recruiters. I wouldn't just bother them, but show them that you are committed and able to provide value by reiterating your fit at IBM. It was also a very rigorous process during the hiring process.

Community culture: A lot of working here is learning how to find and work with people internally. Some sellers may not want to share information because they will be worried about you taking over the client relationship or it is not worth their time to help you with a deal. I say this because working here has another layer of learning how to be effective internally.

review_title: If you like Westeros and the struggle for the Iron Throne
pros:
You are surrounded and part of a community of some of the smartest people on the planet and the scale of what you work on is global.
You can feel like you are part of something bigger than yourself.
Lots of opportunities for global travel and team building across multiple cultures.
Name brand cachet for mom and dad (and grandma and grandpa).
Your work might be around for an eternity (in software years).
Your coworkers will stimulate you and you will be inspired by what they create.
If you like big complicated problems that require systems level thinking, this could be for you.
If you want and are able to travel a lot (and have experience schmoozing with clients) this can be a really great place.
If you want to learn (by doing) about how to persuade and lead people without authority, this could be a place for you. 
If you are a power networker, this could be the place for you.
If you think winning means everyone else has to lose, this could be for you. 
If you enjoy an always on environment, this could be for you.
If you manage to stick around, you will probably advance through attrition.
cons:
One of the Senior Vice President's children summed it up succinctly after interning at IBM for a summer: "What a soul sucking place, Dad."

Politics reigns supreme here and you must constantly flatter people whom you don't respect (if you want to advance). You will also be the pawn in multiple Director's, VP's, and GM's power games to further their own agenda and sphere of influence. Favoritism and Cliques abound and you must devote time to making sure you do not become the next target of their attention (or worse, start a witch-hunt against someone else to provide cover). 

At times you will feel like you have been assimilated by the Borg.

This is a stack ranked environment (despite the new system) where managers are forced to pick losers, even in stellar teams. And yet, Leadership isn't held accountable for failures, because goals change so quickly, or are never decided, that it is impossible for them to fail (on paper). 
Leadership constantly makes the sure bet, and follows the leader (over radical and risky innovation), yet excoriates the ground level employees for the results of such decisions. All innovation happens through acquisition.

The ratio of time spent coordinating and selling yourself and the work you did is almost one to one to actually doing work. You could even do no 'work', if you are good at fabricating stories and narratives that management, or analysts want to hear.

The list goes on and on with every Dilbert scenario you can imagine to some degree.

review_title: CbD Program is not what you think...
pros: IBM is very flexible. Working from home is great.
cons: The CbD program flaunts itself as some kind of recent graduate mutually beneficial training program to groom you to be a consultant, but don't let that fool you. I remember when I first started, I came here to glassdoor to check the reviews and I found one where the reviewer was talking about being laid off. He said "Dont be fooled, you can be laid off just like everyone else!" I talked to one of my peers about it and they said that does not happen to CbD'ers as long as your trying really hard to get staffed, which I was trying my absolute hardest. The problem is IBM hired way to many resources. There were hundreds of recent grads like me trying to find projects. Sure enough, a year later it happened to me too. They tell you that they will find you projects to work on and that you only need to put in a little effort to find them, but the truth is you are competing with everyone around you for projects, and they (Management) dont do much of anything to help you. If you go to long without a project, they will fire you. Yes, I said fire you, because they make it seem like your getting "laid off" but from a HR standpoint, you are being fired, which means your next employer will know about it. They not only not "launched my career", but they actually significantly damaged my reputation in the working world.  Many IBM Managers still have this manage by fear mentality also and a very serious fraternal style attitude where the newer consultants are treated like were worthless.

review_title: New Hire Starting Soon
job_title: User Experience Designer in Littleton, MA
pros:
I applied online in early June and received initial contact from the hiring manager in early July.  The first phone interview was with the hiring manager.  He told me a bit about his particular department and the types of products his UX team is currently working on.  He then asked me to talk about a couple of projects in my online portfolio.  A few weeks later I had a second phone interview with two members of the UX team.  The conversation was the same as the first call.  

Throughout the process, the manager was kind enough to keep me in the loop instead of leaving me in the infamous black hole of uncertainty.  He was very accommodating when I expressed that I had received another offer while waiting for IBM to make their decision and tried to fast-track the process for me.  

I was then asked to fill out my residential and criminal histories for the last seven years.  After this, I took the IBM Information Processing Aptitude Test (IPAT) which consisted of three logic-based sections, two of which were numbers based.  I'm not a math person, so this was nerve-wracking for me, but I heard that it's an outdated test that they don't really pay attention to. 

A few days later, The manager asked to set up a short phone call.  I was expecting another interview or to talk about flying me out for an on-site interview, but to my surprise was offered the position.

It was a great base salary offer with great benefits for someone fresh out of college like myself. I'm still in the process of gathering information prior to starting, but I can tell that IBM wants us to succeed.  It still feels like I'm dreaming.
cons:
In the beginning I was only communicating with the hiring manager. Once I received the offer letter, I was told to communicate with a recruiter from HQ in Armonk, NY. Having to deal with a completely new person in a completely different location kind of slowed the process down and it seemed somewhat unnecessary to involve a third party at this point.  Since then, the recruiter has been much slower in responding than the manager, but I don't want to distract the manager from his primary job.

Because of this, the on-boarding process could be made a bit smoother. Communications with a slow-to-respond recruiter is frustrating when you have less than two weeks to find an apartment and move across the East coast.
