review_title: Project Management
pros: IBM Is a large company with lots of clients and opportunities
cons: The company is being run by the accountants who only see as far down the road as the end of the current quarter and will they make their numbers.  I did not see a single business decision made in the last 3 years that had to do with long term planning or customer satisfaction.  Most of the employees in North America have either been let go, or will be let go shortly.  Replacement workers are no where near as well trained, but that's not why they are being hired.

review_title: IT Manager
pros:
Large organisation so plenty of roles to move to. Good experience given the breadth of what IBM dies in Ireland. 
Reasonable benefits (aside from salary)
cons:
Salary is not competitive in certain divisions of IBM Ireland. Also work ethic in GTS delivery means that the more senior you get the more roles you are expected to do at once.
Large numbers of people out in stress leave due to workload.

review_title: 23 years - 15 roles. I employer
job_title: Executive IT Specialist in London, England
pros: Ongoing education is great. Formal and informal and the opportunity to contribute to the direction of my own and others education paths (by creating education as well as receiving it)
cons:
Easy for salary to fall behind the market - hard to get that back. 
Scale of the company can lead to some decisions being seen as arbitrary at an individual level - and can be hard to predict and avoid

review_title: Happy to join IBM
pros: they were in continous touch uptill they send the offer letter
cons: the process took some time but its considerable...

review_title: Great learning experience
job_title: General Manager in New York, NY
pros: I learned a lot at IBM over many years and most of the people were great. There are more new things to do every day and there is nothing the company is not involved in.
cons: The frustration level is extremely high, the care for people is very low, and the company does not realize it. You can do great things at IBM, but you really need to weather a tough environment and some pretty random cuts.

review_title: Good Company, but very big
pros: Overall great company with great benefits.  Managers are very focused on the needs of the individual employees. The compensation and benefits are not as generous as they were in the past and have move much closer to the industry average.   Great support for skill development
cons: It is a very, very big company.  No single review can give it justice because the environment will vary greatly by business unit and sub-domains.   Someone who isn't comfortable with big orgs (large cities, large schools, etc) may feel lost.

review_title: My experience in IBM
pros:
I have had a great time so far in my 1.5 years in IBM,  this enterprise is undergoing a transformation to behave more like a small company, is difficult but I can see their progress.  Some of the things I like are:
Flexibility to work from home or in different schedule
Lot of focus on developing your skills as a way to give better results, and grow
High focus on looking for innovation ideas from everyone to help the company transformation
Interesting projects to work on (but I guess this depends on the area where you land)
cons:
Too big, that sometimes is difficult to get to the right person, resource or information
Far from the city, (but the bus system is quite good)

review_title: Big Blue = Big Lay Offs
pros: Most peers are intelligent, hard-working, and respectful. Some of the best folks to work with.
cons: Executives care only about lining their own pockets and very little about the folks doing the work. Bonuses are almost non-existent as are raises and promotions. Neither good work nor hard work ensure job safety. If profits don't meet expectations, EVERYONE is at risk of being cut.

review_title: Account Manager
pros:
Diversity: company's respect to minorities is awesome.
Technology: it is great to feel like you are part of the next big thing.
cons:
Oldfashioned Management: middle and higher management feel like they are stuck in 1980/1990. A lot of talking about "The New IBM", but no action to fundamentally change the structure. 
Prevalent Disorganization: everything is caotic and disorganized. None of the departments talk to eachother and the customer (and those representing the company before them) are penalized. It went as far as having someone elses bonus paycheck cashed into my account. 
Payment: under the market average... no matter the area or position.

review_title: IBM Review
pros: Big Organization, Work Culture is some how good.
cons: No work opportunity after getting training, Conflict in JRSS and Actual Work, No respect to senior employees, No Salary Hike, No Promotion, Always a Job threat once come on bench.

review_title: Great Work Life Balance
pros: IBM has grown over years, there are lots of change happening within its IT spectrum. It still offers very good work life balance; once you are in IBM you would always be an IBMer. It is one of the big IT company which has substantial footprint in revolutionary technologies pertaining to artificial intelligence, cognitive solution, cloud computing & a vast array of SAP projects.
cons: With a big work force of more than 4 lakhs its not easy to keep every one happy on the compensation front, so yearly increment is less compared to other competitors however its work life balance equates the shortcomings. Again its my opinion which will differ from others.

review_title: Great for starting out (Watson Health)
pros:
- Able to touch multiple levels of code
- Write code designed to scale for millions of users
- Hours are generally 40 per week
- Company really tries to make you succeed / have you learn
- Watson Health is trying to solve hard/interesting/good problems
- Office is in an amazing location (for Cambridge, MA)
cons:
- No food (yet?)
-  A lot of audio conferencing (small push to video conferencing)
- A lot of young engineers, lacking senior engineers
- Slow moving (healthcare has a lot of red tape)

review_title: Clients, Innovation and Values
job_title: General Manager in New York, NY
pros: Trusted advisor to clients big and small, across different industries and geographies. I love the fact that innovation is at the heart of the work - not just patents but new techs like artificial intelligence (cognitive), quantum computing, blockchain.  And I really like the focus on values and diversity around the world. We recently expanded parental leave (regardless of Family unit/type), just another example of leading with values. The company also has a focus on work/life balance and has that infused in leadership education. Finally, lots of opportunity to change roles and grow new skills.
cons: Constant change to create new markets, improve the portfolio, engage new markets. Not suited for people who prefer to stay in one area.

review_title: Good work environment, but low on salary and benefits
pros:
Good work. Great work culture in the VLSI department. Deadlines are realistic and not very aggressive, though important to not miss. Leadership and management trusts employees once they prove themselves. No micro-management of tasks unless you have missed some deadlines. Good constructive feedback even if some of the points are negative.  Great team to work for. Decent flexible hours.
Encourage movement within the company.
cons:
Location (Manyata) is not conducive for people living in the southern parts of the city(bengaluru)
For verification engineers, tools and methodologies used are not relevant to other companies. It can become a problem when you want to move out and attend interviews.
Compensation and benefits are much lower than industry standard for VLSI

review_title: Operation Data Center Manager
job_title: Data Center Operations Manager in Leesburg, VA
pros:
- Great Benefits which includes, PTO, PCH, Sick Time Off, medical benefits, Matching 401K, Stock Options.
- learning Resources are so many  and free that you can pretty much utilize and learn anything that relates to your career and grow with them.
- Tools that IBM uses are very intuitive and technologically advanced in the IT market which makes job simple to understand and use.
cons: - In the area where I am working is very competitive and data centers getting build consistently which creates lots Job opportunities with higher pay and Management is not able to match that which causes high turnover and losses of great talent and dissatisfied employees

review_title: Data Scientist
pros: A good platform to land on some large projects with big companies. You gonna experience and understand IT projects and business via a very strategic perspective.
cons:
The company is not well-organized at all. 
-Some of your boss might have few technical background and assign you some tasks totally mismatch your skills. 
-Bureaucrats prevail everywhere and processing like on-boarding, reimbursement and separation are very trivial yet time-consuming.
-Company Systems are so obsolete that you have to waste lots of time for some ridiculous purpose rather than to focus on your real work.
-Workplace culture is somehow cold and detached. No one is gonna tell you what's what and knowledge sharing is not a common practice.
And all of these management problems are garnished as "a self-serviced culture".

review_title: Great Company but you're slightly on your own to find what you want to do
job_title: Anonymous Employee in New York, NY
pros:
- So many great opportunities
- can work on cutting edge and high profile projects
- competitive salaries
- clear career paths
cons:
- lacks mentorship (really have to look for a mentor)
- can be a dispersed environment (not always a bad thing)
- have to actively look for project so you don't get stuck on a bad one (which can last a long time)

review_title: System administrator Linux
pros:
Got a Huge opportunity to earn experience of production servers as an administrator  spread over around 14 countries. 

Good training facility for freshers.
cons:
One time cab facilities only. Time dependent cab services. Does not provide cab during day time. 

In my case.. difficult to get leaves even if leaves are available.

Bad training facility for experienced people. I'm asked to get trained from outside of IBM.

Very less financial appraisal every year back to back for every one.

review_title: Tense last few years
pros: Awesome benefits in the beginning that went to great benefits. Work from home options assisted with worklife balance
cons: Last 7 years continual fear of resource actions(IBM for layoff) as the company continues to send work out of country.  Management heavy. Tons of managers. Annual review also sucked. You write your own review then management picks it apart to justify a per-determined rating

review_title: The benefits of working in a company like IBM
pros: There are so many of them. We can start with the employee treatment first, the company itself gives you a wonderful opportunity for career development and cares about your interests. Their workplaces themselves provide great flexibility and are almost always quite convenient to reach. Good opportunities for growth, technological innovation, contribution to both oneself and the community. It's a stable company with good values.
cons: You'll have to dedicate all your time and effort if you decide to get involved with this organization. So consider carefully in order to make a sensible decision.

review_title: Good right now, but in danger of loosing good people through rigid business model and administrative heavy processes
pros: Good employee benefits with flexible working. I don't know of any other employer that would allows the same level of responsibility in terms of organising working hours and location.
cons: Internal processes are cumbersome and frustrating. Hours are long and the culture is increasingly one of working 7 days a week. Pay reviews are poor, the pot for an annual increase is reduced every year. The salary benchmarking is a farse, with roles being measured against incorrect external criteria resulting in lower pay than contempories in other businesses.

review_title: Cool but not so cool either
job_title: Advisory Software Engineer in Hawthorne, NY
pros:
Following are the best reasons I think anyone should like IBM.
-Research in particular helps you innovate and also absorb your creative inputs. 
-Lot of highlight on work life balance (honest effort from the company)
-Very flexible work hours
My liking for IBM are mainly because of these additional reasons:
-I work in research and not too many companies have industrial research labs like of IBMs. They are unique for carrying academia quality research in industry
cons:
My points of dislikes
-not a good ladder in terms of professional growth. You are silo-ed in specific groups and very difficult to reach across. 
- you are evaluated on your bands and the process is too bureaucratic

review_title: IBM, a great company to work for.
pros: IBM values their employees.  Employees are compensated well, both in their salary and medical and health benefits.  Employees are provided an opportunity for advancement all over the world.  If you are requested to transfer to a new location, they make the entire process as painless as possible. They help with the sale of your current residence, provide interim living expenses, help with the purchase of your new residence and even subsidize a lower interest rate on your new mortgage.  They provide all of the resources necessary in order for you to complete your work.
cons: The only difficult period was during the troubling 1990’s.  At that time, IBM was forced to abandon their “Full Employment Principle” and initiate the Ranking System, whereby, periodically; the lower 5% of the workforce was dismissed.

review_title: Good place to work if you like IT
job_title: Marketing Tarinee in Ciudad de Mexico
pros: Solid company with interesting opportunities for young employees go are interested in technology systems. Good, and established procedures. Companies core values are important to all levels, and are shared with all the companies´ environment. They have an "employee club" that organizes events, and seeks for benefits for workers.
cons: As it is the case of many large coorporations, task can be too specific in certain positions, and some times too monotonous (boring), which can make it difficult to outstand from the croud. There is not much feed-back  for operational positions. Compensations are not very competitive. Sometimes it feels there is over share for meaningless information, but not much about important issues.

review_title: Stagnant work place.
pros: IBM is a good place for a diverse experience across a wide range of areas. I
cons: Stagnant advancement, poor communication with management, older workforce.  have been here for less than a year and have received very little feedback and very little contact with management. Opportunity to grow and move up seems to be very difficult because people tend to stay around for a long time. There was very little growth which also limited career advancement. The work force average age is rather high and people seem to be set in their ways of doing things rather being inovative. Instead of looking for new ways to approcah problems they stick to what they know.

review_title: You better like what you'll be doing because you won't be able to change it afterwards
pros: The brand name recognition is pretty much the only reason I can think of. IBM Global Services is a completely different beast from the innovative company that IBM is supposed to be.
cons: Once you get in it's unlikely your pay rate or day-to-day work will change. Dealing with the massive amounts of bureaucracy and broken systems is bound to get you too tired to do any real work. And since this is the consulting branch of IBM you'll have to deal with the customer's bureaucracy as well.

review_title: Stagnant work place.
pros: IBM is a good place for a diverse experience across a wide range of areas. I
cons: Stagnant advancement, poor communication with management, older workforce.  have been here for less than a year and have received very little feedback and very little contact with management. Opportunity to grow and move up seems to be very difficult because people tend to stay around for a long time. There was very little growth which also limited career advancement. The work force average age is rather high and people seem to be set in their ways of doing things rather being inovative. Instead of looking for new ways to approcah problems they stick to what they know.

review_title: You better like what you'll be doing because you won't be able to change it afterwards
pros: The brand name recognition is pretty much the only reason I can think of. IBM Global Services is a completely different beast from the innovative company that IBM is supposed to be.
cons: Once you get in it's unlikely your pay rate or day-to-day work will change. Dealing with the massive amounts of bureaucracy and broken systems is bound to get you too tired to do any real work. And since this is the consulting branch of IBM you'll have to deal with the customer's bureaucracy as well.

review_title: Avoid IBM like the plague!
job_title: Software Engineer in Foster City, CA
pros: You can work from home a lot of the time and while in different cities.  There are lots of training (classes) provided by IBM you can take.  Managers are flexible on you taking time off work to take care of person errands.  After IBM your resume will have lots of name recognition.
cons: They have been gradually outsourcing lots of software development work to India and China. Its only a matter of time before they will no longer have software developers here in the US.  PBC ratings completely unfair.  Management basically rates your performance against the entire organization and not individual performance.

review_title: Leaky bucket.
pros: Minority and female advancement opportunity
cons: Job insecurity.  IBM is committed to sharp reductions in US employee base

review_title: A Great Company to work.
pros:
The biggest IT Company in the world.
Great name in CV for your career.
Great career opportunity 
Satisfied working enviroment & salary.
A lot of things to learn & experience.
cons:
Junior managers doesnt know what they are doing and also I'm not satisfied with their management skills. They working for the greatest IT Company. I'm not sure they'd noticed this or not.

-You are expected to be a pre-sales expert , delivery expert and also post-sales expert. Are you kidding?
either your sales abilities are good or your technical abilities are good so you want to be a technical employee or sales employee you cannot be good both of them at the same time.....

review_title: Long term employee...recently retired
pros: None...Used to be a great company to work for but not any longer.
cons: Pay raises of 1% or 2% every few years drives newer employees away. Unfortunately the respect for the individual that was IBM's creed has vanished. Used to be the Flagship company to work for however now just another large multinational that most new hires stay on for 5 years and then move on.

review_title: IBM - Good work, experience, no money
job_title: Advisory IT Specialist in Bethesda, MD
pros: Smart people, good experience overall provided you work hard and get yourself a good role on the project. There is a lot of scope for enhancing your technical skills especially in the Application Information Services practice area.
cons: Some projects are large - do not necessarily have a great work culture. You might end up feeling lost or may not get a role of your choice in such situations. Raises are not good enough. An experienced person ends up making the same as a new hire after couple of years of working at IBM. This is one of the main causes why IBM would suffer from low retention rates especially in their experienced band 6-7 resources.

review_title: I built sales pipeline for a software company acquired by IBM in 2006.
pros: In a sales function, the name IBM certainly opens doors with prospective clients; they're more willing to listen.  There is more than enough training in all aspects: function, product, industry.  I enjoyed and miss working with smart and dedicated professionals.  Direct management that I experienced was fair and reasonable.  Lots of fun networking opportunities in major cities.
cons: Things move relatively slow in a large organization and consequently enthusiasm can lose steam.  On the other hand, a recent reorganization in sales and marketing swiftly cut thousands of positions.  Once hired, if you want to stay with IBM, learn as much as possible, keep your eyes and ears open, and network like crazy to secure your next position.

review_title: Where did the "soul" of IBM go?
pros: Excellent environment to gain and expose skills in varied parts of the business. No one need feel as though they are placed in a niche work environment- never to entertain other viable options (including world wide assignments) within organizations.
cons: Lack of focus by management to recognise employee skills levels  and assist placing them in appropriate roles within organization. Need to stop the 24x7x365  work day demands.

review_title: Good company overall - with a few disadvantages of being huge.
job_title: Software Developer Co-Op in San Jose, CA
pros:
1. The congeniality and the people willing to help. 
2. Being a very large company, IBM has jobs in almost every field in CS and many non CS fields.
3. You can develop niche skills that are tough to find elsewhere.
cons:
1. Reading legacy code and supporting old technologies might seem uninteresting to fresh college graduates.
2. Being very huge has its own disadvantages - like - a few processes/rules that might not make a lot o sense, but have to be followed.

review_title: My 8 months at IBM were a tremendously valuable learning experience, but they don't have many FT job openings.
pros: The caliber of the people I worked with, ability to network, collaborate, and communicate with others, and flexibility and freedom to do my work on my own schedule in my own way.
cons: They have barely any FT job offers for their interns (at least in my area), and their persistent focus on cost-cutting and leanness has led to overworked, under-appreciated employees.

review_title: IBM is a fantastic place to work.
job_title: IT Specialist in Costa Mesa, CA
pros: Quality people and a fast paced environment that will help you maximize your potential.  Great flexibility of work/life balance.  Even with all the changes in the world, and even some negative ones at IBM, IBM still manages to make the work experience a model for the rest of the world to look up to.
cons: Small fish in a big pond for sure, but these are merely byproducts of the environment.  Your challenge is not to complain about them but to adapt and become successful in the framework that exists.

review_title: IBM has much to offer and has some terrific talent, but the focus should be to leverage the talent not lay them off.
pros: To develop great skills, works with some of the brightest minds, and support some of the biggest companies in the world.
cons: The constant focus on layoffs impacts employee motivation and performance.  IBM was once the best of the best and has reduced intself to a commodity.

review_title: There are ups and downs, and it's sure to end with one big down.
job_title: Staff Software Engineer in Boulder, CO
pros: There are some good employee discounts with large partners.  Some good perks include public transportation passes, recreation areas (at least at my site), and flexible work-at-home schedules.
cons: There are about 300,000 fewer American employees in IBM than there used to be, and you can expect that number to grow.  Compensation lags competitors and won't be improving.  Some of the cost-cutting measures over the last several years are ridiculous, such as reduced trash collection.

review_title:
My experience at IBM has been challenging and rewarding
If you want to change my central position, you would own IBM
job_title: ITD- Server Systems Operation Specialist in San Jose, CA
pros:
IT is the company and the world's largest consulting
IBM thinks of his long professional life and allows you to pursue the career you want,
 It gives you the opportunity to design your work day according to the unique needs and styles depending on the project customer you are.
 It is an innovative company where you can continue to grow and deepen your experience and knowledge.
 A company you can be proud of
cons:
Great company with little bureaucracy and unrealistic expectations.
In wages I can not comment much, but every year if there is an adjustment according to your PBC (Rating)

review_title: Would never work there again
pros: Decent compensation.  But watch-out for those who become employees in an acquisition!  They do not grand-father tenure from previous company in compensation calculations when they lay you off.  Also, they are committed to drawing down their US staff as much as possible.
cons: Our small customer-focused software company was acquired by IBM SWG in 2009.  They laid-off 25% of us within first year.  They would not allow us to go to training for other software tools.  Their bureaucracy and "blue washing" is ridiculously cumbersome.  They were only interested in Sales numbers and only gave lip service to customers.

review_title: Good in the past, steady decline in the last decade
pros:
Chance to work with world class technology.  
Vacation holiday and personal time flexibility.  
Health benefits seem to be pretty good.
cons:
Erosion of support functions, leads to extra work just to keep your work environment going.  Workstation support is one, admin support is another. 
Recurring layoffs keeps you on edge.

review_title: An organization that taught us to Think.
pros: IBM is an organization that offers all possible platforms and domains that one can think of. The highest number of patents filed from this organization is a proof of the fact that technology is above all in IBM. It is a open ground to explore for a tech wizard.
cons: Don't expect much of pay hike, IBM is no pay master. Earning money in IBM is the toughest job. A large part of your mentioned salary will be deducted with excuse of Variable and Groat driven profit sharing.

review_title: Company making profits but not sharing with employees
pros: The work is challenging, the employees are generally highly motivated and skilled, and many opportunities for personal growth
cons: The salary increments are abysmal - this year they decided to not raise salaries for executives, and top performers with the highest ratings were given a 1% raise and everyone else did not get raises.

review_title: Work-life balance is out of whack
pros: Brand name.  Difficult & challenging assignments:  great "boot camp" for future opportunities
cons: Workload increases constantly.  Most of my peers and coworkers are constantly putting in 60-70 hour weeks just to keep up as well as giving up vacation time.  We feel like we are being ground to bits at this pace.  What used to be a work-life balance benefit (work from home) has turned into you-are-on-call-20hrs/day.  I get the pressures of the current economy, but this is not sustainable.

review_title: Great place to work - Its a big company but a very well run company
pros: If you are a hard worker you will do well at IBM. You are surrounded by talented people. Company has great values. You are told to never compromise your values and alway conduct business in a ethically. Even in sales!
cons: You are definitely part of a machine, its hard to shine until you put in you time. Lots of process. I guess you can expect that from a 100 year old company.  But with that said the pros out way the cons for sure

review_title: Good Team Members
job_title: Senior Software Engineer in Raleigh, NC
pros:
Good team atmosphere, everyone's nice. Work is OK, not overly demanding. Learned a lot. 

Good emphasize on a systematic approach to software development, most based Agile Methodologies. They also encourage you to establish patents and technical articles. 

You may be able to work with a lot of teams around the globe. And you have some opportunity to rotate to oversea offices
cons: I met many low-key experts and I also met quite a few egoistic know-it-all. Really need to focus on concrete learning by yourself and make sure your skill set has a strong foundation. You need to search and discover who those real experts are, the ones who are willing spending time to help you to grow your own expertise.

review_title: The experience here at IBM is among the best in India. Having worked here for 5 years, I am completely satisfied.
pros: Good work life, Good remuneration. Most of the top level officials are good and are helpful professionally.
cons: Way more hectic schedules than others. The life offered here gives you almost everything except a very vital component - time. If not today, then someday or the other one will opt for more time and thats where the problems creep in.

review_title: Big blue giant
job_title: Advisory Software Engineer in Shanghai, Shanghai
pros: Really huge global enterprise with full of resources to promote you knowledge and skills in IT industry. I would still like to recommend IBM to college graduates because they can learn a lot in this company.
cons:
Very bureaucratic, complex internal process and unreasonable internal regulations which hinders the employee's working performance (for example, PGP installation on every employee's laptop hard disk to encrypt data)
Severe cost saving which has huge negative impact on business

review_title: Big Blue
job_title: Senior Consultant in New York, NY
pros: big company, tons of resources, large client base. IBM has some of everything making them capable of competing with anyone in any space
cons: The pay is lower than industry average and the amazing benefits are starting to be watered down. Management is under ridiculous targets which can't be met leading to negative feelings in the rank and file as we are very short sighted and cheap. Many managers and partners are not good consultants, they have just stayed for many years. Tons of politics.

review_title: I've been moved
job_title: Staff Software Engineer in Austin, TX
pros: Professional colleagues who are usually willing to help.  Easy to move around US while staying in the same position.  A sense of stability, depending which group you are in ( I am in SWG).  Salary seems to be competitive no matter of race or sex.
cons: Management does not provide what is needed to be excellent only enough to get by.  Hard to be a top performer without sucking up to management.  Very hard to move up without being a consecutive top performer (1).

review_title: Not the great company it used to be
job_title: Senior Project Manager in London, England
pros: Opportunities, variety of roles. Usually very good people to work with on projects. When I joined 19 years I thought this was an amazing company with great inspirational leaders that cared and invested in people.
cons:
Motivational leadership is non existent compared to the past. The leaders of the business today just shout at people to do more and reduce costs. People are  costs that need to be removed
Strategy changing all the time no clear direction. 
Benefits are poor and getting worse

review_title: IBM Design is a frustrating opportunity
pros: Ground floor of a big movement in design, inspiring company legacy, vacation and benefits, funding.
cons: Management cares more about perception than substance; they want to promote themselves as good designers more than to be good designers. IBM is a tough company to get things done in. It is so big that projects are disorganized and extremely political. It is hard to do good design here.

review_title: The Best Company, The Best People.
job_title: Senior Software Quality Assurance Engineer in Sydney
pros:
When you join IBM you are an IBMer for life. There are so many talented, intelligent, innovative people working side by side with you every day that you are inspired to be the best you can be. 
Work/life balance is extremely important as are the happiness, satisfaction and safety of all staff.
All new ideas, no matter if they come from the mailroom or the executive board are treated with the consideration and enthusiasm.
cons: I really have no negatives to report at all. If I hadn't needed to move away I would have happily been an IBM lifer

review_title: Mostly positive experience, some negative points mostly to do with big corporate business
pros: Great people and great perks.  Vacation was plentiful and negotiable.  Many experts all around to consult and gleam knowledge from.    Flexible work from home options.
cons: Easy to get lost in the fray.  Difficult to transition roles or change departments.   IT support staff was non-existent.  Engineers had to constantly solve their own IT / networking issues, taking critical time away from the real job.  Performance evaluations are a farce.  IBM is changing its business model and is probably abandoning the semiconductor manufacturing business, which might explain the decline in support staff.

review_title: Senior IT Architect
pros: Several years back, it was a great company to work for.  Lots of flexibility for learning and opportunities.  There was no limit on what one could achieve.  No limit on which class one could attend.  Continuous learning was promoted to better support our clients.  It was great to be an IBMer and to work with very, very smart people.  Great memories!
cons: Frequent layoffs since 2007, almost every quarter employees are laid off and employee selection is not based on performance.  It is a numbers game.   The IT resource model is being transformed into an off-shore resource model.

review_title: Great place to work
pros: I think the best thing in IBM research is the man power. I've been working there for almost 8 years and it has been a genuine pleasure. The work environment is usually very calm and most of the time very oriented (you don't get the feeling that you are all alone and not sure what to do).
cons: Being a contractor employee. No where to advance.

review_title: Vast and Varying Company
job_title: Software Engineer in Belfast, Northern Ireland
pros: Prestigious reputation. Spans most major cities in the world. Despite it's size it is increasingly an amalgamation of acquisitions so you will find plenty of sites and departments that have the feel of a small company or start up.
cons: There are endless protocols and red tape when doing things and any small company or start up feel is only temporary in an acquisition as the 'Bluewash' rolls in. It does feel like an acquisition machine focusing on shareholder happiness rather than innovation.

review_title: Still a good place to work
pros:
Work at home provides the flexibility to adjust your schedules provided you aren't overloaded with work.    
Some managers are excellent and really care about their staff and show great respect.
cons: Workloads can be excessive and time frames are often far too short to do the correct things.   Customer requirements are often changing and executives often don't consider the complexity of customer solutions.    Generally there aren't enough staff available to do the volume of work.

review_title: HIt and miss

review_title: The Last Bastion of Corporate Bloat in an Agile World
job_title: Site Reliability Engineer in Dallas, TX
pros:
* Excellent Paid Time Off policy, particularly for employees in Essential Operations roles.

* Exposure to a very broad array of technologies and systems.

* Progressive values and strong support for equality in and out of the workplace

* Looks good on a resume
cons:
* Massive corporate bloat. The company has been around for well over 100 years, and it still runs like an old company, with numerous levels of management slowly drip-feeding decisions through a painfully dense bureaucratic process. IBM is slow to react, and when your primary competition are billion-dollar newcomers with better brand recognition, that's not a sustainable position.

* Over-reliance on archaic first-party software and systems. I get it, it looks bad if you sell your own email client but use someone else's, but maybe that's just a sign that Notes is a failed product and we should cut our losses and let Microsoft take the .01% market share we're occupying, because Outlook/Exchange is better at everything we set out to do. This applies to a number of areas of concern.

* Inadequate compensation. There's no getting around it: IBM pays below industry average in any given area, for any given skill level in any given field. Other benefits are pretty average for the industry, so the argument that they're making up for the low dollar figure in other ways doesn't hold up anymore. Career advancement within the technical side caps out really quickly, and the only way to continue your development is by going into management, which is far more stress than it's worth.

* Cultural dissonance. As IBM has made a number of acquisitions in recent years, it's failed to integrate the company cultures of those acquisitions into itself, particularly taking the good from them. Instead, it pushes a preexisting central IBM culture that isn't compatible with the way many of these smaller companies' employees are used to operating. As a result, these employees continue to see themselves as employees of other companies and not as part of IBM, and it creates an us-vs-them mentality in the organization as a whole.

* No clear plan. While we hear all the time about "strategic imperatives" and other buzzwords, the fact is, no plan seems to stay in place longer than a couple of quarters, and we're not gaining any ground against our ever-stronger competition. In fact, IBM is still on a negative growth trend. Everyone knows about Watson, but it's still not making us any money, so what's the plan?

* Self-congratulatory management. Various managers and executives are constantly sending out emails and lectures about how IBM is doing so great innovating in x field over y period of time, which while dubious is understandable. However, every other manager uses the opportunity to suck up to the exec in question. Call it corporate politics, but no manager is willing to tell his boss when they're wrong. It rolls downhill in a way I've never seen elsewhere.

* Ginni Rometty. I always say, anything that happens at a company can be blamed on the CEO. In IBM's case, we've had Ginni for the last 12 years, and of that time, just about half of it has been spent on a constant decline. All the while, Ginni waxes on about her strategic imperatives and how they're going to Make IBM Great Again. Prior to being the CEO, she worked in strategic outsourcing, and everyone who could tell her things she doesn't want to hear, which could help make decisions that would improve our standing, is well aware of that history. There are worse CEOs to work under, but don't expect Jeff Bezos or Satya Nadela.

I have been working for them almost 3 years and  in my 30 years in the computer industry, it is by far the BEST.  I am proud to say I am an IBMer!!!
cons: I haven't had a pay raise yet in over 2 years - not even a merit raise.  I wish that would change.  But other than that, I enjoy my job and my team!

review_title: Proud to be an IBMer
pros: Good thing here in IBM is equality. Hard work will paid off here in IBM. We can get lot of opportunities to work with other technologies if we are interested. And we can opt training sessions on technology based. Again these things are purely based on project which you are chosen for  .
cons: The disadvantage here is work from home option is there, it is good for few days but not for long time, if team members are working from home most of time then team collaboration will be missed. And most of the problems can be solved easily with team work.

review_title: Great people and great company
pros: My coworkers are overall talented, my work is extremely challenging and the work life balance is terrific.   In addition to the actual work, I really appreciate limited travel, work from home opportunities and 6+ weeks of paternity leave.  The opportunity to change jobs within IBM is also something that excites me.  The diversity in the products and services IBM brings to market provides numerous opportunities to change roles, learn new skills and grow my career.
cons: Size and complexity of organization can sometimes slow things down.

review_title: Delivery infrastructure
pros: A good place to work in terms of benefits. Lot of opportunity in different fields and industry. Has a wide range of training links through which you can learn new technologies. Has tie up with best online books resources - which you can avail for no cost - It is good for aspiring candidates for reference. Lot of forums around the world to reach out for issues in your field.
cons: As you grow in the organization there is a limit to your movement to different roles as the role are based on the clients requirement.  In the delivery side there is a lot of focus on cost management - mainly on the curtailing of resources allotment to projects.

review_title: Transform mutually
pros: An organization that helped me to transform myself and made me realize what I need rather than what I want. There could always be some instances in your career when you are not happy with work or compensation or flexibility offered by the organizations and it can be highly confusing and misleading at times. In such situations all need is some extra space to choose from multiple options. IBM has been helpful for me to choose the right kind of work,benefit and flexibility.
cons: You need to showcase your capabilities and have right kind of energy to connect with people, otherwise you can feel stagnant and lost in the vastness of the organization.

review_title: Flexible work place  but still beaurocratic
pros:
Excellent training opportunities and flexible working in home office
Offices worldwide 
Focus on reskilling for digitalization and AI provides opportunity to develop quickly and take on interesting projects 
High ethical standards
Has both management and technical promotion paths
cons: Process before people. Can get lost in complex processes trying to solve mundane problems. professed culture of regular feedback not lived by many managers. Focus still very much on managing numbers, rather than impactful outcomes for the customer and employees.

review_title: One Company. Many Career Opportunities!
job_title: Talent Acquisition Partner in Cambridge, MA
pros:
- Endless career paths you can pursue within one company (imagine not having to enroll in new benefits again!). 
- Everyone has personal accountability and are trusted to get work done (read: no micromanagement). 
- Work/Life balance is practiced, not just preached (I'm WFH as I write this review).
- I'm encouraged to bring my whole self to work each and every day.
cons:
- Company is so large and complex it's hard to get your arms around it.
- Office environment is a little lacking (/uninspiring) if you're not at a strategic location (Binney Street > Rogers Street in Cambridge, MA)
- Benefits are not competitive with others in this space (bonuses are unreliable, if non-existent; no RSUs, etc.).

review_title: Good company but no upward mobility
job_title: Solutions Architect in Boca Raton, FL
pros: The company itself still has a reputation even though it's not special anymore. The job is good, some days boring, some days are exciting, the people are nice and remote work is fantastic
cons:
No upward mobility
No salary increase, you get maybe 2% so plan you base salary accordingly
Bonus is like 1 week worth of salary if any if you are in a cost center (basically anything other than sales, pre-sales)

review_title: You're a number
pros:
Work from home, dependent on manager and team
Decent benefits
Big company and you have good chance of working with good people.
cons:
Red tape--on a massive scale. Why any company would hire IBM to help the run their operations is a joke considering IBM can't get its own house in order.
Every pro at IBM is dependent on your manager. At IBM it's possible you are managed by someone who is simply there to do the red tape stuff and have nothing else to do with you.
No raises, pitiful bonuses

review_title: IBM CIO, CHQ
pros: At the moment, my job is flexible. I can work from home a few times a week and as long as I'm getting my work done, my boss does not question me. However, this depends entirely on management. I've had some crazy, micromanagers too.
cons: You are not praised for doing more work; it is expected. and the more work you do, the more you will get without compensation or praise.

review_title: Money makes for greedy management
job_title: Software Engineer in San Jose, CA
pros: Good technical experience in enterprise software development.  It is intelligent, hard working people at the lowest level that makes this company what it is!
cons: Too much emphasis on return to shareholders, at the expense of decent employee salaries.  All upper management care about are aquisitions, aquisitions and more aquisitions, which doesn't instill a lot of confidence in employees who are often working on competing projects.

review_title: Money makes for greedy management
job_title: Software Engineer in San Jose, CA
pros: Good technical experience in enterprise software development.  It is intelligent, hard working people at the lowest level that makes this company what it is!
cons: Too much emphasis on return to shareholders, at the expense of decent employee salaries.  All upper management care about are aquisitions, aquisitions and more aquisitions, which doesn't instill a lot of confidence in employees who are often working on competing projects.

review_title: Elephants may dance, but not very well.
job_title: Advisory Software Engineer in Tucson, AZ
pros: Obviously IBM provides the stability that comes with such a large organization, but also the subtleties such as working with cutting edge research and development. Also, IBM strives to improve work/life balance, but it can often depend on the individual or management situation.
cons: Like any behemoth, IBM has its bureaucracy.  It does seem to be a cesspool like breeding ground for middle management.  There are times where you are treated like a child and not the highly educated professional that you are.

review_title: Good company overall.
pros: Good place for work/life balance.  You have the flexibility to work from remotely or from home.  Big company with many areas of opportunities to work in.  The company rewards you for innovating and coming up with ideas that generate patents.  The people are generally competent and easy to work with.
cons: Large company with plenty of red tape.  Sometimes can be very political.  Working across groups and components can be challenging.  There can be a lot of negotiating between groups on how to split revenue and this can hamper or completely halt a project.  Different groups internally may have similar products that compete with each other.

review_title: Find a niche and it could work for you - but stay out of the politics if you can.
pros:
Plenty of opportunity to find a role that suit's your strengths.
Empowered to act, within reason, to achieve your objectives.
Nice working environment; well furnished offices, good canteens.
Reasonable understanding of the need for work / life balance.
Good benefits; car, health, pension plan.
Opportunity for travel and entertainment.
Oh and the money isn't bad either!
cons:
Politics. There's a lot of game playing and power struggles - to prove one's worth.
Too much time needed to promote oneself amongst one's peers and managers.
Death by PowerPoint. Torture by Excel.
Lotus Domino.
Projects that go nowhere.
Too comfortable - easy to becomne complacent.
A place where bad performers can hide.

review_title: Company Review
job_title: User Experience Designer in San Jose, CA
pros:
- work / life balance
- 401(k) match is awesome
- flexible work hours
- vacation time is great
- they don't work you to death (at least in my dept.)
- free light rail pass for commuting
- encourage learning, having a mentor, moving around in the company
cons:
- the ability to affect change is difficult because the company is so large
- career growth is a slow process

review_title: From a former IBMer
job_title: Project Manager in San Jose, CA
pros: There is good work/life balance. The amount that the company matches for the 401k is higher than any other place I have been.  The flexible work schedule is great. You can work from home anytime you want.
cons: Carrer growth can be difficult unless you are willing to move to another region of the country or even out of the country.  There seems to be lots of job losses in the areas where there is higher cost of living.  There are frequent layoffs.

review_title: Not your mother's or father's IBM
pros: Unlimited resources for information in order to self-learn multiple IT disciplines.  Still carries prestige with others.  Many employees are spectacular and top achievers.
cons: In practice, workloads kept increasing as downsizings were common.  Came to be where employees were working around the clock in global environments.  Acquiring a sweatshop atmosphere with small or nonexistant salary increases for the general population.  New management by fear, intimidation and bullying style becoming prevalent.

review_title: Ok place to work, but beware of inflexible corporate culture
job_title: IT Architect in São Paulo, São Paulo
pros:
- Good opportunities for career growth
- Makes it easy for changing job roles and positions
- Career path is well-defined
- Broad business vision
cons:
- Salaries lower than competitors; especially if you are a long time employee
- Too much competition within the company; hurts overall business strategy
- Many layers of management and overlapping job roles
- Inefficiency of resources and slow response to market changes
- HW e SW divisions still depend on mainframe sales
- Cross reporting makes employees waste time keeping multiple managers up to date.

review_title: I suggest to see beyond the brand.
pros:
You have best teams
You can reach out to any one for help or with Ideas
You have full potential to grow  but you need manager backup
cons:
*Performance Appraisal is too complex they call it PBC 
*You get more work,less pay compared to others unfair
*IBM India is full of stupid politics, lack of direction and leadership.
* Executive at DPE level shows Excel sheet , Cracker Cartoons in All hands meet on a over head projector 
* Manager is King, and usually they are assoles unless you are lucky.

review_title: Employment at an IBM GDC is relatively stable, however it does not satisfy in terms of compensation and general morale.
pros:
- Relatively stable employment
- Competitive benefits package
- Reasonable work/life balance encouraged and applied
- Sufficient opportunity for lateral movement within the organization
cons:
- Virtually no possibility for advancement
- Nepotism common
- Compensation is below industry average
- Senior management often has fundamental lack of respect for employees
- Employee turnover high

review_title: Freedom to experiment, learn, improve and implement
pros: Freedom to innovate. No micro-management. Very good work-life balance. At the end of the day, it all depends on the manager you work for.
cons:
Very hard to influence any decision making at any level. A lot of processes in place which is understandable for such a large company. However, they slowdown your work.A lot of time is spent adhering to policies OR following training on policies. 
There is system for every little thing that you need to do and it takes time to learn who to contact for what and then the time to actually get the task done.

review_title: A good deal of independence
pros:
Flexible working - nobody keeping a check on you - getting good quality work done is the priority
A culture of generally helpful people with a positive team ethic
cons:
Extremely low salary with managers powerless to raise it (make sure you get a healthy starting salary)
Lack of a sense of team, with full time remote working the norm, and meetings rare and focussed, with little time for informal interactions
Some very poor managers
Unnecessary cost-cutting measures at all times (from shoddy phones to cumbersome processes to get work-related travel approved, etc)
Top-down communications with an occasional cursory "forum" with management

review_title: Occupy Movement Required Across IBM
job_title: Human Resources Leader in Toronto, ON
pros:
Size 
Depth of skills, know how and commitment of employees
Business focus
Brand
Potential
cons:
Executive entitlement
Distribution of corporate wealth
Abuse of power
Competitive Salaries
Career Opportunity
Lost Potential

review_title: Some thoughts after some years.
pros:
Possibility to work and learn with some very smart and experienced individuals. 
Highly valued externally as an employer. 
New opportunities come up constantly.
Many different areas of technology and services where you can progress.
cons: There seems to be a lack of structure in many of the business areas. Communication within large work groups is often insufficient and not transparent. Management often fully aware of the inputs/outputs that their function is working with. More focus on "IBM internal" rather than the client, which is in conflict with the values.

review_title: Good company for new Grads
pros: Working as a Financial analyst at the Rochester COE has it perks. First the work life balance is great, you work 40 or even 38 hours some weeks, as long as you get your work done. You also have the option to work from home and the atmosphere is very laid back and relaxed and this is reflected in the dress code. Plus the average age for FA's is 24/25 so it is a youthful bunch.
cons: Salary is pathetic, 40k flat with no room for negotiotion. You get a 2k increase when converted to a reg. Also limited upward mobility, not he greatest place to build a career.

review_title: Great company for starting!
pros: I worked 6 years for IBM. There's some really great people working there, and the work environment is nice. Lots of innovation going on, the IBM brand name still gives you some visibility, you work in a global environment, and there are lots of tech job options.
cons: Again, this is a ideally a company for someone just starting in the job market, so this is not the place to go if you want a fat paycheck or even decent benefits. Career opportunities do exist, but if you're a top performer or if you have marketable skills, in time you'll want to look elsewhere for real career advancement.

review_title: Learned a lot, but career options were limited.
job_title: Advisory Hardware Engineer in Research Triangle Park, NC
pros: There are a lot of smart people at IBM.  Management is good, not great.  It is a great place to be part of a successful team.
cons: Lots of big company issues including outsourcing and shutting down businesses that are profitable, but not profitable enough!  You do not feel like anyone outside of your immediate colleagues cares about you.

review_title: Tivoli SME, team leader
job_title: Tivoli SME, Team Leader in São Paulo, São Paulo
pros: Multi-cultural company, you will work with people around the world, flexibility company (home office, flexible shift)
cons: This company seems to always be cutting expenses and laying off good employees. It's hard to believe that they will continue to load off some regions to send to low cost regions (ok it is low cost, but what else? they don't have any skills set, never will get the job done, will always cause troubles). Seems that IBM is always thinking in costs and leaving the quality. Really sad!!!

review_title: 20 years and gone !
pros: I worked from home successfully for last 12 of my 20 years with the company.  Management trusted their employees and supported the work-at-home model.
cons: I think my story is common at IBM - once you're in your 50s with many years of success and service and making a bit more money, your position is eliminated through re-organization.  What's worse, the internal job posting system uses keywords instead of people to sift through internal transfers and applications.

review_title: Extremely varied work over the years but extremely process bound
pros:
As a permanent,
* Variety in all respects: people, locations, technologies, languages, programming APIs.
* Get to write some documentation and/or redbooks.
cons:
* You will become entirely stereotyped in job function. Having a technology you wish to pursue (in your own time) does not prevent you becoming trapped.
* Get to read some documentation and/or redbooks.
* Long hours (no overtime pay of course) and no / slow progression.
* Ever descending morale.

review_title: Great company. Tough times.
pros: There is much to be proud of in IBM: technology/patent leader, major deal maker, depth, business focus, looks good on resume, high ethical standards, health/family support and reasonable salary packaging.
cons:
Not all management understand the business.
Many decisions by fiat.
Can be difficult to deal with politics.
US centric.
Formal training is a thing of the past. Get it when you can. Usually in your own time. (Just like being back in Uni)

review_title: Hard work for less pay.
job_title: Unix Technical Support Specialist III (JAZZ) in Columbia, MO
pros:
o Great people and teams you'll get to interact with in Columbia, MO.

o You'll possibly learn new skills or hone existing technical skills.

o Ample parking.
cons:
o Below (way below) average pay.

o If you know what you're doing (tech-wise), the company will quickly take advantage of it and you will burn out.

o Salary.

review_title: Big Blue review
pros:
Great learning experiences in dealing with all sorts of people from various business and social cultures.
Usually very flexible work/life balance.
Learn to operate and achieve success in a highly matrixed and political corporation.
cons:
Remuneration is not where it should be. For the last 7 of my 15 years there the salary reviews and increases were almost a pointless exercise, and gradually fell well behind the market averages.
Some red-tape is outdated and limits efficiency.
The right people/teams aren't often rewarded and recognised, but rather a who you know system.

review_title: Senior Support Analyst
job_title: Senior IT Specialist in London, England
pros: Flexible home/office work options, lots of training opportunities if you seek them out.  Lots of options to apply to other positions all around the world with good help from management to facilitate this.
cons: Too big a company to get to be really noticed for your hard work, it's who you know to get ahead up the ladder. Too little investment in new ideas due to the bean counters stifling innovation.

review_title: Career versus a Job .. still possible!
job_title: Software Development, First Line Manager in Raleigh, NC
pros: IBM has a focus on retaining its high performance culture, recognizing employees impact to the business. In addition, employees have the opportunity, through management and mentor support, to chart a course for a Career at IBM --  allowing for change in interests and experiences, and development of new skill sets.
cons: Salary and Benefits are not the highest in the industry .. probably more average to above average, in most areas. That being said, look at IBM as a long-term investment - to develop that Career, and you will see the value of working at the company.

review_title: Solid, not exciting
job_title: Software Development Engineer in Hursley, England
pros:
- better job stability than many other companies
- excellent technical capability and technical career paths in Software Group
- lots of opportunity for changing jobs within the same company
- they look after you very well if you have personal misfortune (e.g. cancer, bereavement)
cons:
- direction appeared to be led more by bean counters and with an eye on stock price, than "being an excellent technology company" or satisfying clients
- constant acquisition policy creates huge churn both within the company and for clients

review_title: Glad to be gone end of May
pros: My first 15 years were very good. Literally got to see the world. Worked great projects and with great people. Work-life balance was pretty good.  Enjoyed coming to work every day.
cons: Last 4+ years nothing but resource actions. Very stressful. Was very happy to be laid-off. Until my manager told me about the new severance packages. I felt totally disrespected considering all the work I put in over almost two decades. IBM could not pay me enough money to come back. The upside is I've had multiple job offers already because of my IBM experience.  Can't wait to be competing against IBM.

review_title: Great environment and very flexible workplace
pros: IBM is very flexible and allows remote work with no further questions whenever it is possible, especially if you are in a support role. Also, you are exposed to many technologies and IBM products and have the chance to interact with other teams.
cons: The facilities are not as modern as you would expect from a multinational. There is not even free beverages such as tea and coffee. Workplace is made up of a much older crowd so depending on your age you might feel a bit left out. Also, even though you probably are working within a team, you will feel that the lack of individual feedback is a problem.

pros:
Just the brand name.
The company can provide flexible working hours.

Work for a banking process called National Australia Bank. The management is indecisive and keep changing the parameters for improvement. This process/project restricts career growth for any employee despite meeting expectations. One has to literally beg the management to move out of the project for career opportunities.

review_title: Not the employer it was
pros: Opportunities, good graduate program, employees, culture.
cons:
Very demanding work
Long hours
Lack of training once out of graduate status
Lack of recognition either monetarily or through promotions
Constant separation programs.
Low morale amongst workforce.

review_title: Consultant
pros: Fine if you are looking to work for a very large international organisation and prepared to commit fully to it - opportunities for travel, and, if one is solely career focused then the rewards are there
cons: In order to progress, one has to fully commit to the company. Family life will / does suffer - as an example, I don't know how many senior executives who are still with their original partners. One gets paid in advance which is great to start with, but then if you want to leave ...... they have sort of got you over a barrel.

review_title: Doesn't care about the person no matter how much they say they do
job_title: Senior Program Manager in Providence, RI
pros: Most of the people are awesome - great attitude and teamwork abounds but teams get bogged down from lack of senior management direction.  Only a few VPs+ are inspirational, most are just blowing air and buzz words.
cons: Although they say that there is plenty of opportunity to transfer it is limited to your location, especially development teams.  Definitely block you when you are on the radar for a resource action and will set up layoff to the great advantage of IBM, even making it 2 days short of a month end just to save on vacation day accumulation for the laid off employees.

review_title: Culture that aims to continually improve, but values work-life balance.
pros: Constantly transforming, the company culture inspires in its individuals the desire to transform and improve. Also, work-life balance is great, especially for senior managing consultant level and below. 40-45 hour work weeks common. People care about people. Latest extension from 6 to 12 weeks for paternity leave demonstrates a continued recognition of the balance that people crave.
cons: typical downsides of transformation. There is a serious undercurrent of tried and true employees who are not embracing a new way, but upper management is on the side of pushing the boundaries - and that side will win out eventually.

review_title: Good company in terms of flexibility.However career growth options limited
pros:
-Excellent learning opportunities available
- Flexibility in work hours as well as option of performing various different roles across geographies
cons:
-Salary hike quite nominal
-People managers rarely are interested in the growth of the employee as they are assigned a large group of DRs to report to
- Career growth is an issue once an employee reaches a particular seniority level as no proper guidance or process laid out. Getting a mentor in a huge organization is always a challenge

review_title: An unique, essential company facing day-to-day challenges
pros:
* Great company with 100+ years of innovation history
* High proficiency, many very clever and skilled colleagues, several great leaders
* International work style, many learning opportunities
* Many cool products
* Agile transformation
* High degree of freedom - you can achieve almost anything if you want and deliver!
cons:
* Focus on cutting costs with limited financial and career opportunities
* Often still too busy to meet short time targets instead to believing in strategic success
* Still much legacy products with few innovation - not "cool" but the legacy customers depend on them

review_title: Great Place to work and grow.
job_title: Principal Talent Acquisitions Partner in Baton Rouge, LA
pros: IBM is like any other job. What makes it different is that you can learn and advance your skills to be in the top 10 of the market. IBM has great opportunities as it's a around  the world company. You can travel anywhere around the world & work at any IBM operations. You have to be a IBMer to know what it takes to thrive in this economy of challenges. Every challenge is a opportunity!
cons: The con's are based on people who do not apply themselves and want the easy way out.

review_title: Prioritized Location Over Knowledge
job_title: Agile Project Manager in Cambridge, MA
pros: I have worked here for many years and have had great opportunities to expand my career. I have had many different jobs over my 20+ here.  I have been fortunate to work with amazing people and have felt valued in the roles I have played.
cons: High level CIO leadership has decided that locating talent near where executives are is more important then retaining the knowledge base they have.   They are currently giving dozens of long time Massachusetts resources the ultimatum to move to NYC or Raleigh negating their claim that people are their most valuable resource.

review_title: It's big so you experience will vary
pros: There is a lot of potential to go into new or developing areas such as the Watson AI and machine learning space. Tons of different technologies in play that you can learn. Your front-line manager will make a huge impact on how you perceive the company and progress your career. Benefits seem average.
cons: Typical megacorp. It take a long time to get things done. There is a lot of red tape. IBM seems to be stalling vs their competitors. Salary sand benefits seem low compared to other technology firms.

review_title: As a top manager join, as a fresh graduate fly away ...
pros:
#Competency of the senior management
#Good balance between private and professional life
#Strong work mobility between different IBM locations
#Still a great name on a resume
cons:
#No employee development vision
#Only one 3days sessions in 2 years (fresh grad employee)
#Short term/PTI oriented decisions, even if the best long term choice is evident
#Very poor salary plan in the first years, even with a top performance grade
#Entry salary is only determined by grad schools studies. Personal and previous experiences are not valued

review_title: A good stepping stone
job_title: Senior I/T Specialist in Lake Dallas, TX
pros: Exposure to large projects and early exposure to new products and technologies.    The pay is industry average, and the entire experience can be heavily influenced on your immediate management; this is good and bad.  Having experience at IBM may be viewed as desireable by future employers.  There are lots of opportunities for professional and personal networking.
cons: Little personal attention given to skills development.  Preoccupation with Billable utilization over other important commitments.  Getting answers to client questions could be difficult at times, with the client sometimes getting 2 different directions from 2 separate Service areas within GS.

review_title: IBM - The ulitimate scene in office space
pros: Good benefits, large, well known corporation, top of the line opportunites to work with the newest technology, everything seems to change on a daily basis, you also have the option of working from home, very flexible as long as you get your stuff down. Great match rate on the 401(k) (only after your there for the 1st year)
cons: very bureaucratic, very secretive about recent layoffs, can feel diconnected due to working with people everywhere, awkard about the outsourcing that generally happens, the office atmosphere can sometimes feel like your stuck in a scene from office space, no tuition reimbursement until after 5 years with company

review_title: Life at IBM is ok at the ends (entry level/partner) don't get stuck in the middle
job_title: Senior Consultant in San Francisco, CA
pros: IBM has great benefits and discounts to just about everything you can think of. They have the best hotel and car rental rates, so it's great if you like to travel. Career development has become more objective with formal reviews and PDF frameworks, however navigating this can be tough.
cons: Lack of control on choice of projects and industry. Difficulty in changing sector/ lateral movement. There is no regular merit increases that you would find in industry. Raises typically happen either when you get promoted or when you show an offer letter from a competing company.

review_title: Times Have Changed At IBM
job_title: Senior Software Engineer in Westford, MA
pros: My co-workers were always supportive as well as some of the management team.  The atmosphere amongst the non-mangers is relatively good and most people get along.  People are not out to get your job or step on you.
cons: There isn't a tremendous opportuntiy to move up the ladder now a days.  However, most of the managers do not give consistent feedback either good or bad.  The employees need to hear from the managers mostly now with the down economy, so they don't have to look over their shoulders all the time.  You don't want a team that is paranoid about losing their job.

review_title: Your "career" as a financial analyst in the Rochester COE is a joke
pros:
1) Flexibility - Most managers will let you work from home if you are sick or if you are back in your hometown for a few days
2) 401K match is pretty solid - Dollar for dollar up to a 6% match, 100% vested after the first year
3) Health benefits are pretty good
4) The "IBM" name on your resume goes a long way
5) If you're a top performer they'll pay 100% of your tuition costs (MBA, grad degrees, etc)
cons:
1)  Compensation - Base salary is downright pathetic.  I counter-offered out of college and it was turned down, but decided to work for them anyway.  Annual raises only go to employees with PBC 1 and 2+ ratings (roughly 2% a year).  Bonuses are offered to only PBC 1 (top performers) and are about 4-5% of base salary.  They COE will offer "retention bonuses" to their top performing employees ($10K in two installments of $5K over two years.  Each year you are committed to stay with the company for one year.  If you leave you must pay the bonus back).  All of these "incentives" are a slap in the face because your base salary never really grows.  

2) Growth Opportunity - From day 1 you are sold that the opportunities are endless within IBM, but in reality they are not unless you want to settle for jobs that never give you face to face exposure with middle management or senior leaders.  They constantly try to sell you that the prize is going out to Somers, NY to work with the finance teams out there, but they'll give you $60k to move out there.....to NY, which is just laughable.  Once you get out there you will work 60-70 hours a week, and it might take you 5 years to get to a level of income where you're just breaking even due to the market prices out there.  

3) Environment - Rochester absolutely sucks and becomes depressing after the first year.  If you like small towns you might object to that statement.  Your first year might seem cool working with other twenty-somethings out of college, but after a few years you'll realize that an environment where people wear shorts to work and play foosball all day is not a place where you can further your career. Also, you will share an office with another co-worker that will be from 1970 and include a phone that is also from 1970.  You'll get a work laptop, but you have to buy your own monitor if you want something bigger than a 13'' screen.  (No joke).  

4) Cost Cutting - IBM manages their expenses very closely which means you do not get the leisure of having them pay for work outings, business cards, or other sensible acts of corporate kindness when you're working on Saturday's and Sunday's.  After I left the company, I was told that the Rochester COE would no longer be getting their offices cleaned or their trash taken out (employees have to take their own trash out!).  So it looks like not only are you a financial analyst now, but you're a part-time janitor as well.  

The above might make it seem like I hate IBM, but I really do not.  It's a great company....for shareholders.  If you can commit three years of your life here you will become very marketable and make a decent sum of money if you opt to work elsewhere.

review_title: Bureaucratic giant focused on cost reductions and controls
pros: Benefits are decent and generally speaking I found it easy to get personal time off when needed. My organization was spread out across the globe, so while I worked at an IBM office, I could work from home whenever I needed/wanted.
cons:
After 34 years I was selected to participate in a "Resource Action". I was given 30 days to find another job or be out the door. (I was out the door.) These RAs, always the end of the second month of a quarter, are designed to lower costs quickly. They are a common occurrence and because there are so many organizations the overall numbers are never high enough to get media coverage. It is a cloud over every employee's head. 

Executive management doesn't want to hear bad news, so middle management will spin any problem to save themselves. Even bad programs/products get out the door, the management in charge get their awards and move up and out before stuff hits the fan. Then new management has to fix the problem that they didn't cause.

Non-performing employees are kept around because headcount is so micromanaged that if someone is let go, there's a good chance that there will never be a backfill. So, managers are continually faced with the problem of keeping a bad performer around just to save the spot or save it until they're forced to make an RA selection. 

Expenses are micro-managed. In my Group, if you asked for $8 business cards, you had to go through reviews and get half a dozen upper managers to okay it - oh, and provide a list of external customers that you interfaced with to prove that the cards would be used in a clear revenue opportunity. Just before I left, the edict came out from CHQ - no external monitors or minidocks if you had a laptop. SW and HW developers writing code, running scripts, compiling, debugging in multiple windows, why would they need an external LCD monitor to actually see what they're doing??? Penny wise and pound foolish. Be prepared to buy things you'll need to do your job with your own dime.

It is clear that the goal is to reduce US headcount and increase headcount in those countries where the P/Y rate is a third of what it is in the US. That would be a good financial decision if those individuals had the necessary skills AND if they stuck around to do work and provide continuity. Turnover in those countries is very high because the employees are focused solely on making more money (who can blame them). 

IBM is clearly not the company I went to work for 34 years ago. We used to be proud to be IBMers. Today it is a paycheck. IBM tries to recruit from the best schools and the pay is competitive in the beginning, but by year 4, those hires will be behind their peers in other companies. IBM may have more patents than any other company, but it doesn't play out in how they reward their employees in job opportunities and advancement.
